description: The Linux Command Line show is designed to introduce viewers to working on Linux based computers using only the command line interface. This is considered the first step in learning BASH scripting as most scripts are made up of a series of CLI commands.
descriptionMD: The Linux Command Line show is designed to introduce viewers to working on Linux based computers using only the command line interface. This is considered the first step in learning BASH scripting as most scripts are made up of a series of CLI commands.
name: Linux Command Line
subtitle: Getting started in the Linux command line

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don take a look how to use a Linux terminal to gain access to the command line. They demonstrate Gnome terminal, Xterm, Konsole and several other terminals and walk through their configruation and use.
episodes.title: Terminals and Shells
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.210 --> 00:00:01.446
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.446 --> 00:00:06.490
I'm your host, Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.490 --> 00:00:08.482
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.482 --> 00:00:12.317
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.317 --> 00:00:14.275
>> All right, greetings everyone and

6
00:00:14.275 --> 00:00:16.825
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:16.825 --> 00:00:18.614
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and

8
00:00:18.614 --> 00:00:22.260
in today's episode we are kicking
off our Linux command line series.

9
00:00:22.260 --> 00:00:24.540
It's gonna be a lot of fun,
gonna learn a lot about Linux.

10
00:00:24.540 --> 00:00:27.590
And joining us in the studio,
our good friend, Mr. Don Pezet.

11
00:00:27.590 --> 00:00:29.010
Don, welcome to the show, sir.

12
00:00:29.010 --> 00:00:30.020
Thanks for coming today.

13
00:00:30.020 --> 00:00:31.149
>> Hey, thanks for having me, Daniel.

14
00:00:31.149 --> 00:00:33.410
And this is a really fun topic for me.

15
00:00:33.410 --> 00:00:36.050
Diving into the shell and
actually getting these working.

16
00:00:36.050 --> 00:00:39.050
We've got a series coming up on batch
scripting that's gonna have a ton of

17
00:00:39.050 --> 00:00:44.250
really cool things that you can do that
are all driven by the command line.

18
00:00:44.250 --> 00:00:46.960
So we need to know how to get in and
interact with that shell,

19
00:00:46.960 --> 00:00:50.380
interact with the interface that we have,
to actually kind of

20
00:00:50.380 --> 00:00:53.810
talk right to the Linux kernel and
get to do some really neat stuff.

21
00:00:53.810 --> 00:00:57.930
And one of the things that I always try
and remember is that in the Linux world,

22
00:00:57.930 --> 00:01:02.450
almost everything is developed
from the command line first, and

23
00:01:02.450 --> 00:01:06.330
then eventually gets a nice little GUI
stuck on it, a graphical user interface.

24
00:01:06.330 --> 00:01:09.087
But if you just stick in
the graphical environment,

25
00:01:09.087 --> 00:01:12.605
you're really limited, there's only so
many things you can do.

26
00:01:12.605 --> 00:01:16.325
And when you pull those shackles off and
dive right into the command line,

27
00:01:16.325 --> 00:01:17.286
sky's the limit.

28
00:01:17.286 --> 00:01:19.520
So you can do so much stuff.

29
00:01:19.520 --> 00:01:23.240
So I'm excited to dive into it here in
this episode, and really the whole series,

30
00:01:23.240 --> 00:01:25.930
to be able to see what we can do from
the command line, how we can use it, and

31
00:01:25.930 --> 00:01:28.960
some of the neat utilities that are there
that let us talk to that system.

32
00:01:28.960 --> 00:01:32.840
>> Well, Don, when we start talking about
terminals, right, the command line stuff,

33
00:01:32.840 --> 00:01:33.640
there are terminals.

34
00:01:33.640 --> 00:01:36.690
It's a little black box that pops up and
we type command into it.

35
00:01:36.690 --> 00:01:39.144
And we think, that's kind of vanilla.

36
00:01:39.144 --> 00:01:41.221
But there's a bit more to it than that,
right?

37
00:01:41.221 --> 00:01:45.916
>> Yeah, in the olden days where we had
a mainframe or something in that nature,

38
00:01:45.916 --> 00:01:48.330
you would have a dummy terminal.

39
00:01:48.330 --> 00:01:52.100
And a dummy terminal was a keyboard and
a monitor, and when you sat down at it,

40
00:01:52.100 --> 00:01:54.600
you would just see a command prompt.

41
00:01:54.600 --> 00:01:58.000
You didn't have a graphical user
interface, you didn't have a mouse.

42
00:01:58.000 --> 00:02:00.350
But on most computers these days,

43
00:02:00.350 --> 00:02:03.722
when you sit down at them, you actually
get a graphical user interface.

44
00:02:03.722 --> 00:02:05.520
So that the terminal, the command line,

45
00:02:05.520 --> 00:02:08.740
is kind of hidden away behind the scenes,
right?

46
00:02:08.740 --> 00:02:10.082
So we need to know how to get to it.

47
00:02:10.082 --> 00:02:13.232
And fortunately, there's actually
a number of different ways to get to it.

48
00:02:13.232 --> 00:02:16.563
Now, remember that Linux,
whether it's running as a desktop or

49
00:02:16.563 --> 00:02:20.270
whether it's running as a server,
it really is the same under the hood.

50
00:02:20.270 --> 00:02:22.090
There's a lot of operating
systems that differentiate.

51
00:02:22.090 --> 00:02:25.480
You have Windows Server versus
Windows Desktop, two different products.

52
00:02:25.480 --> 00:02:28.850
But in the Linux world,
it's really the same.

53
00:02:28.850 --> 00:02:31.170
The big difference is that when
you install Linux as a server,

54
00:02:31.170 --> 00:02:33.440
you normally leave the GUI off.

55
00:02:33.440 --> 00:02:36.490
So if you push the power
button on a Linux server,

56
00:02:36.490 --> 00:02:39.600
on the screen you see
the text-based terminal,

57
00:02:39.600 --> 00:02:42.960
the command prompt that you can jump
into and start to work with, right?

58
00:02:42.960 --> 00:02:46.800
But if you do it on a desktop,
you get a graphic user interface.

59
00:02:46.800 --> 00:02:48.970
Some people put a graphic
user interface on a server.

60
00:02:48.970 --> 00:02:51.300
But you're not really supposed to,
but you can.

61
00:02:51.300 --> 00:02:54.780
So either way, if we get the graphical
interface, how do we get at it?

62
00:02:54.780 --> 00:02:57.140
Well, it's not that
the text-based one is gone,

63
00:02:57.140 --> 00:02:58.810
the text-based one is
just kind of hidden away.

64
00:02:58.810 --> 00:03:00.110
So let me show you here on my laptop.

65
00:03:00.110 --> 00:03:03.446
So this is my laptop, I use it every
single day, and so I have a graphical user

66
00:03:03.446 --> 00:03:06.912
interface on it because I don't want to
do everything from the command shell.

67
00:03:06.912 --> 00:03:08.750
Although, I do a surprising
amount of things.

68
00:03:08.750 --> 00:03:09.655
>> Quite a bit, yeah.

69
00:03:09.655 --> 00:03:12.400
>> [LAUGH] So when I log in,
it's graphical, right?

70
00:03:12.400 --> 00:03:14.980
So I can launch in here and
I can browse my files, and

71
00:03:14.980 --> 00:03:18.250
do all the different things that I
need to do right here through a GUI.

72
00:03:18.250 --> 00:03:19.540
And then that's great, right?

73
00:03:19.540 --> 00:03:23.160
But if I want to access the terminal,

74
00:03:23.160 --> 00:03:26.050
the command prompt is actually
running in the background.

75
00:03:26.050 --> 00:03:27.830
I just don't see it, right?

76
00:03:27.830 --> 00:03:33.470
On most Linux distributions, you actually
have usually about six text-mode

77
00:03:33.470 --> 00:03:37.580
terminals that are running in the
background you're just not seeing, right?

78
00:03:37.580 --> 00:03:41.130
They fire up briefly while the computer's
booting up, and then the GUI loads and

79
00:03:41.130 --> 00:03:41.920
takes over from there.

80
00:03:41.920 --> 00:03:46.250
So I'm in X Windows but no Window
managers, all kind of running and

81
00:03:46.250 --> 00:03:47.580
giving a GUI.

82
00:03:47.580 --> 00:03:50.720
If you wanna see the text based stuff,
you can, but

83
00:03:50.720 --> 00:03:52.330
it's not as good as it used to be.

84
00:03:52.330 --> 00:03:54.885
And the main problem with that
is high resolution monitors.

85
00:03:54.885 --> 00:03:57.123
So the monitor on my laptop,
I forget my resolution,

86
00:03:57.123 --> 00:04:00.580
it's something like 3,200 by 1,800
something ridiculous like that.

87
00:04:00.580 --> 00:04:02.450
>> Crazy.
>> And high resolution monitor,

88
00:04:02.450 --> 00:04:07.505
even like a 1920 by 1080 monitor these
days makes the terminal almost unreadable.

89
00:04:07.505 --> 00:04:09.910
>> It's like a postage stamp
on your screen, it's crazy.

90
00:04:09.910 --> 00:04:11.410
>> It's really tiny.

91
00:04:11.410 --> 00:04:12.800
So here, let me pull mine up.

92
00:04:12.800 --> 00:04:17.110
And I'm just gonna switch right over
to one of my text-mode terminals.

93
00:04:17.110 --> 00:04:20.350
So you're gonna see my monitor blank out,
and then there it is, okay?

94
00:04:20.350 --> 00:04:22.280
I'm now in a text-mode terminal.

95
00:04:22.280 --> 00:04:24.070
And it's asking me to login.

96
00:04:24.070 --> 00:04:25.208
Now, how do I know that?

97
00:04:25.208 --> 00:04:26.890
>> [LAUGH]
>> Because if you look, I mean,

98
00:04:26.890 --> 00:04:29.060
that is really, really small.

99
00:04:29.060 --> 00:04:35.040
I know for you guys in TV land, you're
seeing this in the little boxed in view.

100
00:04:35.040 --> 00:04:37.480
But even if you were to full screen it,
it's really small.

101
00:04:37.480 --> 00:04:40.790
Even looking at my own monitor,
it is really small, I can barely read it.

102
00:04:40.790 --> 00:04:42.458
And unfortunately, there's no way for

103
00:04:42.458 --> 00:04:45.900
me to adjust that without like really
going in and re-engineering this terminal.

104
00:04:45.900 --> 00:04:48.381
You have to put in a giant font and
all this other stuff, so

105
00:04:48.381 --> 00:04:50.480
there's not an easy way to do it.

106
00:04:50.480 --> 00:04:53.710
As a result, this is not how we
normally access the terminal.

107
00:04:53.710 --> 00:05:00.000
If you do, if you ever want to do this,
the keyboard shortcuts are Ctrl+Alt+F1.

108
00:05:00.000 --> 00:05:06.580
And it's usually Ctrl+ F1 through F7, and
one of those will have the GUI, okay?

109
00:05:06.580 --> 00:05:10.219
Most operating systems
today put the GUI on F1.

110
00:05:10.219 --> 00:05:14.490
So if I hit ctrl+alt+F1, it should
return me back to my GUI, all right?

111
00:05:14.490 --> 00:05:16.300
Some distros put it one F7, though.

112
00:05:16.300 --> 00:05:19.140
And you hit Ctrl+Alt+F7, and there you go.

113
00:05:19.140 --> 00:05:21.982
Meanwhile, one through six,
or whatever ones aren't used,

114
00:05:21.982 --> 00:05:23.760
those are the text-based terminals.

115
00:05:23.760 --> 00:05:25.920
So they're there, they're running,
and you use them.

116
00:05:25.920 --> 00:05:28.979
If you ever lock up your graphical
user interface and you're stuck,

117
00:05:28.979 --> 00:05:31.878
you can drop to one of those terminals and
try and fix the problem,

118
00:05:31.878 --> 00:05:34.697
it's nice to have, if you also
have a magnifying glass [LAUGH].

119
00:05:34.697 --> 00:05:35.823
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

120
00:05:35.823 --> 00:05:39.293
that's not the normal way that
we get into our command prompt,

121
00:05:39.293 --> 00:05:42.450
to get into that kind session
to talk to the Linux kernel.

122
00:05:42.450 --> 00:05:46.910
So instead, what we normally
use is a terminal program.

123
00:05:46.910 --> 00:05:50.830
And there are a number of different
terminal programs that are available.

124
00:05:50.830 --> 00:05:54.647
And what you'll find is that over time,
you'll find one you really like,

125
00:05:54.647 --> 00:05:57.934
that you'll kind of bond with,
you'll team up and be buddies.

126
00:05:57.934 --> 00:06:00.035
>> That's like the Linux manifesto, right?

127
00:06:00.035 --> 00:06:04.750
Is do it the way you like to do it and
there's many options on the smorgasbord

128
00:06:04.750 --> 00:06:07.300
of different things that do
kinda the same stuff, right?

129
00:06:07.300 --> 00:06:08.310
>> Yeah, absolutely.

130
00:06:08.310 --> 00:06:10.740
And there's no right or wrong answer here.

131
00:06:10.740 --> 00:06:13.780
You need to find the one that
works out the best for you.

132
00:06:13.780 --> 00:06:17.989
Now, the best piece of advice I can
give you is don't just use what I use,

133
00:06:17.989 --> 00:06:20.197
because what I use is just what I like.

134
00:06:20.197 --> 00:06:25.013
And I get a little bit lazy sometimes,
not lazy as in I don't want to do work,

135
00:06:25.013 --> 00:06:29.630
but lazy as in I'm in a hurry and I want
to get to a terminal as fast as I can.

136
00:06:29.630 --> 00:06:32.159
There might be some flashy terminal
that has a lot of bells and

137
00:06:32.159 --> 00:06:33.357
whistles that's awesome.

138
00:06:33.357 --> 00:06:34.863
But if it's not installed by default,

139
00:06:34.863 --> 00:06:37.750
I don't want to deal with it cuz I don't
have time to install the terminal.

140
00:06:37.750 --> 00:06:39.358
I want to use something
that's already there.

141
00:06:39.358 --> 00:06:42.446
So a lot of times, I'll pick one
that I know is not as feature rich.

142
00:06:42.446 --> 00:06:44.733
So don't let me influence you.

143
00:06:44.733 --> 00:06:46.072
You need to find out what works for you.

144
00:06:46.072 --> 00:06:47.500
Or you might agree with me and say, hey,

145
00:06:47.500 --> 00:06:49.403
I only want to use stuff
that's installed natively.

146
00:06:49.403 --> 00:06:53.420
I don't want to have to install extra
packages to get to some crazy terminal.

147
00:06:53.420 --> 00:06:55.900
Now, when you install your Linux distro,

148
00:06:55.900 --> 00:06:59.290
it will have at least
one terminal available.

149
00:06:59.290 --> 00:07:02.490
And so you can use whatever GUI
you've got, if you got Unity,

150
00:07:02.490 --> 00:07:06.290
or I'm on GNOME here, if you have KDE.

151
00:07:06.290 --> 00:07:09.375
When you bring up your menu and
you just type in terminal,

152
00:07:09.375 --> 00:07:11.507
something's going to come up, okay?

153
00:07:11.507 --> 00:07:14.166
Now, I have a number of terminals
installed in my machine, so

154
00:07:14.166 --> 00:07:15.500
I see several choices.

155
00:07:15.500 --> 00:07:18.010
But you may only see one, right?

156
00:07:18.010 --> 00:07:19.910
It just depends on the distro.

157
00:07:19.910 --> 00:07:21.790
And the one that you'll normally
have is this guy right here,

158
00:07:21.790 --> 00:07:23.990
he's called Xterm, right?

159
00:07:23.990 --> 00:07:29.880
The X Windows GUI is kind of the defacto
standard for graphical interfaces.

160
00:07:29.880 --> 00:07:30.860
Now, it's changing.

161
00:07:30.860 --> 00:07:35.370
We have a replacement for X Windows
called, or Xterm is what that's actually

162
00:07:35.370 --> 00:07:38.620
called, that's slowly being
replaced by a product called Mir.

163
00:07:38.620 --> 00:07:40.390
And, or sorry, not Mir, Wayland.

164
00:07:40.390 --> 00:07:40.955
>> There we go [LAUGH].

165
00:07:40.955 --> 00:07:42.350
>> Gotta get my managers right.

166
00:07:42.350 --> 00:07:46.100
So Wayland is kinda taking over, so
you might not have XTerm in that case.

167
00:07:46.100 --> 00:07:48.688
In which case, you have other
terminals that might be available.

168
00:07:48.688 --> 00:07:52.859
But normally,
a distro will take some terminal and

169
00:07:52.859 --> 00:07:56.450
label it as just plain old terminal, okay?

170
00:07:56.450 --> 00:08:00.142
Now in a GNOME environment that's actually
what's called the GNOME Terminal.

171
00:08:00.142 --> 00:08:04.154
In a KDE environment, this would be
linking to what's called Konsole.

172
00:08:04.154 --> 00:08:06.860
Which I actually have installed also,
Konsole with a K.

173
00:08:06.860 --> 00:08:08.190
This is from KDE.

174
00:08:08.190 --> 00:08:12.530
But there are other terminals that
are out there that you might see.

175
00:08:12.530 --> 00:08:16.430
All of them provide the same
basic functionality.

176
00:08:16.430 --> 00:08:18.350
But then some of them
add a lot of bells and

177
00:08:18.350 --> 00:08:21.020
whistles that enable you to
do some really neat things.

178
00:08:21.020 --> 00:08:24.870
So if I were to launch into xterm,
that's the oldest one.

179
00:08:24.870 --> 00:08:26.690
That's the most basic terminal.

180
00:08:26.690 --> 00:08:29.939
And when I get into it, I see-
>> A postage stamp.

181
00:08:29.939 --> 00:08:30.451
>> It's pretty small.

182
00:08:30.451 --> 00:08:34.550
>> [LAUGH]
>> And if I were to zoom in,

183
00:08:34.550 --> 00:08:36.500
I can read it now, right?

184
00:08:36.500 --> 00:08:41.130
But xterm is really operating the same way

185
00:08:41.130 --> 00:08:42.850
as those text mode terminals
in the background.

186
00:08:42.850 --> 00:08:47.130
It's just putting a GUI
wrapper around that terminal.

187
00:08:47.130 --> 00:08:50.170
And I can get in and
I can do some set term commands to try and

188
00:08:50.170 --> 00:08:51.650
change the background color.

189
00:08:51.650 --> 00:08:54.140
And other things to try and
make it useful.

190
00:08:54.140 --> 00:08:59.410
But as far as the GUI is concerned,
there's not really any options for me.

191
00:08:59.410 --> 00:09:02.910
There's not much of a menu here
other than minimize and maximize.

192
00:09:02.910 --> 00:09:05.610
And even if I go up to the menu
items up here, there's just quit.

193
00:09:05.610 --> 00:09:08.770
I don't get a lot of
functionality with xterm.

194
00:09:08.770 --> 00:09:12.520
This was the original, graphical
terminal that was made available and so

195
00:09:12.520 --> 00:09:15.090
it's got a very basic set.

196
00:09:15.090 --> 00:09:16.590
So most of us aren't gonna use that one.

197
00:09:16.590 --> 00:09:20.520
Most of us are gonna use GNOME Term or
Konsole if you're in KDE.

198
00:09:20.520 --> 00:09:22.830
But GNOME Term is really
the most popular one.

199
00:09:22.830 --> 00:09:28.190
If you're running Ubuntu,
Debian, Fedora, RedHat, Centos.

200
00:09:28.190 --> 00:09:31.780
All of those distros
default to Gnome Term.

201
00:09:31.780 --> 00:09:34.550
Ubuntu is using the Unity window manager.

202
00:09:34.550 --> 00:09:37.770
But the Unity window manager actually
uses GNOME Term as its terminal.

203
00:09:37.770 --> 00:09:40.520
So even though it's not GNOME,
it's still using that terminal.

204
00:09:40.520 --> 00:09:42.400
So that's kind of the most popular one.

205
00:09:42.400 --> 00:09:45.610
And that's the one that I'm gonna use for
the rest of this series.

206
00:09:45.610 --> 00:09:48.680
So for the whole series,
I'm going to be using the GNOME Terminal.

207
00:09:48.680 --> 00:09:51.740
But I wanna walk you through a few of the
other terminals here in this episode to

208
00:09:51.740 --> 00:09:55.830
give you an idea of which ones might
be great or which ones might be lame.

209
00:09:55.830 --> 00:09:57.930
>> They get kind of fancy,
don't they, Don?

210
00:09:57.930 --> 00:09:58.650
>> They really do.

211
00:09:58.650 --> 00:10:01.090
Some of them, some have some
really impressive feature sets.

212
00:10:01.090 --> 00:10:04.660
So, for example,
let me just fire up real quick.

213
00:10:04.660 --> 00:10:06.170
We'll breeze through a few real quick and

214
00:10:06.170 --> 00:10:08.110
then I'll do a deeper
dive into some of them.

215
00:10:08.110 --> 00:10:09.840
So, for example, the GNOME Termina.

216
00:10:09.840 --> 00:10:14.670
If I just fire up my terminal, this is the
GNOME Terminal, the default built one in.

217
00:10:14.670 --> 00:10:16.640
See how I got a nice big font?

218
00:10:16.640 --> 00:10:19.890
Well, it didn't have that by default but I
was able to change it because I've got all

219
00:10:19.890 --> 00:10:21.940
these menu options up here
where I can tweak it.

220
00:10:21.940 --> 00:10:23.600
I can change the font size.

676
00:31:33.670 --> 00:31:35.720
So those traditional copy and

677
00:31:35.720 --> 00:31:39.430
paste don't quite work the way
that you might expect them to.

678
00:31:39.430 --> 00:31:42.390
Now you can always use your mouse,
right, which is a little bit anti-Unix.

679
00:31:42.390 --> 00:31:44.031
But we're not in Unix,
right, we're in Linux.

680
00:31:44.031 --> 00:31:47.705
I can highlight with the mouse and
I can right-click and I can choose copy,

681
00:31:47.705 --> 00:31:50.225
and then I can right-click and
I can choose paste.

682
00:31:50.225 --> 00:31:52.484
And there we go, it worked, right?

683
00:31:52.484 --> 00:31:57.411
But a lot of terminals will rematch
shortcuts to something that actually does

684
00:31:57.411 --> 00:31:59.165
work inside of a terminal.

685
00:31:59.165 --> 00:32:02.678
Whichever terminal you pick, you'll need
to look at what its defaults are, right?

686
00:32:02.678 --> 00:32:06.870
Back up here and edit and preferences.

687
00:32:06.870 --> 00:32:11.698
We had the shortcuts and right here is
where I could define a number of shortcuts

688
00:32:11.698 --> 00:32:13.391
including copy and paste.

689
00:32:13.391 --> 00:32:16.639
And if you take a look at
the ones that are in here,

690
00:32:16.639 --> 00:32:19.824
it's got Shift+Ctrl+C, Shift+Ctrl+V.

691
00:32:19.824 --> 00:32:22.973
So instead of just hitting
Ctrl+C I hit shift as well and

692
00:32:22.973 --> 00:32:26.464
that's how it avoids sending
the breaking command, right?

693
00:32:26.464 --> 00:32:30.456
So that'll make sure that it does that and
ensures that I can copy it.

694
00:32:30.456 --> 00:32:33.812
So now, I could come in and
I could highlight something.

695
00:32:33.812 --> 00:32:37.556
And I could hit, I don't usually do
Shift+Ctrl, I usually do Ctrl+Shift.

696
00:32:37.556 --> 00:32:41.320
But Ctrl+Shift+C to copy and
then Ctrl+Shift+V and

697
00:32:41.320 --> 00:32:44.851
there I'm pasting what I highlighted,
all right?

698
00:32:44.851 --> 00:32:47.047
Now in the GNOME Terminal,
that's the way you do it.

699
00:32:47.047 --> 00:32:48.869
That's the shortcut that you remember.

700
00:32:48.869 --> 00:32:52.361
In some terminals though they do
what's called copy on highlight,

701
00:32:52.361 --> 00:32:55.059
where if you just highlight
something the moment you

702
00:32:55.059 --> 00:32:57.835
let go off your mouse it
copies it into the clipboard.

703
00:32:57.835 --> 00:33:02.456
And the moment you right click it
immediately paste that data, right?

704
00:33:02.456 --> 00:33:05.298
The GNOME Terminal doesn't do that but
there are terminals that do.

705
00:33:05.298 --> 00:33:08.558
And they usually just call that
copy on click or copy on highlight.

706
00:33:08.558 --> 00:33:10.676
So as you dig through
the options on your terminal,

707
00:33:10.676 --> 00:33:12.560
you may find something
that indicates that.

708
00:33:12.560 --> 00:33:16.817
And I don't think I have
that option here at all.

709
00:33:16.817 --> 00:33:18.788
If we take a look at even Shortcuts,

710
00:33:18.788 --> 00:33:21.959
O'm pretty sure GNOME Terminal
doesn't support that.

711
00:33:21.959 --> 00:33:25.599
But like I said, yours might and if you
dig through your options you may find it

712
00:33:25.599 --> 00:33:28.406
and see where you can turn that on or
customize that option.

713
00:33:28.406 --> 00:33:30.323
So that's another way we might do that.

714
00:33:30.323 --> 00:33:32.963
But again, it does vary a bit
from terminal to terminal.

715
00:33:32.963 --> 00:33:33.468
>> All right.

716
00:33:33.468 --> 00:33:35.133
Well Don,
we've run out of time with this episode.

717
00:33:35.133 --> 00:33:39.960
I know you have more to go,
jumping into the shells area or the arena,

718
00:33:39.960 --> 00:33:40.967
should I say.

719
00:33:40.967 --> 00:33:43.257
>> Yeah.
>> But looks like we'll have to wait for

720
00:33:43.257 --> 00:33:44.135
part two on that.

721
00:33:44.135 --> 00:33:45.302
We do thank you for joining today.

722
00:33:45.302 --> 00:33:48.717
Is there anything you'd like to
part our guests with before we go?

723
00:33:48.717 --> 00:33:50.768
>> I certainly didn't get to
every terminal in the world,

724
00:33:50.768 --> 00:33:53.136
there's hundreds of them, and
you might have a favourite one.

725
00:33:53.136 --> 00:33:56.218
I know I left out Konsole,
the one from KDE.

726
00:33:56.218 --> 00:34:00.595
KDE's console has a neat little bookmark
feature, where you can bookmark folders as

727
00:34:00.595 --> 00:34:03.714
you navigate your file system,
you can bookmark location.

728
00:34:03.714 --> 00:34:05.864
And so when you launch that console,
you can say go to this bookmark and

729
00:34:05.864 --> 00:34:07.437
it jumps right to that
location on the file system.

730
00:34:07.437 --> 00:34:09.265
>> Very nice.
>> It's a neat feature.

731
00:34:09.265 --> 00:34:14.125
All of those terminals, they have bright
shiny spots that make them great to use.

732
00:34:14.125 --> 00:34:16.349
They usually have a couple of
cons that make them not so great.

733
00:34:16.349 --> 00:34:19.574
You just gotta find the one that's
perfect for you and it's trial and error.

734
00:34:19.574 --> 00:34:21.970
Usually they're very small so
it's easy to install a bunch of them.

735
00:34:21.970 --> 00:34:24.989
I probably have five different
terminals installed here.

736
00:34:24.989 --> 00:34:28.070
Just take a look at what you've got and
find out what one you like and

737
00:34:28.070 --> 00:34:31.333
just know that it's pretty easy to
move to another one if you chose to.

738
00:34:31.333 --> 00:34:31.946
>> That's right.

739
00:34:31.946 --> 00:34:33.054
It never hurts to test drive something,
right?

740
00:34:33.054 --> 00:34:35.076
You're not locked into it.

741
00:34:35.076 --> 00:34:37.752
You don't like it, you delete it,
and you move on to the next thing.

742
00:34:37.752 --> 00:34:38.972
Don, thanks for joining us today.

743
00:34:38.972 --> 00:34:42.865
We appreciate your expertise on this and
imparting that into us.

744
00:34:42.865 --> 00:34:45.048
But as I've said,
we're out of time for this episode.

745
00:34:45.048 --> 00:34:47.877
Definitely come back for
part two as we look into shells.

746
00:34:47.877 --> 00:34:51.363
But as for this episode and we are gonna
go ahead and sign off for ITProTV.

747
00:34:51.363 --> 00:34:52.928
I've been your host Daniel Lawry.

748
00:34:52.928 --> 00:34:53.865
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

749
00:34:53.865 --> 00:34:56.548
>> And we'll see you next time.

750
00:34:56.548 --> 00:35:02.089
[MUSIC]

751
00:35:02.089 --> 00:35:05.459
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don take a look how to interact with the Linux kernel using a shell. They demonstrate the bash shell and highlight zsh, dash, and sh and walk through their configuration and use.
episodes.title: Terminals and Shells Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.190 --> 00:00:01.251
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.251 --> 00:00:02.092
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.092 --> 00:00:02.828
>> We're creating vectors.

4
00:00:02.828 --> 00:00:04.986
>> Coming at you live from San Francisco,
California.

5
00:00:04.986 --> 00:00:11.887
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.887 --> 00:00:13.736
>> All right, greetings, everyone,

7
00:00:13.736 --> 00:00:16.488
and welcome back to another
great episode of ITProTV.

8
00:00:16.488 --> 00:00:19.067
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode,

9
00:00:19.067 --> 00:00:21.700
we're back with more on our
Linux Command Line series.

10
00:00:21.700 --> 00:00:23.330
And of course,
joining us back in the studio,

11
00:00:23.330 --> 00:00:26.390
lending his expertise in that topic,
our good friend, Mr. Don Pezet.

12
00:00:26.390 --> 00:00:28.180
Don, we're so
glad to have you yet again today.

13
00:00:28.180 --> 00:00:28.910
How's it going?

14
00:00:28.910 --> 00:00:30.040
>> It is going great, Daniel,

15
00:00:30.040 --> 00:00:32.830
ready to dive into the world
of terminals and shells.

16
00:00:32.830 --> 00:00:33.825
And this is part two.

17
00:00:33.825 --> 00:00:34.896
If you watched part one,

18
00:00:34.896 --> 00:00:37.660
we really spent our time just
talking about terminals, right?

19
00:00:37.660 --> 00:00:40.370
We didn't really delve
into a shell at all.

20
00:00:40.370 --> 00:00:41.310
We saw a shell a few times.

21
00:00:41.310 --> 00:00:42.510
We didn't actually work with it.

22
00:00:42.510 --> 00:00:43.520
So in this episode,

23
00:00:43.520 --> 00:00:47.400
what I wanna do is actually hit the more
important part, what the heck a shell is.

24
00:00:47.400 --> 00:00:49.730
And so we're gonna see some of
the different shells that are available.

25
00:00:49.730 --> 00:00:53.458
Understand what that difference between
a terminal and a shell happens to be.

26
00:00:53.458 --> 00:00:56.523
And get in there and get that chance to
kinda work with it and start to see some

27
00:00:56.523 --> 00:00:59.783
of our first commands, because for a
command line show, we were pretty light on

28
00:00:59.783 --> 00:01:02.231
the commands in the last episode, so-
>> [LAUGH]

29
00:01:02.231 --> 00:01:03.488
>> It's probably time to start running

30
00:01:03.488 --> 00:01:04.059
some commands.

31
00:01:04.059 --> 00:01:06.810
So we're gonna get you to see all
that right here in this episode.

32
00:01:06.810 --> 00:01:08.590
>> All right, Don this sounds interesting.

33
00:01:08.590 --> 00:01:11.230
Let's talk about that,
what in the world is a shell,

34
00:01:11.230 --> 00:01:14.620
because I know
the Linux-uninitiated is going,

35
00:01:14.620 --> 00:01:19.170
everybody keeps talking about shells, but
no one's telling me what they are exactly.

36
00:01:19.170 --> 00:01:21.883
>> All right,
when we work with the command line, right,

37
00:01:21.883 --> 00:01:23.923
a lot of people will call it a CLI, right?

38
00:01:23.923 --> 00:01:26.860
And CLI stands for
command line interpreter.

39
00:01:26.860 --> 00:01:28.043
You got a line on the screen.

40
00:01:28.043 --> 00:01:30.020
You type a command.

41
00:01:30.020 --> 00:01:34.183
And the operating system has to interpret
what you typed into something the computer

42
00:01:34.183 --> 00:01:38.239
understands, cuz what we type is usually
what's considered human-readable.

43
00:01:38.239 --> 00:01:41.430
I know the commands sometimes are wacky
and weird and don't make any sense.

44
00:01:41.430 --> 00:01:44.680
But they're somewhat human-readable, but
they're not what the computer wants.

45
00:01:44.680 --> 00:01:46.490
The computer wants machine code.

46
00:01:46.490 --> 00:01:50.640
That's what it wants, is the really
low-level programming language that

47
00:01:50.640 --> 00:01:53.200
none of us can really work with.

48
00:01:53.200 --> 00:01:55.138
None of us here on camera, at least.

49
00:01:55.138 --> 00:01:57.230
>> [LAUGH]
>> Certainly can.

50
00:01:57.230 --> 00:01:59.400
It is very difficult to work
with is the point, though.

51
00:01:59.400 --> 00:02:01.360
So we have these easier terms,

52
00:02:01.360 --> 00:02:04.460
these easier executables that we run and
the computer then works with.

53
00:02:04.460 --> 00:02:08.280
So a command line interpreter
is kind of like a translator,

54
00:02:08.280 --> 00:02:10.890
translating between the human and
the computer.

55
00:02:10.890 --> 00:02:13.519
And that's really what your shell is.

56
00:02:13.519 --> 00:02:16.587
The shell is the interpreter that
you're choosing to work with,

57
00:02:16.587 --> 00:02:18.439
that you're handing the commands to.

58
00:02:18.439 --> 00:02:22.377
And then it's figuring out what
to do with those commands.

59
00:02:22.377 --> 00:02:25.905
The terminal, what we saw yesterday, or
in the previous episode, depending on when

60
00:02:25.905 --> 00:02:28.970
you watched it, maybe not yesterday-
>> [LAUGH]

61
00:02:28.970 --> 00:02:30.160
>> The terminal

62
00:02:30.160 --> 00:02:32.790
is simply a way to see the shell.

63
00:02:33.860 --> 00:02:36.820
How can I actually view
the shell on my screen?

64
00:02:36.820 --> 00:02:37.790
I use a terminal.

65
00:02:37.790 --> 00:02:41.366
And it might be a physical hardware
terminal, like the old dummy terminals.

66
00:02:41.366 --> 00:02:43.137
Or it might be a graphical terminal,

67
00:02:43.137 --> 00:02:45.601
like GNOME Term that I'm
using here on the screen.

68
00:02:45.601 --> 00:02:50.584
Or XTERM or Konsole, any of the various
other products that are out there,

69
00:02:50.584 --> 00:02:53.049
those are just a way to see the shell.

70
00:02:53.049 --> 00:02:54.662
And the shell is what's
really doing the work.

71
00:02:54.662 --> 00:02:56.760
So your terminal is just bells and
whistles,

72
00:02:56.760 --> 00:02:58.702
just making things look pretty, right?

73
00:02:58.702 --> 00:03:01.123
And that's really what the last
episode centered around.

74
00:03:01.123 --> 00:03:02.692
That's why we didn't
have to run any commands,

75
00:03:02.692 --> 00:03:04.043
cuz it's all just making it look pretty.

76
00:03:04.043 --> 00:03:08.453
But the shell itself
is all about commands.

77
00:03:08.453 --> 00:03:12.892
And so when we fire up a terminal,
what we see is our actual shell.

78
00:03:12.892 --> 00:03:15.610
So if we look in my screen,
I've got my GNOME Terminal fired up.

79
00:03:15.610 --> 00:03:17.637
And here's a command prompt.

80
00:03:17.637 --> 00:03:21.056
Here's an entry where I can
start to type commands, and

81
00:03:21.056 --> 00:03:24.053
I can tell the computer to do something,
right?

82
00:03:24.053 --> 00:03:26.519
I can tell it, hey,
I wanna know what my hostname is.

83
00:03:26.519 --> 00:03:32.410
And so I type in hostnamectl,
and I press Enter, right?

84
00:03:32.410 --> 00:03:36.111
When I press Enter,
that tells the shell to do something.

85
00:03:36.111 --> 00:03:37.780
And the shell says, okay,
well, what did you type?

86
00:03:37.780 --> 00:03:38.780
You typed hostnamectl.

87
00:03:38.780 --> 00:03:39.606
What does that mean?

88
00:03:39.606 --> 00:03:42.123
All right, I've got a binary file
over here that has the same name,

89
00:03:42.123 --> 00:03:43.960
so that's must be what you're calling.

90
00:03:43.960 --> 00:03:47.240
So let me go and find that binary and
execute it and run it and

91
00:03:47.240 --> 00:03:48.710
do whatever it says.

92
00:03:48.710 --> 00:03:52.910
And then that binary says, we're
gonna output on the screen this data.

93
00:03:52.910 --> 00:03:55.660
And so then the interpreter says,
let me take that data and

94
00:03:55.660 --> 00:03:58.610
turn it into a human-readable format,
not ones and zeroes.

95
00:03:58.610 --> 00:04:00.840
And let me throw it on the screen,
and here it is.

96
00:04:00.840 --> 00:04:02.703
I can see my computer
is called Dons-Laptop,

97
00:04:02.703 --> 00:04:04.535
cuz I'm very creative with computer names.

98
00:04:04.535 --> 00:04:07.230
>> Yeah.
>> So I can see that information.

99
00:04:07.230 --> 00:04:10.270
That's me interacting with the shell.

100
00:04:10.270 --> 00:04:13.097
Technically, it's me interacting
with the terminal and the shell.

101
00:04:13.097 --> 00:04:14.262
The two go together.

102
00:04:14.262 --> 00:04:18.170
It's kinda like chocolate and
peanut butter in a peanut butter cup.

103
00:04:18.170 --> 00:04:19.530
>> [LAUGH]
>> The two work together to

104
00:04:19.530 --> 00:04:22.770
give me that way to
interface with the computer.

105
00:04:22.770 --> 00:04:24.100
And so I'm accessing it.

106
00:04:24.100 --> 00:04:27.520
I'm typing commands, and
that's with the shell is doing.

107
00:04:27.520 --> 00:04:30.630
So this is the Linux shell, in this case.

108
00:04:30.630 --> 00:04:32.730
>> So Don, the shell is our interpreter.

109
00:04:32.730 --> 00:04:35.580
It's the middleman between us and
the computer hardware.

110
00:04:35.580 --> 00:04:37.990
Is there any other specific thing
we need to know about the shell?

111
00:04:37.990 --> 00:04:40.710
I opened this black terminal
prompt you have opened.

112
00:04:40.710 --> 00:04:44.380
And is there something specific
about that that I'll need to know?

113
00:04:44.380 --> 00:04:47.820
>> Well, on most systems,
the shell is the same.

114
00:04:47.820 --> 00:04:50.110
So you drop, and you'll get a prompt,
something like this.

115
00:04:50.110 --> 00:04:51.650
Now, the prompt can be customized, right?

116
00:04:51.650 --> 00:04:52.560
You can tweak and change it.

117
00:04:52.560 --> 00:04:54.160
People go crazy with it.

118
00:04:54.160 --> 00:04:58.090
Mine is just [COUGH] a default prompt
where I've got the username and

119
00:04:58.090 --> 00:05:02.750
computer name, followed by
the file system path that I'm in,

120
00:05:02.750 --> 00:05:05.830
followed by a little symbol here that
let's me know my privilege level.

121
00:05:05.830 --> 00:05:11.210
So a $ in this case means I'm
just a regular old user, versus,

122
00:05:11.210 --> 00:05:14.840
if it was a pound symbol, that would mean
that I was an administrative user or

123
00:05:14.840 --> 00:05:17.940
the root user, somebody who's got
a lot more control over the system.

124
00:05:17.940 --> 00:05:20.510
So all of that's being
communicated to me via the prompt.

125
00:05:20.510 --> 00:05:21.670
But none of that has to be there.

126
00:05:21.670 --> 00:05:24.060
You can actually make the prompt
completely blank if you want.

127
00:05:24.060 --> 00:05:25.649
It makes it annoying, but you can do that.

128
00:05:25.649 --> 00:05:27.311
>> [LAUGH]
>> So now you start typing commands, and

129
00:05:27.311 --> 00:05:29.670
it works, so
the prompt is purely optional.

130
00:05:29.670 --> 00:05:35.190
But the shell itself, in this case,
I'm using a shell that's called Bash.

131
00:05:35.190 --> 00:05:37.942
And Bash stands for
the Bourne Again Shell.

132
00:05:37.942 --> 00:05:39.521
I say it's just a shell.

133
00:05:39.521 --> 00:05:45.330
And it is one of a multitude of shells
that are available, that are out there.

134
00:05:45.330 --> 00:05:48.330
Now, in the first episode,
we talked about terminals.

135
00:05:48.330 --> 00:05:50.690
And I said, hey,
just pick the terminal that works for you.

136
00:05:50.690 --> 00:05:52.650
Pick the one that you like the best,
right?

137
00:05:52.650 --> 00:05:54.130
You got a lot of flexibility there.

138
00:05:54.130 --> 00:05:57.010
And if I fire up three
different terminals,

139
00:05:57.010 --> 00:06:00.590
they might all be giving me
access to the Bash shell.

140
00:06:00.590 --> 00:06:03.850
And the Bash shell works
the same under each one.

141
00:06:03.850 --> 00:06:08.282
So it doesn't matter
if I use Terminator or

142
00:06:08.282 --> 00:06:12.351
tmux or Konsole or XTERM or GNOME Term.

143
00:06:12.351 --> 00:06:16.590
It doesn't matter, cuz they're all
just giving me the Bash shell.

144
00:06:16.590 --> 00:06:18.975
But Bash is not the only one, right?

145
00:06:18.975 --> 00:06:23.068
There's actually many other shells that
are available, that your system may or

146
00:06:23.068 --> 00:06:23.801
may not have.

147
00:06:23.801 --> 00:06:28.882
Now, if you're running Red Hat Linux or
Fedora, CentOS, a lot

148
00:06:28.882 --> 00:06:35.295
of the other distributions like Slackware,
they all default to the Bash shell.

149
00:06:35.295 --> 00:06:38.570
So that's kind of a common
experience that you're gonna have.

150
00:06:38.570 --> 00:06:41.780
But there are some distros,
like Debian and

151
00:06:41.780 --> 00:06:46.570
Ubuntu, that default to a different shell,

We try real hard to do that for

00:29:36.003 --> 00:29:37.015
>> [LAUGH]
>> But

00:29:37.015 --> 00:29:40.235
it is that time looking at the clock,
we've run out of the precious little

seconds that make up our episode
>> We're gonna go ahead and

597
00:29:42.400 --> 00:29:45.700
sign off for ITPro.TV,

00:29:45.700 --> 00:29:46.340
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don walks the viewers through the various ways you can get help from the Linux command line. He demonstrates the man command as well as info, apropos and other methods of retrieving help.
episodes.title: Getting Help

Mr Don Pezet, joining us today.

we're gonna be opening

not just the commands itself, but all the

25

change the way the commands work
>> Those are my favorite.

26

>> It's a lot, yeah, it's overwhelming.

27

So before we do that, though, before we

28

29

How do we find out what

30

How we do we figure out
how to use a command?

32

How do we figure out if

33

So in this episode,

34
00:01:25.190 --> 00:01:27.450
That Linux, as an operating system,

35

as a whole, has really good documentation

36
00:01:31.140 --> 00:01:32.930
Now a lot of that comes

37
00:01:32.930 --> 00:01:37.100
So some of the documentation is really

38
00:01:37.100 --> 00:01:38.920
We just need to know that it's there.

39

40

And so the stuff in this episode

41

that you want to always

43
00:01:48.050 --> 00:01:49.380
And if you know the commands
from this episode,

44
00:01:49.380 --> 00:01:53.870
you'll be able to find them, stumble
back upon them and make some use of it.

45
00:01:53.870 --> 00:01:55.576
So this is stuff that's
really critical for

46
00:01:55.576 --> 00:01:58.010
the day-to-day operation of
using the Linux command line.

47
00:01:58.010 --> 00:01:59.410
>> Don, this is not a joke.

48
00:01:59.410 --> 00:02:04.011
I have been using Linux since 1999,
I believe,

49
00:02:04.011 --> 00:02:07.370
and I still use all the help features.

50
00:02:07.370 --> 00:02:09.747
You're never gonna memorize
every little switch and

51
00:02:09.747 --> 00:02:11.410
option that comes with a command.

52
00:02:11.410 --> 00:02:13.880
Heck, I might not even remember
exactly what the command is, or

53
00:02:13.880 --> 00:02:16.190
where it's located, or
those configuration files.

54
00:02:16.190 --> 00:02:20.530
We need to be able to get help with our
system because man, you're gonna need it,

55
00:02:20.530 --> 00:02:21.810
so this is great stuff.

56
00:02:21.810 --> 00:02:24.020
Don, where do we start when
it comes to getting help?

57
00:02:24.020 --> 00:02:27.640
>> All right, so some commands,
if you just remember their name,

58
00:02:27.640 --> 00:02:31.210
they have a simple thing that you run,
and that's it, right?

59
00:02:31.210 --> 00:02:35.379
So if I'm in my shell, like I am right
now, and I wanna know what folder I'm in,

60
00:02:35.379 --> 00:02:37.390
there's a command for that, right?

61
00:02:37.390 --> 00:02:41.990
There's the pwd command or
the present working directory.

62
00:02:41.990 --> 00:02:45.030
So it's gonna show me the direct
ribbon I'm in in the file system.

63
00:02:45.030 --> 00:02:48.920
And if I run it, I just run the command,
and there it is, right?

64
00:02:48.920 --> 00:02:52.260
So some commands, it's really just
a matter of remembering their name.

65
00:02:52.260 --> 00:02:56.370
But a lot of commands will require
additional arguments to make them work.

66
00:02:56.370 --> 00:02:59.650
You have to provide additional
feedback into them, otherwise,

67
00:02:59.650 --> 00:03:01.120
they just don't work by themselves.

68
00:03:01.120 --> 00:03:05.132
So for example, the copy command,
copy is cp, all right?

69
00:03:05.132 --> 00:03:09.899
And if I do copy, it's expecting me to
say a source file and a destination file,

70
00:03:09.899 --> 00:03:11.290
all right?

71
00:03:11.290 --> 00:03:15.550
So I might copy file1 to file2, right?

72
00:03:15.550 --> 00:03:19.150
If I don't give it those arguments,
if I just type cp, and

73
00:03:19.150 --> 00:03:22.200
press Enter,
it gives me a little bit of help, right?

74
00:03:22.200 --> 00:03:24.108
And when I say a little bit,
I mean that literally.

75
00:03:24.108 --> 00:03:26.320
>> [LAUGH]
>> It is a little bit of help.

76
00:03:26.320 --> 00:03:29.275
Sometimes they're very, very detailed,
but usually, it's something like this.

77
00:03:29.275 --> 00:03:32.800
And it's telling me,
you kind of forgot to provide an operand.

78
00:03:32.800 --> 00:03:36.534
You didn't provide the command
line options and arguments,

79
00:03:36.534 --> 00:03:39.370
so it's not able to do its job, okay?

80
00:03:39.370 --> 00:03:40.978
We need to give it some more.

81
00:03:40.978 --> 00:03:45.714
So if you've forgotten just the argument,
that's not such a big deal, right?

82
00:03:45.714 --> 00:03:47.378
You can just run the command, and

83
00:03:47.378 --> 00:03:49.950
it will usually tell you
how you can find more help.

84
00:03:49.950 --> 00:03:53.962
And in this case,
it's telling me that I can run cp -- help.

85
00:03:53.962 --> 00:03:57.580
All right, now, when it comes to
command line arguments like this,

86
00:03:57.580 --> 00:03:59.980
there's actually two different forms for
providing it.

87
00:03:59.980 --> 00:04:02.900
And you'll see this commonly throughout
all the commands that we run.

88
00:04:02.900 --> 00:04:08.397
The old style Unix way of doing it was
a single dash followed by a single letter,

89
00:04:08.397 --> 00:04:09.540
all right?

90
00:04:09.540 --> 00:04:15.190
So you might see cp-h,
and that -h was help.

91
00:04:15.190 --> 00:04:18.750
But in the BSD world,
they started using words instead.

92
00:04:18.750 --> 00:04:20.800
It was a little more user friendly, right?

93
00:04:20.800 --> 00:04:22.350
And so here it's help.

94
00:04:22.350 --> 00:04:26.790
But we wanna make sure that Unix or
Linux in this case understands

95
00:04:26.790 --> 00:04:32.030
that it's not H-E-L-P, individual letters,
it's not four arguments.

96
00:04:32.030 --> 00:04:33.880
It's one word, called help.

97
00:04:33.880 --> 00:04:37.880
And that's where the double
dashes come in, the --help.

98
00:04:37.880 --> 00:04:42.480
So if I wanna learn more about cp,
I can run cp- -help,

99
00:04:42.480 --> 00:04:46.330
and it's gonna provide me
with the help information.

100
00:04:46.330 --> 00:04:48.949
And when I look at the information here,

101
00:04:48.949 --> 00:04:53.350
as it goes to tell me how to use
the command, it lays it all out for me.

102
00:04:53.350 --> 00:04:56.350
And I can start to see it, and
here's actually that --help right here.

103
00:04:56.350 --> 00:04:59.840
That displays this help,
and then it exits, right?

104
00:04:59.840 --> 00:05:04.020
But there's plenty of other
commands that I could've run.

105
00:05:04.020 --> 00:05:09.510
And as I look down the list, I'll see -a,
-b, -d, all of these are options.

106
00:05:09.510 --> 00:05:14.140
And when I look at the very top,
that's where it gives me my actual syntax,

107
00:05:14.140 --> 00:05:16.070
my actual usage.

108
00:05:16.070 --> 00:05:20.800
And the usage is made up of a couple of
different pieces in this case, right?

109
00:05:20.800 --> 00:05:25.090
So let me kinda show you the syntax here
of how help documentation is written.

110
00:05:25.090 --> 00:05:28.810
That it starts by giving you the command,
and

111
00:05:28.810 --> 00:05:32.910
then everything else that we need to
provide to make that command work.

112
00:05:32.910 --> 00:05:37.390
If it's in square brackets like this,
then it's an optional thing.

113
00:05:37.390 --> 00:05:39.500
We don't have to have it.

114
00:05:39.500 --> 00:05:43.300
If it's not in square brackets,
then you do have to have it.

115
00:05:43.300 --> 00:05:50.370
So the cp command has to have
a source file and a destination file.

116
00:05:50.370 --> 00:05:55.040
It's got to have those two things,
or it doesn't work, all right?

117
00:05:55.040 --> 00:06:00.430
The options in -t, we can do this if
we want, we don't have to, right?

118
00:06:00.430 --> 00:06:07.600
And then be careful because there's things
like a -T capital and a -t lower case.

119
00:06:07.600 --> 00:06:10.570
And sometimes they do the same thing,
but a lot of times,

120
00:06:10.570 --> 00:06:12.560
they do two different things.

121
00:06:12.560 --> 00:06:15.710
And if I scroll down here and
look at the help,

122
00:06:15.710 --> 00:06:20.600
I can see that -t with a lowercase
is specifying a target directory.

123
00:06:20.600 --> 00:06:24.639
Oops, sorry, and a -t with an upper
case is saying no target directory,

124
00:06:24.639 --> 00:06:27.860
right, just treat it as a file,
not a directory.

125
00:06:27.860 --> 00:06:30.600
Two different things, they're
actually the opposite of each other,

126
00:06:30.600 --> 00:06:32.870
by making one capital and one lower case.

127
00:06:32.870 --> 00:06:35.540
So that's a big difference.

128
00:06:35.540 --> 00:06:39.160
And we find that here in the help, okay?

129
00:06:39.160 --> 00:06:43.850
Now this help is not written
to be read like a book.

130
00:06:43.850 --> 00:06:46.650
I don't say, boy,
I wanna learn about the copy command.

131
00:06:46.650 --> 00:06:52.270
Let me go run cp--help, and I'm just gonna
read this from the beginning to the end.

132
00:06:52.270 --> 00:06:53.810
That's not what this is designed for.

133
00:06:53.810 --> 00:06:56.580
This is designed to be a quick reference,
all right?

134
00:06:56.580 --> 00:07:00.230
I'm trying if it, what was that little
tag I needed to specify a target?

135
00:07:00.230 --> 00:07:02.647
>> Is it capital T or
capital lower case t?

136
00:07:02.647 --> 00:07:06.547
>> Yeah, and you can scan through this
really quick, find what you're looking

137
00:07:06.547 --> 00:07:10.130
for, and there it is,
right there is that information, right?

138
00:07:10.130 --> 00:07:12.680
And that was just by running --help.

139
00:07:12.680 --> 00:07:17.300
On some applications, it's actually not
-- help, it will be -h, the old style.

140
00:07:17.300 --> 00:07:20.240
If I do that here,
that's an invalid option.

141
00:07:20.240 --> 00:07:22.930
Unfortunately, this is not
exactly standardized, so

142
00:07:22.930 --> 00:07:25.560
not every application
follows the same method.

143
00:07:25.560 --> 00:07:32.950
If I take the hostnamectl command and
I run --help, I get the help.

144
00:07:32.950 --> 00:07:36.930
And if I run -h, I get a help, right?

145
00:07:36.930 --> 00:07:38.340
This one supports both.

146
00:07:38.340 --> 00:07:43.941
It supports both modifications of -h,
but cp didn't, right?

147
00:07:43.941 --> 00:07:47.848
So you might have to stumble through this
a few times before you find the right one.

148
00:07:47.848 --> 00:07:52.536
And where it gets a little tricky is
with cp, if I just type cp by itself,

149
00:07:52.536 --> 00:07:55.366
it told me what to type, type cp--help.

150
00:07:55.366 --> 00:07:57.130
hostnamectl, though,

151
00:07:57.130 --> 00:08:02.174
if I just run hostnamectl It doesn't
need any command line arguments.

152
00:08:02.174 --> 00:08:05.040
So if I just run it,
it runs and does it's thing.

153
00:08:05.040 --> 00:08:10.070
So I have to know, in the back of my mind,
that if I wanna figure out how this works,

154
00:08:10.070 --> 00:08:15.260
I can run it, with --help or -h, or
I might have to try them both, right?

155
00:08:15.260 --> 00:08:17.790
And some applications go even crazier.

156
00:08:17.790 --> 00:08:19.472
And they say, you know this is wild
>> [LAUGH]

157
00:08:19.472 --> 00:08:20.382
>> And they say you know what,

158
00:08:20.382 --> 00:08:21.850
you type question mark.

159
00:08:21.850 --> 00:08:26.170
If you do hostnamectl space ?,
it will display the help.

160
00:08:26.170 --> 00:08:27.900
Well, this one doesn't support that,
maybe it's a -?.

161
00:08:27.900 --> 00:08:31.840
You might have to try a few different
things before you hit on the winner, and

162
00:08:31.840 --> 00:08:33.750
it just depends on who
wrote that application.

163
00:08:33.750 --> 00:08:37.090
Which is a frustrating aspect
of using this method for help.

164
00:08:37.090 --> 00:08:40.880
So this is not normally my go to
when I need help, but it is there.

165
00:08:40.880 --> 00:08:44.590
It's built into a lot of commands and I
want you guys to be aware of it because if

166
00:08:44.590 --> 00:08:47.380
you know the command name and you're
just trying to figure out the arguments,

167
00:08:47.380 --> 00:08:49.340
this is going to be a pretty
easy way to do that.

168
00:08:49.340 --> 00:08:53.112
>> And Don, I'm with you on that as far as
this my, I kind of have some familiarity

169
00:08:53.112 --> 00:08:56.010
with the command or
whatever it is I'm working with.

170
00:08:56.010 --> 00:08:57.676
And I just need that quick reference.

171
00:08:57.676 --> 00:08:59.920
Yeah, let me just ask
--help that really quickly.

172
00:08:59.920 --> 00:09:01.230
There, it was capital T.

173
00:09:01.230 --> 00:09:02.590
That's what I need to use.

174
00:09:02.590 --> 00:09:05.360
But what if I want a more exhaustive,
help file,

175
00:09:05.360 --> 00:09:10.300
something that is going to take me from
soup to nuts on how to use this operation?

176
00:09:10.300 --> 00:09:13.230
>> All right, there are a few other
ways to get good documentation on this.

177
00:09:13.230 --> 00:09:18.230
And the most commonly is using
the Unix manual system, okay.

178
00:09:18.230 --> 00:09:23.630
The manual system is basically a part of
the command that's called man, and when we

179
00:09:23.630 --> 00:09:27.930
run that, we can find detailed information
about, just about any command, right?

180
00:09:27.930 --> 00:09:33.200
So if I wanna learn more about cp, or
I wanna learn more about pwd or one of

181
00:09:33.200 --> 00:09:38.650
these other commands, I can just type man,
and then the name of the command, so cp.

182
00:09:38.650 --> 00:09:42.290
I wanna see the manual page for cp.

183
00:09:42.290 --> 00:09:45.000
And when I run that, here we go.

184
00:09:45.000 --> 00:09:46.340
We get output on the screen.

185
00:09:46.340 --> 00:09:48.820
And I can see, here's the cp command.

186
00:09:48.820 --> 00:09:50.450
Here's the options for it.

187
00:09:50.450 --> 00:09:51.640
And, as I start scrolling down,

188
00:09:51.640 --> 00:09:55.910
I can see all the other modifiers and
additional details.

189
00:09:55.910 --> 00:09:59.040
And some of it is really descriptive,
really well documented.

190
00:09:59.040 --> 00:10:02.040
Sometimes they'll have examples
of how you can run the command.

191
00:10:02.040 --> 00:10:02.850
Sometimes they don't.

192
00:10:02.850 --> 00:10:04.470
Sometimes it's much abbreviated.

193
00:10:04.470 --> 00:10:08.170
In fact, this really doesn't look that
much different than the output that I got

194
00:10:08.170 --> 00:10:11.580
when I ran cp--help, right?

195
00:10:11.580 --> 00:10:16.105
So this one, the authors didn't really
go too far into adding more to it.

196
00:10:16.105 --> 00:10:18.965
But you can see recommendations
to other commands and

197
00:10:18.965 --> 00:10:24.635
various other things we can use to find
out information about this utility, right?

198
00:10:24.635 --> 00:10:29.798
Now, when I look at this data, I'm pulling
it up for any number of commands, right?

199
00:10:29.798 --> 00:10:32.975
So I can do manpwd for
present working directory, and

200
00:10:32.975 --> 00:10:34.347
I can look at it's documentation.

201
00:10:34.347 --> 00:10:39.100
Or manpostname CTL, and
now I'm looking at it's documentation.

202
00:10:39.100 --> 00:10:40.460
And we can go through,
and we can find out more.

203
00:10:40.460 --> 00:10:47.550
Now, with hostnamectl, remember when
I ran hostnamectl --help, I got this.

204
00:10:47.550 --> 00:10:49.000
It all fits on one screen.

205
00:10:49.000 --> 00:10:50.610
Just a simple layout.

206
00:10:50.610 --> 00:10:52.980
Here's the arguments we can use.

207
00:10:52.980 --> 00:10:55.070
Here's the commands that are available.

208
00:10:55.070 --> 00:10:56.690
This is it, right?

209
00:10:56.690 --> 00:11:00.780
But when I run man hostnamectl and
I pull up the man page,

210
00:11:00.780 --> 00:11:05.730
the manual,
now I get screens of data, all right?

211
00:11:05.730 --> 00:11:07.690
Where they really go through and

212
00:11:07.690 --> 00:11:11.970
explain exactly how each
of these tags work, right?

00:17:32.020 --> 00:17:34.880
the way back to where this thing started,
right.

363
00:17:34.880 --> 00:17:36.250
So I might have a problem there.

364
00:17:36.250 --> 00:17:39.180
In fact, I could use the up
time command to find out.

365
00:17:39.180 --> 00:17:41.850
It's been two days, yeah, two days and
an hour since I've rebooted.

366
00:17:41.850 --> 00:17:45.540
So I'd have to go back quite a ways
to actually find the boot log, right.

367
00:17:45.540 --> 00:17:50.260
But what I could do is I could
take that dmesg output and

368
00:17:50.260 --> 00:17:55.090
I could put it into a file and I could
then use less and search through it, or

369
00:17:55.090 --> 00:17:59.100
more or head, tail, I could use
all that other stuff on the data.

370
00:17:59.100 --> 00:18:04.830
So I wanna take the output of this
command and I wanna send it into a file,

371
00:18:04.830 --> 00:18:08.300
and we can do that through
a few different means, right.

372
00:18:08.300 --> 00:18:11.820
We could either do it live where
the file already exists or

373
00:18:11.820 --> 00:18:16.530
we can create files ahead of time and
then add the data into them.

374
00:18:16.530 --> 00:18:19.160
And it's kind of up to us how
we want to go about that.

375
00:18:19.160 --> 00:18:21.600
But just to show you a quick example here.

376
00:18:21.600 --> 00:18:26.230
I'm gonna do a dmesg, and
I'm gonna use a greater than symbol.

377
00:18:26.230 --> 00:18:32.430
And a greater than symbol says take the
output of whatever the first command is,

378
00:18:32.430 --> 00:18:37.030
and then stick it somewhere else,
right, into a file somewhere else.

379
00:18:37.030 --> 00:18:39.982
And so
I'm gonna take this dmesg output and

380
00:18:39.982 --> 00:18:43.510
I'm gonna put it into bootlog.txt, okay.

381
00:18:43.510 --> 00:18:46.431
So it's gonna run, and
what do I see on the screen?

382
00:18:46.431 --> 00:18:47.660
Nothing, right.

383
00:18:47.660 --> 00:18:52.550
Instead of putting this data on my screen,
it redirected it.

384
00:18:52.550 --> 00:18:57.630
It redirected that outlet from standard
out to this file, bootlog.txt.

385
00:18:57.630 --> 00:19:00.661
And if I take a look at my directory
I've now got a bootlog.txt.

386
00:19:00.661 --> 00:19:06.508
And if I pull the long output for
that, let me make that human readable,

387
00:19:06.508 --> 00:19:11.025
it is 336K, not as long as Moby Dick for
the record.

388
00:19:11.025 --> 00:19:13.120
>> [LAUGH] Still substantial.

389
00:19:13.120 --> 00:19:17.920
>> Yeah, and now I can come in and
I can take the command like less and

390
00:19:17.920 --> 00:19:23.570
I could feed into it that bootlog.txt, and
now it starts from the very beginning.

391
00:19:23.570 --> 00:19:25.860
And here is where my computer booted up.

392
00:19:25.860 --> 00:19:29.680
I see the Linux kernel
initializing right there, and

393
00:19:29.680 --> 00:19:34.390
it initialized my c groups, the processor
groups, and then memory is initializing.

394
00:19:34.390 --> 00:19:37.220
This is when my computer booted up,
I'm right here at the beginning.

395
00:19:37.220 --> 00:19:39.200
And I can search through and
I can look for things.

396
00:19:39.200 --> 00:19:43.140
Maybe I wanna find if there
were any errors that occurred.

397
00:19:43.140 --> 00:19:45.700
I might be error free, apparently I am.

398
00:19:45.700 --> 00:19:46.250
>> Good for you.

399
00:19:46.250 --> 00:19:47.320
[LAUGH]
>> Look I'm error free.

400
00:19:47.320 --> 00:19:49.250
But I can search through and
look for various things.

401
00:19:49.250 --> 00:19:52.700
Maybe I wanna find where it mounted
a hard drive or something like that.

402
00:19:52.700 --> 00:19:55.270
And so I can search and
I can find that, and here it is.

403
00:19:55.270 --> 00:19:59.970
And I might be thousands of lines in but
I just jumped to it and got there.

404
00:19:59.970 --> 00:20:01.971
So we can pull that
information really easily.

405
00:20:01.971 --> 00:20:06.130
And I got the data into this
file by just doing a redirect.

406
00:20:06.130 --> 00:20:09.230
I took the output of one command,
dmesg, and

407
00:20:09.230 --> 00:20:12.670
I used the greater than symbol to
then dump it right into a text file.

408
00:20:12.670 --> 00:20:16.730
>> And this text file,
this bootlog.txt, did not exist.

409
00:20:16.730 --> 00:20:20.100
So Linux created and said,
you want this, it's not there.

410
00:20:20.100 --> 00:20:22.042
I'll just make that file and
put this content inside it.

411
00:20:22.042 --> 00:20:24.220
>> Yeah, yep,
that's basically how it works.

412
00:20:24.220 --> 00:20:27.500
And so now I've got that file and
it's there.

413
00:20:27.500 --> 00:20:31.310
There are a few other ways that we could
have done this to get the data in there.

414
00:20:31.310 --> 00:20:35.690
And there's other things that
I could have output into it.

415
00:20:35.690 --> 00:20:40.770
If I run this command again,
it's gonna overwrite that bootlog.txt,

416
00:20:40.770 --> 00:20:41.550
so what was that?

417
00:20:41.550 --> 00:20:45.565
Whatever was in bootlog is gonna get
overwritten with whatever is in the new

418
00:20:45.565 --> 00:20:46.610
dmesg command.

419
00:20:46.610 --> 00:20:51.463
Or if I ran something else,
maybe I ran uname-a like that,

420
00:20:51.463 --> 00:20:54.385
and the uname-a command if you're
not familiar with that one,

421
00:20:54.385 --> 00:20:56.505
it just shows what kernel you're running,
right.

422
00:20:56.505 --> 00:20:59.115
So if that's all I wanted to know,
I didn't have to go to my dmesg for that,

423
00:20:59.115 --> 00:21:00.645
I could have pulled it right from uname.

424
00:21:00.645 --> 00:21:01.995
Or you can run uname by itself, and

425
00:21:01.995 --> 00:21:04.760
it just says you're running Linux,
which is pretty pointless.

426
00:21:04.760 --> 00:21:06.305
>> [LAUGH]
>> But if I want uname-a and

427
00:21:06.305 --> 00:21:11.750
I send that into bootlog.txt,
the file already exists.

428
00:21:11.750 --> 00:21:13.080
So what does it do?

429
00:21:13.080 --> 00:21:14.701
It overwrites the file.

430
00:21:14.701 --> 00:21:17.766
And so
now when I take a look at bootlog.txt,

431
00:21:17.766 --> 00:21:22.285
that's all it's got is that one line,
that little one entry, and

432
00:21:22.285 --> 00:21:26.340
I just lost all the d message
stuff that was in there, okay.

433
00:21:26.340 --> 00:21:30.282
So when you do a redirect like this,
if the file already exists,

434
00:21:30.282 --> 00:21:32.039
you need to make a decision.

435
00:21:32.039 --> 00:21:36.070
You might want to overwrite it, in which
case you just redirect like I did.

436
00:21:36.070 --> 00:21:38.372
But you might want to append and

437
00:21:38.372 --> 00:21:42.000
say, I wanna add on to the end
of that file instead, okay.

438
00:21:42.000 --> 00:21:46.318
And you can do that by doing two,
whoops, by screwing up the prompt,

439
00:21:46.318 --> 00:21:48.940
by doing two greater than signs, right.

440
00:21:48.940 --> 00:21:52.060
By doing this, by saying, and
I'll change this so it's dmesg this time.

441
00:21:52.060 --> 00:21:58.560
I'm gonna do a dmesg and
two greater than symbols, bootlog.txt.

442
00:21:58.560 --> 00:22:01.430
That's gonna take the dmesg output and
stick it on the end of that file.

443
00:22:01.430 --> 00:22:03.590
So don't override it, add to it.

444
00:22:03.590 --> 00:22:05.600
And this is often times what we want.

445
00:22:05.600 --> 00:22:08.830
And when I run that, again I don't
get any output on my screen, but

446
00:22:08.830 --> 00:22:16.280
when I take a look at bootlog.txt, there's
the output for uname-a right at the top.

447
00:22:16.280 --> 00:22:20.570
And then after that it starts the output
for d message, all right after it.

448
00:22:20.570 --> 00:22:22.560
I just appended and added on to it.

449
00:22:22.560 --> 00:22:25.640
So a single greater than sign
versus a double greater than sign,

450
00:22:25.640 --> 00:22:27.610
that's gonna move that data and
get it in there.

451
00:22:27.610 --> 00:22:29.275
>> Well Don,
these redirectors seem pretty handy.

452
00:22:29.275 --> 00:22:31.915
Are there any others that we need to be
aware of when it comes to redirection?

453
00:22:31.915 --> 00:22:36.005
>> There's a few other where a little more
useful, like in our scripting series.

454
00:22:36.005 --> 00:22:38.325
I know we'll redirect errors.

455
00:22:38.325 --> 00:22:41.085
When you run a program, there's two
different outputs that you get.

456
00:22:41.085 --> 00:22:43.065
There's the successful output with data,
and

457
00:22:43.065 --> 00:22:47.040
then there's the error output if there's
a problem, if something goes wrong.

458
00:22:47.040 --> 00:22:51.920
And so you might wanna redirect just
the good stuff, or just the error.

459
00:22:51.920 --> 00:22:54.330
Well by default it is just
outputting the good stuff.

460
00:22:54.330 --> 00:22:57.330
So when the command runs, the greater than
symbol is grabbing the good stuff and

461
00:22:57.330 --> 00:22:58.770
putting it where you want it to go, right.

462
00:22:58.770 --> 00:23:00.100
That's standard out.

463
00:23:00.100 --> 00:23:03.970
But there's standard error,
also STDERR, and

464
00:23:03.970 --> 00:23:06.410
standard error is just
the errors if you have them.

465
00:23:06.410 --> 00:23:09.010
Now I didn't have any errors,
there is nothing to output, right.

466
00:23:09.010 --> 00:23:14.970
If I run dmesg and I just do the normal
thing that I've been doing here so

467
00:23:14.970 --> 00:23:19.080
far, that's redirecting the standard out,
the good stuff.

468
00:23:19.080 --> 00:23:23.368
And if I want the errors, what I need
to do is stick a two before it, okay.

469
00:23:23.368 --> 00:23:28.824
The first output is the good stuff,
the second output are the errors.

470
00:23:28.824 --> 00:23:33.950
And if there are any errors it will take
them and dump them into bootlog.txt.

471
00:23:33.950 --> 00:23:37.250
Now when I run that,
see how I got stuff on the screen?

472
00:23:37.250 --> 00:23:39.350
That's because I didn't
redirect the standard out.

473
00:23:39.350 --> 00:23:41.720
The standard out still goes to
where ever it's supposed to go,

474
00:23:41.720 --> 00:23:46.060
which is my screen,
just the errors get redirected.

475
00:23:46.060 --> 00:23:50.340
And if I take a look at bootlog.txt,

476
00:23:50.340 --> 00:23:54.020
it's now empty because there were no
errors, there were no errors to output.

477
00:23:54.020 --> 00:23:55.169
But if there were errors,
they would get saved there.

478
00:23:55.169 --> 00:23:57.669
And that's a great way when
you're running a script,

479
00:23:57.669 --> 00:23:59.949
to say I need to log
the errors somewhere else, and

480
00:23:59.949 --> 00:24:03.615
you could do that by redirecting it this
way and dumping it that way, all right.

481
00:24:03.615 --> 00:24:08.368
Another thing is that the redirectors,
you can flip it around.

482
00:24:08.368 --> 00:24:13.063
And instead of taking the output of
a command and sending it into a file,

483
00:24:13.063 --> 00:24:16.821
I can do the opposite where I
take the contents of a file and

484
00:24:16.821 --> 00:24:19.424
I send them into a command, all right?

485
00:24:19.424 --> 00:24:23.885
So, for example, the, let's say I do,

486
00:24:23.885 --> 00:24:27.465
I don't know, LS-LH, right?

487
00:24:27.465 --> 00:24:31.300
That shows me all the files that
are in my directory, all right?

488
00:24:31.300 --> 00:24:34.530
Or just ls, for that matter, and
I see the files that are in my directory.

489
00:24:34.530 --> 00:24:39.210
Well, I might want to take those and
alphabetize them.

490
00:24:39.210 --> 00:24:41.198
And, or actually it wont work
here cuz it's all on one line.

491
00:24:41.198 --> 00:24:42.540
>> It's already alphabetized.

492
00:24:42.540 --> 00:24:43.040
Is it?

493
00:24:43.040 --> 00:24:44.900
>> Yeah.
>> It does alphabetize, doesn't it?

494
00:24:44.900 --> 00:24:49.520
So if I wanted to take this, though,
and feed it into some other command,

495
00:24:49.520 --> 00:24:52.330
I could take a document, I could take
MobyDick for that matter, right?

496
00:24:52.330 --> 00:24:56.941
And let's say that I wanted to take the
contents of Moby Dick and alphabetize it.

497
00:24:56.941 --> 00:24:59.010
I don't know why you'd wanna do this.

498
00:24:59.010 --> 00:25:02.480
But you can use the sort command
to alphabetize anything, right?

499
00:25:02.480 --> 00:25:07.246
So if you look at the syntax or the sort
command, it tells you to provide it

500
00:25:07.246 --> 00:25:12.460
a file, and it'll take that file and
it will sort it to match what you need.

501
00:25:12.460 --> 00:25:17.232
So, for example, if I take, here,
let's just do /user/bin all right?

502
00:25:17.232 --> 00:25:19.270
So here's a bunch of binaries.

503
00:25:19.270 --> 00:25:22.240
And they're already alphabetized for
me in here, right?

504
00:25:22.240 --> 00:25:26.160
But if I take that directory listing, and

505
00:25:26.160 --> 00:25:30.340
I'm gonna drop that into a file
called binaries.txt, okay?

506
00:25:30.340 --> 00:25:35.280
Well, maybe I want that, I wanna be able
to see the files that are in there, right?

507
00:25:35.280 --> 00:25:38.470
So if I take a look at my
new binaries.txt files here,

508
00:25:38.470 --> 00:25:43.130
here's all of the binaries, and
they're alphabetized from A to Z, okay?

509
00:25:43.130 --> 00:25:45.000
Well, maybe that's not what I want.

510
00:25:45.000 --> 00:25:47.905
Maybe I want it to be from Z to A, right?

511
00:25:47.905 --> 00:25:55.216
Well, if I do it from a command,
I could say ls /user/bin,

512
00:25:55.216 --> 00:25:59.490
and I could pipe the output
into the sort command,

513
00:25:59.490 --> 00:26:01.450
which by default would
sort alphabetically.

514
00:26:01.450 --> 00:26:07.596
And I could sort it with a -r to reverse
the sort order, and there it goes, right?

515
00:26:07.596 --> 00:26:12.540
And I'd have to scroll back to see it all,
but now it was from Z and A, the A was at

516
00:26:12.540 --> 00:26:18.390
the end versus of I did sort without the
dash r, the Zs would it be the end, okay?

517
00:26:18.390 --> 00:26:20.290
That's good if you can
run the command now.

518
00:26:20.290 --> 00:26:23.826
But if somebody gives you a file,
the command's already been run, and so

519
00:26:23.826 --> 00:26:27.874
you've got this data, this output from the
database, and I might want to sort it and

520
00:26:27.874 --> 00:26:28.860
change that order.

521
00:26:28.860 --> 00:26:33.065
What I could do is I could
use the sort command and

522
00:26:33.065 --> 00:26:38.660
I could do a less than symbol,
and feed in a file like that.

523
00:26:38.660 --> 00:26:42.930
I'm gonna take that text file and
make it input instead of output.

524
00:26:42.930 --> 00:26:45.940
Instead of taking the output of a command
and saving it, I'm taking the file's

525
00:26:45.940 --> 00:26:49.350
input and feeding it into the command,
doing it the other way around.

526
00:26:49.350 --> 00:26:52.600
And now I can do that, and
it sorts it from A to Z.

527
00:26:52.600 --> 00:26:54.980
And I can even go further,
we can get really crazy with this.

528
00:26:54.980 --> 00:26:58.300
And then I could pipe that
into the less command.

529
00:26:58.300 --> 00:27:00.680
And now we really get some fun, right?

530
00:27:00.680 --> 00:27:03.860
And here's the Zs first
going all the way down to A.

531
00:27:03.860 --> 00:27:06.260
And we're kinda three levels deep, right?

532
00:27:06.260 --> 00:27:08.870
I redirected the file's input and

533
00:27:08.870 --> 00:27:11.590
then I redirected all of
that into the less command.

534
00:27:11.590 --> 00:27:12.580
Now you can keep going on.

535
00:27:12.580 --> 00:27:13.430
This is called pipelining.

536
00:27:13.430 --> 00:27:16.330
You can keep going adding command after
command after command to really create

537
00:27:16.330 --> 00:27:17.660
some powerful scenarios.

538
00:27:17.660 --> 00:27:21.810
So if you mix all these together you
can really get some great information.

539
00:27:21.810 --> 00:27:23.305
Information put the way that you want it.

00:27:23.305 --> 00:27:26.860
>> Yeah, there's a fun thing,

00:27:33.350 --> 00:27:35.570
It does a lot of amazing powerful stuff.

00:27:35.570 --> 00:27:36.420
Very cool.

00:27:36.420 --> 00:27:39.100
Don, I know we got
a little bit of time left.

I don't know if you want to
try to finish this up or-

00:27:41.345 --> 00:27:41.970
>> Well, I've

moving files, deleting files,

I also want to talk

00:24:11.080 --> 00:24:13.550
you're the owner of, but the permissions
have been changed to read only or

460
00:24:13.550 --> 00:24:15.340
something like that, it might stop you.

461
00:24:15.340 --> 00:24:18.796
And if you ever encounter that, you can
change the command just a little bit.

462
00:24:18.796 --> 00:24:22.684
Maybe I wanna get rid of test 1 and
2, so I'm using expansion so

463
00:24:22.684 --> 00:24:26.080
that I can delete test1 and
test2 at the same time.

464
00:24:26.080 --> 00:24:27.320
Or you could actually write them out.

465
00:24:27.320 --> 00:24:29.723
I could say test1, test2 like that.

466
00:24:29.723 --> 00:24:33.680
It works either way, but
the expansion is just a little bit short.

467
00:24:33.680 --> 00:24:34.810
I think it's one keystroke short.

468
00:24:36.250 --> 00:24:42.930
So if I wanna remove those, you can do
an rm-rf, and that f says to force it.

469
00:24:42.930 --> 00:24:45.871
Now this is what we have to be
careful with because basically we're

470
00:24:45.871 --> 00:24:47.457
taking off the safety gloves here.

471
00:24:47.457 --> 00:24:50.315
And it's saying I don't care what I
encounter underneath as long as you're

472
00:24:50.315 --> 00:24:53.306
the owner or you have the permission to
mess with it, we're going to toast it and

473
00:24:53.306 --> 00:24:54.081
get it out of there.

474
00:24:54.081 --> 00:24:55.553
So that's what rm-rf does.

475
00:24:55.553 --> 00:24:59.220
This is the command I run when I
wanna just get something going on and

476
00:24:59.220 --> 00:25:01.985
I don't want to be bothered
with error messages.

477
00:25:01.985 --> 00:25:03.740
Just do it, get rid of it.

478
00:25:03.740 --> 00:25:06.710
And when I run that,
it's gonna go through and purge it.

479
00:25:06.710 --> 00:25:09.500
And now all of those folders are gone,
okay.

480
00:25:09.500 --> 00:25:11.011
So -r made it recursive.

481
00:25:11.011 --> 00:25:13.987
That's what got me around
the directory problem.

482
00:25:13.987 --> 00:25:18.566
-rf made it force and just get
past any kind of blocks, just say,

483
00:25:18.566 --> 00:25:20.330
we're gonna remove it.

484
00:25:20.330 --> 00:25:22.480
You can't delete something
you don't have permission to.

485
00:25:22.480 --> 00:25:24.210
So force isn't magic.

486
00:25:24.210 --> 00:25:27.150
It's just, there's some things that
you may have set yourself to have

487
00:25:27.150 --> 00:25:29.658
read only permission, and
that's what it will [INAUDIBLE].

488
00:25:29.658 --> 00:25:32.910
A couple of different manipulations there
on that rm command to remove the data and

489
00:25:32.910 --> 00:25:33.745
get it out of there.

490
00:25:33.745 --> 00:25:37.305
>> All right, Don, well, we've gone
through a litany of very basic, but

491
00:25:37.305 --> 00:25:41.315
very crucial items of manipulating files,
working with files.

492
00:25:41.315 --> 00:25:45.675
We've copied, we've moved them, we've
deleted them, we've done a lot of stuff.

493
00:25:45.675 --> 00:25:49.566
You've shown us expansion, which was a
great thing, because it helps us minimize

494
00:25:49.566 --> 00:25:53.620
the amount of typing and time that it's
gonna take to make a lot of stuff.

495
00:25:53.620 --> 00:25:56.010
Or just move stuff or
whatever it is we're doing.

496
00:25:56.010 --> 00:25:59.380
As you say, it works so
ubiquitously through our batch system,

497
00:25:59.380 --> 00:26:01.775
it can be very helpful in
a lot of great places.

498
00:26:01.775 --> 00:26:05.617
Is there anything else you want to
enlighten our audience with before we go?

499
00:26:05.617 --> 00:26:06.805
We're running short on time.

500
00:26:06.805 --> 00:26:09.598
>> Well, I know I've made this comment
in some of the other episodes, but

501
00:26:09.598 --> 00:26:12.035
we've really just scratched
the tip of the iceberg, right?

502
00:26:12.035 --> 00:26:14.035
It's kind of an introductory,
getting used to it.

503
00:26:14.035 --> 00:26:18.398
So there are a ton of other commands that
are out there that are incredibly useful

504
00:26:18.398 --> 00:26:22.465
that you'll use all the time, but these
are kinda the core ones, the base ones,

505
00:26:22.465 --> 00:26:23.735
the ones you're expected to know.

506
00:26:23.735 --> 00:26:27.750
And more importantly, because they're core
utilities, these are present everywhere.

507
00:26:27.750 --> 00:26:32.800
So if you go to a BSD machine, or a Linux
Machine, if it's Ubuntu or Fedora or

508
00:26:32.800 --> 00:26:37.345
Red Hat, if you go to a Solaris machine,
Oracle Linux, whatever, these

509
00:26:37.345 --> 00:26:41.190
commands are there, these same commands,
the same way we manipulate things.

510
00:26:41.190 --> 00:26:45.600
So this is a consistent set of
core utilities they always have.

511
00:26:45.600 --> 00:26:46.320
The fancier bills and

512
00:26:46.320 --> 00:26:49.040
whistles are great, but
you don't necessarily always have those.

513
00:26:49.040 --> 00:26:52.140
So this is kind of that starting point for
manipulating files.

514
00:26:52.140 --> 00:26:53.200
>> All right, great stuff, Don.

515
00:26:53.200 --> 00:26:55.421
We do appreciate your time and
effort into this show and

516
00:26:55.421 --> 00:26:57.320
all the great examples
that you've shown us.

517
00:26:57.320 --> 00:27:01.200
The demonstrations, they were
really well-executed and explained.

518
00:27:01.200 --> 00:27:02.090
And that's the important part.

519
00:27:02.090 --> 00:27:04.510
Hopefully you guys out there that
are watching this are like, man,

520
00:27:04.510 --> 00:27:05.470
I'm eating this up.

521
00:27:05.470 --> 00:27:07.315
I can run me some Linux now.

522
00:27:07.315 --> 00:27:10.580
That's kind of the purpose of why we're
doing this for you folks out there.

523
00:27:10.580 --> 00:27:13.360
Don, thanks again for joining us,
and we do thank you for watching.

524
00:27:13.360 --> 00:27:15.990
Well, looking at the clock, we have

00:27:15.990 --> 00:27:16.780
another show.

00:27:16.780 --> 00:27:19.460
Signing off for ITProTV,
