episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how applications execute in Linux and demonstrates how to view what processes are currently running. He then demonstrates how to pull additional detailed information on each process running and how to terminate a malfunctioning process if required.
episodes.title: Managing Processes
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:00.957
Welcome to IT Pro TV, I'm your host
Don Pezet coming at you live from

2
00:00:00.957 --> 00:00:06.535
San Francisco's
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.535 --> 00:00:08.291
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.291 --> 00:00:12.035
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.035 --> 00:00:13.949
>> All right, greetings everyone and

6
00:00:13.949 --> 00:00:16.705
welcome back to another
great episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:16.705 --> 00:00:18.337
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie and

8
00:00:18.337 --> 00:00:21.899
in today's episode we are back with
more in our Linux Command line series.

9
00:00:21.899 --> 00:00:25.340
And it's definitely been
an interesting conversation so far.

10
00:00:25.340 --> 00:00:29.500
Joining us back to continue that talk,
our good friend, Mr. Don Pezet.

11
00:00:29.500 --> 00:00:31.120
Don, welcome back sir,
how's it going today?

12
00:00:31.120 --> 00:00:34.704
>> It is going great, ready to dive back
into the world of the Linux Command line.

13
00:00:34.704 --> 00:00:38.400
And in this episode we're gonna be taking
a look at how to manage processes, right?

14
00:00:38.400 --> 00:00:40.720
And processes are all those
programs that we run.

15
00:00:40.720 --> 00:00:44.060
Linux is a true multi-tasking
operating system which,

16
00:00:44.060 --> 00:00:46.200
it used to be a really
big deal in the Eighties.

17
00:00:46.200 --> 00:00:49.600
But in today's age we just
expect it to have it,

18
00:00:49.600 --> 00:00:52.270
that our system can run more
than one program at once.

19
00:00:52.270 --> 00:00:57.013
But the power that we get from that
brings a little bit of a flip side.

20
00:00:57.013 --> 00:00:58.752
Which is that if you get too much running,

21
00:00:58.752 --> 00:01:01.250
your system performance
can start to be affected.

22
00:01:01.250 --> 00:01:04.060
So in this episode we're gonna get
a chance to see how to determine

23
00:01:04.060 --> 00:01:05.330
what all is running on our system.

24
00:01:05.330 --> 00:01:07.000
Be able to see if it is impacting us or

25
00:01:07.000 --> 00:01:09.060
if we're perfectly in
the bounds of our hardware.

26
00:01:09.060 --> 00:01:12.465
And then see how we can kind of recover
from it in the event that we are consuming

27
00:01:12.465 --> 00:01:13.085
too many resources.

28
00:01:13.085 --> 00:01:15.427
So all that laid out right
here in this episode.

29
00:01:15.427 --> 00:01:18.195
>> All right Don, well let's do that and
let's start at the very beginning.

30
00:01:18.195 --> 00:01:21.055
I've got processes running
in my Linux system,

31
00:01:21.055 --> 00:01:24.705
I wanna see what they are and
what the heck is going on with them.

32
00:01:24.705 --> 00:01:25.813
Where do I begin there?

33
00:01:25.813 --> 00:01:30.945
>> All right so in the Unix world, there
was a command that was introduced a long,

34
00:01:30.945 --> 00:01:32.550
long time ago called ps.

35
00:01:32.550 --> 00:01:35.950
And the ps command would just
show you all of your processes.

36
00:01:35.950 --> 00:01:39.320
Unfortunately, the ps command,
it's critical, it's a core utility,

37
00:01:39.320 --> 00:01:40.760
it's part of every distro.

38
00:01:40.760 --> 00:01:43.110
But it's evolved a lot over the years.

39
00:01:43.110 --> 00:01:46.540
And so the way it gets used is
kind of strange because there's

40
00:01:46.540 --> 00:01:48.150
the original Unix way.

41
00:01:48.150 --> 00:01:51.300
There's the BSD way,
there's the newer GNU version.

42
00:01:51.300 --> 00:01:53.700
And so there's all sorts of changes and
manipulations.

43
00:01:53.700 --> 00:01:58.070
So what I'm gonna show you here in this
show is one way of using the ps utility,

44
00:01:58.070 --> 00:01:59.490
but know there's more than one way.

45
00:01:59.490 --> 00:02:02.576
And if you read the man file for
it it's almost like a history documentary,

46
00:02:02.576 --> 00:02:03.160
>> [LAUGH]

47
00:02:03.160 --> 00:02:04.535
>> On this command's mutations

48
00:02:04.535 --> 00:02:05.760
through the years.

49
00:02:05.760 --> 00:02:09.103
But I'll just use the standard Linux way
of kind of manipulating with it to look at

50
00:02:09.103 --> 00:02:10.120
our processes.

51
00:02:10.120 --> 00:02:13.323
But if I'm in a command prompt
like this and I run ps,

52
00:02:13.323 --> 00:02:18.140
that's gonna show me the processes for
my session.

53
00:02:18.140 --> 00:02:20.630
And so
my session currently has two processes.

54
00:02:20.630 --> 00:02:23.240
One is the ps command,
which I was just running.

55
00:02:23.240 --> 00:02:27.360
And the other one is the bash command,
which I'm in right now.

56
00:02:27.360 --> 00:02:29.430
That's my shell, right so
that's what I'm seeing.

57
00:02:29.430 --> 00:02:31.780
That's my session all right?

58
00:02:31.780 --> 00:02:36.320
But the key thing to remember here is that
the ps command by default is just showing

59
00:02:36.320 --> 00:02:39.360
you the processes for your session.

60
00:02:39.360 --> 00:02:41.440
What if we have more than one session,
right?

61
00:02:41.440 --> 00:02:43.290
What if I whip open another tab, and

62
00:02:43.290 --> 00:02:45.980
I'm gonna fire up the Midnight Commander,
right?

63
00:02:45.980 --> 00:02:48.040
So I'm running the Midnight Commander
in this other tab, and

64
00:02:48.040 --> 00:02:50.580
I come back to my first tab, and I run ps.

65
00:02:51.900 --> 00:02:53.980
No Midnight Commander right and

66
00:02:53.980 --> 00:02:58.550
that's because it's in a different
session, running somewhere else, right?

67
00:02:58.550 --> 00:03:02.200
If I had run it here in this shell and
then hidden it,

68
00:03:02.200 --> 00:03:05.300
thrown it in the background or
something of that nature, right?

69
00:03:05.300 --> 00:03:09.430
If I had run it that way,
then it would show here in this list.

70
00:03:09.430 --> 00:03:13.340
So ps by itself is not
that incredibly useful.

71
00:03:13.340 --> 00:03:16.772
Instead, we're normally gonna add some
command line arguments to expand that out

72
00:03:16.772 --> 00:03:17.730
all right?

73
00:03:17.730 --> 00:03:21.552
And probably one of the most
important ones is -a.

74
00:03:21.552 --> 00:03:28.190
ps -a says show me all processes,
not just the ones tied to this session.

75
00:03:28.190 --> 00:03:34.560
And when I run ps -a I can see
Midnight Commander right there, MC.

76
00:03:34.560 --> 00:03:38.870
And I can see ps right,
the process command that I ran.

77
00:03:38.870 --> 00:03:42.577
So I can see those,
now notice how bash disappears right.

78
00:03:42.577 --> 00:03:46.537
And that's because when I start
modifying the way that ps behaves.

79
00:03:46.537 --> 00:03:51.089
Now I'm getting into that area of, are you
running at the BSD way or the Unix way or

80
00:03:51.089 --> 00:03:51.950
the Linux way.

81
00:03:51.950 --> 00:03:57.100
I'm running at the Linux way now and
in the Linux way they don't show processes

82
00:03:57.100 --> 00:04:01.710
that are basically like a startup or
init processes.

83
00:04:01.710 --> 00:04:04.310
And then your bash shell in this case,
would be one of those, so

84
00:04:04.310 --> 00:04:05.700
it's getting left off.

85
00:04:05.700 --> 00:04:09.576
So I actually need to modify this just
a little bit more to make it show

86
00:04:09.576 --> 00:04:11.010
other things like that.

87
00:04:11.010 --> 00:04:14.966
By adding in for
example an x to show a little bit more and

88
00:04:14.966 --> 00:04:19.530
we'll start to see processes
that are tied to the system.

89
00:04:19.530 --> 00:04:23.910
And somewhere in all of this my bash
instance will show up in here too,

90
00:04:23.910 --> 00:04:26.430
it's a lot, right?

91
00:04:26.430 --> 00:04:29.650
The other problem here is,
I'm now seeing that x technically says

92
00:04:29.650 --> 00:04:34.620
show me everything that's not bound to
a TTY, which would be a shell session.

93
00:04:34.620 --> 00:04:37.360
So I'm seeing a ton of system processes,

94
00:04:37.360 --> 00:04:39.370
which are not necessarily
things that I'm running.

95
00:04:39.370 --> 00:04:41.680
There's things in here that
are being run by the root user, or

96
00:04:41.680 --> 00:04:44.025
maybe other users on my system,
which hopefully there aren't any.

97
00:04:44.025 --> 00:04:46.880
[LAUGH] But
things are being run by other people.

98
00:04:46.880 --> 00:04:51.749
So I normally add one more thing to this,
I typically run ps -aux, like this.

99
00:04:51.749 --> 00:04:55.820
And that u says tell me
the username as well all right?

100
00:04:55.820 --> 00:04:57.900
It actually does a little more,
in addition to the user name,

101
00:04:57.900 --> 00:05:02.470
it'll show things like the processor
utilization and stuff.

102
00:05:02.470 --> 00:05:06.450
So you get an idea of who's really
consuming resources on your system.

103
00:05:06.450 --> 00:05:11.320
And when I run that, now I get a nice
big layout here and right here,

104
00:05:11.320 --> 00:05:15.355
I just lucked out and
saw it I can find dpozet bash, right?

105
00:05:15.355 --> 00:05:17.390
There's my bash process running.

106
00:05:17.390 --> 00:05:20.800
And I can start to see all these other
things that I happen to be running that

107
00:05:20.800 --> 00:05:23.680
aren't necessarily a part of my shell.

108
00:05:23.680 --> 00:05:27.720
Now, the ps output, it can be really big,
it can be hard to find,

109
00:05:27.720 --> 00:05:30.250
I got lucky here and
found that bash instance.

110
00:05:30.250 --> 00:05:34.622
But I could have come in and
piped the output of that

111
00:05:34.622 --> 00:05:39.010
into grep, grep lets you search for
a string and find it.

112
00:05:39.010 --> 00:05:41.230
I could have searched for the word bash.

113
00:05:41.230 --> 00:05:44.450
Instead, you'll find this
particular process, and

114
00:05:44.450 --> 00:05:46.360
when I run that, there's more than one.

115
00:05:46.360 --> 00:05:49.940
And there's more than one because
well one's gonna be my search,

116
00:05:49.940 --> 00:05:52.130
the actual grep command right there.

117
00:05:52.130 --> 00:05:55.595
But the other ones, I've got more than one
terminal open in different places, and

118
00:05:55.595 --> 00:05:57.293
so they're each kinda showing up here.

119
00:05:57.293 --> 00:06:00.160
And I can see them and
kind of find where they are.

120
00:06:00.160 --> 00:06:02.370
Now I've located them a lot more easily.

121
00:06:02.370 --> 00:06:05.404
I could have done the same thing
searching by username and said,

122
00:06:05.404 --> 00:06:07.492
show me everything that dpozet is running.

123
00:06:07.492 --> 00:06:12.510
And now it's all the processes that are
tied to me so I get much better output.

124
00:06:12.510 --> 00:06:18.420
The ps command went from being this
to being all of that above it, right?

125
00:06:18.420 --> 00:06:22.180
It all comes down to those command line
arguments and having the right extensions

126
00:06:22.180 --> 00:06:26.820
to use to get the output that you want to
be able to see what's running in the back.

127
00:06:26.820 --> 00:06:31.230
>> Now Don, ps also allows us to kind of,
sometimes processes

128
00:06:31.230 --> 00:06:33.880
are a bundle of processes or-
>> Yeah.

129
00:06:33.880 --> 00:06:37.400
>> There's things like that, we can
even flesh that out as well, can't we?

130
00:06:37.400 --> 00:06:40.440
>> Sure so a lot of these
processes are interrelated, right?

131
00:06:40.440 --> 00:06:46.660
And we kind of saw that when,
well like here, where I've got ps running.

132
00:06:46.660 --> 00:06:49.990
And ps is technically
running in the bash shell.

133
00:06:49.990 --> 00:06:51.290
If I were to kill the bash shell,

134
00:06:51.290 --> 00:06:53.350
what do you think's gonna
happen to the ps command?

135
00:06:53.350 --> 00:06:53.930
>> Bye bye.

136
00:06:53.930 --> 00:06:55.670
>> It's gonna go away,
they're related, right?

137
00:06:55.670 --> 00:06:59.140
It's like a parent child, bash is
the parent, ps is the child underneath it.

138
00:06:59.140 --> 00:07:03.760
We don't see that normally,
when I run ps -aux, I just see a list,

139
00:07:03.760 --> 00:07:06.560
here's all the processes,
good luck, right?

140
00:07:06.560 --> 00:07:12.440
But if we add a little bit to that,
I'm gonna add --Forest.

141
00:07:12.440 --> 00:07:16.990
That says,
arrange things in a tree format, right?

142
00:07:16.990 --> 00:07:19.590
There's actually a command called tree,
it's useful in the file system.

143
00:07:19.590 --> 00:07:22.070
You can see the tree
that builds up a folder.

144
00:07:22.070 --> 00:07:24.540
But here, it can take the processes and
arrange them as trees.

145
00:07:24.540 --> 00:07:27.080
And then when it puts them all together,
you've got forest,

146
00:07:27.080 --> 00:07:28.520
that's where the term comes from.

147
00:07:28.520 --> 00:07:33.790
So by saying -- Forest, now I start to
see how these processes are related.

148
00:07:33.790 --> 00:07:38.310
And so I can see, for example,
I've got the gnome Terminal server, and

149
00:07:38.310 --> 00:07:45.220
inside of that I've got bash, and
inside of that I've got ps -aux --forest.

150
00:07:45.220 --> 00:07:47.760
They're related,
they're tied to each other.

151

And what it's doing is in the background,

376
00:18:54.007 --> 00:18:56.729
it's actually running
a command called kill, right?

377
00:18:56.729 --> 00:18:57.661
Kind of aggressive.

378
00:18:57.661 --> 00:18:58.181
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

379
00:18:58.181 --> 00:19:01.377
if we take a look at the documentation for
kill, I'll just do a man kill.

380
00:19:01.377 --> 00:19:02.671
This is-
>> [LAUGH]

381
00:19:02.671 --> 00:19:04.745
>> At least it's not the other way round.

382
00:19:04.745 --> 00:19:06.552
[LAUGH]
>> So what you'll see here is the kill

383
00:19:06.552 --> 00:19:08.024
command is pretty simple, right?

384
00:19:08.024 --> 00:19:11.389
You say kill, and then you specify
a process ID, and kills it.

385
00:19:11.389 --> 00:19:14.597
And there's a lot of other options here
where we can change the way the kill

386
00:19:14.597 --> 00:19:18.040
works, so you can even change the way
that it is actually killing the process.

387
00:19:18.040 --> 00:19:20.398
So you can tell it to simulate an error.

388
00:19:20.398 --> 00:19:23.781
You can tell it to tell it to just restart
the process, or you could tell it to act

389
00:19:23.781 --> 00:19:27.350
like it crashed, you'll make the program
think it crashed, and then it resets.

390
00:19:27.350 --> 00:19:29.170
There's all sorts of different
things that you can send.

391
00:19:29.170 --> 00:19:31.452
For developers,
they'll use this frequently,

392
00:19:31.452 --> 00:19:34.943
to test out various scenarios to make
sure their applications can recover.

393
00:19:34.943 --> 00:19:38.563
But for us, if I've got an application
like Midnight Commander that's just

394
00:19:38.563 --> 00:19:40.968
running and
maybe it's just going crazy, right?

395
00:19:40.968 --> 00:19:47.681
So I do a ps -aux, I grep for
Midnight Commander, and there it is.

396
00:19:47.681 --> 00:19:49.414
And, yeah, see that RHS?

397
00:19:49.414 --> 00:19:52.740
That line, it just has MC in the name,
so that's why it came up earlier.

398
00:19:52.740 --> 00:19:55.392
But here's that Midnight Commander
process 1313, and

399
00:19:55.392 --> 00:19:57.427
I decided I don't want
that running anymore.

400
00:19:57.427 --> 00:20:00.260
I can do a kill 1313, like that.

401
00:20:01.360 --> 00:20:02.750
And it's gonna send a signal to it,

402
00:20:02.750 --> 00:20:05.020
telling it that the process has ended,
right?

403
00:20:05.020 --> 00:20:07.670
It's gonna terminate it,
with what's called a sig term.

404
00:20:07.670 --> 00:20:11.570
I could do a one of
the other different modes.

405
00:20:13.870 --> 00:20:16.110
Well, they all have a number
coded to them, right?

406
00:20:16.110 --> 00:20:21.000
So if you do a kill -l,
you get a list of the numbers, right?

407
00:20:21.000 --> 00:20:22.845
So I don't have these memorized, and

408
00:20:22.845 --> 00:20:25.507
I don't feel bad about that
cuz there's a ton of them.

409
00:20:25.507 --> 00:20:27.296
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] You see all the different

410
00:20:27.296 --> 00:20:29.797
numbers here, but
some of these are telling it,

411
00:20:29.797 --> 00:20:32.002
like it's an aborted operation, right?

412
00:20:32.002 --> 00:20:34.128
So cancel the operation
you're performing right now.

413
00:20:34.128 --> 00:20:38.010
Most applications will recover from that,
and just retry their operation.

414
00:20:38.010 --> 00:20:41.984
SIGTERM, which is buried in here
somewhere, is telling it to terminate,

415
00:20:41.984 --> 00:20:45.717
to actually end and stop running,
and that's normally what we want.

416
00:20:45.717 --> 00:20:48.960
You've also got SIGKILL, where it
knows that we're manually killing it,

417
00:20:48.960 --> 00:20:50.591
versus thinking of some kinda error.

418
00:20:50.591 --> 00:20:52.429
>> There's SIGTERM, number 15.

419
00:20:52.429 --> 00:20:56.592
>> 15, yep, so 1, 9, and 15,
are probably the most common.

420
00:20:56.592 --> 00:20:59.330
And 9, that sigkill, is the default.

421
00:20:59.330 --> 00:21:00.527
That's what we're sending it.

422
00:21:00.527 --> 00:21:05.280
But we could say, kill -9, and
now we know we're sending it a SIGKILL, or

423
00:21:05.280 --> 00:21:09.290
kill -15, and
now we know we're sending it a SIGTERM.

424
00:21:09.290 --> 00:21:11.614
But for most of us,
if we just wanna kill it, right?

425
00:21:11.614 --> 00:21:16.160
We just wanna get it out of there,
I see that process ID 1313 running, right?

426
00:21:16.160 --> 00:21:20.170
Actually, let me change this up,
just searching for that one process.

427
00:21:20.170 --> 00:21:21.260
So there it is.

428
00:21:21.260 --> 00:21:26.060
And then, if I do a kill 1313,
that's gonna terminate it.

429
00:21:26.060 --> 00:21:29.780
And now, when I pull up that listing,
all I get is my grep command,

430
00:21:29.780 --> 00:21:31.960
the actual process is gone.

431
00:21:31.960 --> 00:21:36.210
And if I switch over to my tab, Midnight
Commander, it's still running, sort of.

432
00:21:36.210 --> 00:21:39.792
Look at that little note down
there at the bottom, Terminated.

433
00:21:39.792 --> 00:21:40.515
>> Terminated.

434
00:21:40.515 --> 00:21:45.120
Okay and it's actually returned me to my
prompt, but the screen hasn't refreshed.

435
00:21:45.120 --> 00:21:45.852
So there we go.

436
00:21:45.852 --> 00:21:48.195
And it can't refresh
because it's terminated,

437
00:21:48.195 --> 00:21:50.280
the process itself is already dead.

438
00:21:50.280 --> 00:21:52.370
So it's not able to reload.

439
00:21:52.370 --> 00:21:55.628
So that's it though, well,
now we're back in business, and

440
00:21:55.628 --> 00:21:58.157
that process is no longer
taking over my system.

441
00:21:58.157 --> 00:22:00.707
So that's the kill command,
it's a pretty handy on,

442
00:22:00.707 --> 00:22:02.711
especially when you know that process ID.

443
00:22:02.711 --> 00:22:05.025
>> Now, Don,
what if I do not know the process ID.

444
00:22:05.025 --> 00:22:08.471
For whatever reason, I couldn't grab that,
is there anything I can do?

445
00:22:08.471 --> 00:22:10.415
>> Yeah, you can.

446
00:22:10.415 --> 00:22:13.335
If you dont know the process ID,
if you just know the application name,

447
00:22:13.335 --> 00:22:15.455
or let me give you a different scenario,
right?

448
00:22:15.455 --> 00:22:16.452
You mentioned web browsers.

449
00:22:16.452 --> 00:22:17.121
>> I did.

450
00:22:17.121 --> 00:22:20.103
>> Web browsers, say, boy,
what a pain in the butt.

451
00:22:20.103 --> 00:22:21.691
>> [LAUGH]
>> Web browsers crash a lot.

452
00:22:21.691 --> 00:22:25.930
And sometimes we dont realize how often
they crash, but web browsers crash a lot,

453
00:22:25.930 --> 00:22:28.600
and they go crazy a lot,
consume memory a lot.

454
00:22:28.600 --> 00:22:31.482
And so most vendors like Firefox and

455
00:22:31.482 --> 00:22:36.396
Google Chrome, they make each
tab run in it's own process.

456
00:22:36.396 --> 00:22:37.610
So that's awesome.

457
00:22:37.610 --> 00:22:40.288
If Chrome starts going nuts on my system,

458
00:22:40.288 --> 00:22:44.890
I might have fifteen processes to kill,
and that's really annoying.

459
00:22:44.890 --> 00:22:49.100
So instead of killing by a process number,
we can kill by a name.

460
00:22:49.100 --> 00:22:51.895
And we can say, I'm gonna look for any
occurrence of this name, and kill them.

461
00:22:51.895 --> 00:22:53.809
You gotta be really
careful with it though,

462
00:22:53.809 --> 00:22:55.515
cuz in my Midnight Commander example,

463
00:22:55.515 --> 00:22:58.998
there is more than one process that had MC
in it, so we gotta be a little careful.

464
00:22:58.998 --> 00:23:01.120
But if I were to fire up
something like Chromium.

465
00:23:02.260 --> 00:23:07.139
And so here we go, and maybe I'll
go to CNN.com, I'll go to ITPro.TV,

466
00:23:07.139 --> 00:23:08.571
I'll go to Fox News.

467
00:23:08.571 --> 00:23:12.022
We'll be fair and balanced, right?

468
00:23:12.022 --> 00:23:14.000
We gotta get all of it.

469
00:23:14.000 --> 00:23:16.470
So I'm pulling up all these
different web pages, right?

470
00:23:16.470 --> 00:23:19.828
Each one is technically
a different process.

471
00:23:19.828 --> 00:23:23.913
And so when I come back here,
and I do a ps -aux, and

472
00:23:23.913 --> 00:23:28.780
I start looking around,
I can find Chromium in here.

473
00:23:28.780 --> 00:23:30.140
And look at that, right?

474
00:23:30.140 --> 00:23:32.290
It's a bunch of different processes.

475
00:23:33.440 --> 00:23:35.464
So if I wanna kill them all, right?

476
00:23:35.464 --> 00:23:37.878
[LAUGH] Really aggressive this afternoon.

477
00:23:37.878 --> 00:23:39.407
>> [LAUGH]
>> I wanna kill them all,

478
00:23:39.407 --> 00:23:40.305
so- [LAUGH]
>> It's a Metallica album.

479
00:23:40.305 --> 00:23:43.045
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, [LAUGH] so I can come in here and

480
00:23:43.045 --> 00:23:47.860
I can use the killall command,
followed by a name instead.

481
00:23:47.860 --> 00:23:49.823
And so I can look for that name.

482
00:23:49.823 --> 00:23:53.259
I'm gonna go killall chromium,
like that, and it's gonna look for it.

483
00:23:53.259 --> 00:23:54.856
Now, notice how I got process not found,
right?

484
00:23:54.856 --> 00:23:58.702
And that's because it's not called
chromium, it's called chromium-browser,

485
00:23:58.702 --> 00:23:59.685
if I remember right.

486
00:23:59.685 --> 00:24:00.234
It isn't.

487
00:24:00.234 --> 00:24:00.873
>> Shoot it's not.

488
00:24:00.873 --> 00:24:05.634
>> Yeah, now I really gotta figure
out what this thing is called.

489
00:24:05.634 --> 00:24:09.400
And I think my problem is that I'm getting
scrolled off the edge of the screen to see

490
00:24:09.400 --> 00:24:11.650
what the actual executable is named.

491
00:24:11.650 --> 00:24:15.790
So let me pull this up.

492
00:24:15.790 --> 00:24:17.670
Normally what I would do is
just export this thing out.

493
00:24:17.670 --> 00:24:20.270
Well, actually I could export it to less,
couldn't I?

494
00:24:20.270 --> 00:24:22.004
>> Yeah.
>> Pipe that to less.

495
00:24:22.004 --> 00:24:25.510
Cuz less will let you scroll left and
right and see the rest of it, and

496
00:24:25.510 --> 00:24:27.100
I can search for old Chromium,

497
00:24:27.100 --> 00:24:29.910
and we're gonna find out what
that thing is actually called.

498
00:24:30.930 --> 00:24:33.800
It is called Chromium-browser.

499
00:24:33.800 --> 00:24:35.480
That's interesting,
it didn't pull the name.

500
00:24:35.480 --> 00:24:37.352
S did I spell it wrong?

501
00:24:37.352 --> 00:24:38.590
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

502
00:24:38.590 --> 00:24:40.565
>> It doesn't help it with that.

503
00:24:40.565 --> 00:24:41.800
>> No.

504
00:24:41.800 --> 00:24:42.690
>> But yeah, there it is.

505
00:24:42.690 --> 00:24:46.140
We'll do full path,
maybe that will make it happy.

506
00:24:46.140 --> 00:24:49.573
And grab that.

507
00:24:49.573 --> 00:24:52.680
All right, and we'll do a kill all.

508
00:24:52.680 --> 00:24:54.096
And we'll feed that in there.

509
00:24:54.096 --> 00:24:54.960
There we go.

510
00:24:54.960 --> 00:24:57.150
So it must have hit some kind
of duplicate for some reason.

511
00:24:57.150 --> 00:25:00.835
But by doing it that way it's gonna say,
I'm not just looking for

512
00:25:00.835 --> 00:25:05.290
a single process ID, I'm looking for
every instance of Chromium-browser.

513
00:25:05.290 --> 00:25:10.505
We're gonna knock that out as well as
the child processes that might spawn.

514
00:25:10.505 --> 00:25:13.390
Cuz a web browser can spawn plugins and
extensions and

515
00:25:13.390 --> 00:25:16.980
other things, it will kill all those
too and nail them and knock them out.

516
00:25:16.980 --> 00:25:20.040
So now when I come in and
I take a look and

517
00:25:20.040 --> 00:25:24.750
see if I have any Chromium instances,
I don't.

518
00:25:24.750 --> 00:25:27.500
Okay, I killed them and
knocked them all out.

519
00:25:27.500 --> 00:25:31.990
So if you don't know the number,
you can use a name if you know the name.

520
00:25:31.990 --> 00:25:32.960
That was my challenge.

521
00:25:32.960 --> 00:25:37.020
Or if there's just more than one
process you can kill them all by using

522
00:25:37.020 --> 00:25:37.880
that kill all command.

523
00:25:37.880 --> 00:25:39.960
Really handy one to do right there.

524
00:25:39.960 --> 00:25:43.730
>> All right, Don,
well you've given us a great, a bite of

525
00:25:43.730 --> 00:25:47.030
a food when it comes to working with
the processes inside of our Linux system.

526
00:25:47.030 --> 00:25:51.350
We now know how to find them, list them,
work through them, see who's running what.

527
00:25:51.350 --> 00:25:55.970
And if need be,
take the old [LAUGH] the old

528
00:25:55.970 --> 00:26:00.000
geeter to a process that's gone rogue on
us cuz that does happen from time to time.

529
00:26:00.000 --> 00:26:02.890
So it's really great that we have
the ability to make them stop and

530
00:26:02.890 --> 00:26:05.080
work with our system,
make it do what we need it to do.

531
00:26:05.080 --> 00:26:07.410
Don, anything that you want
to part us with before we go?

532
00:26:07.410 --> 00:26:08.950
>> Yeah, the commands you saw in here,

533
00:26:08.950 --> 00:26:10.670
they're pretty much
present on every system.

534
00:26:10.670 --> 00:26:12.370
But there are other ones that
are out there, I know Daniel and

535
00:26:12.370 --> 00:26:14.280
I were talking before the show.

536
00:26:14.280 --> 00:26:17.070
I use top just because it's what I'm
used to, it's been around forever.

537
00:26:17.070 --> 00:26:21.630
Daniel uses htop, which is present in
most distros, let me show you real quick.

538
00:26:21.630 --> 00:26:27.010
The top that I was using is just black and
white, here's the data, whatever.

539
00:26:27.010 --> 00:26:30.580
If you have htop on your system,
you can run it and it looks pretty.

540
00:26:30.580 --> 00:26:31.730
>> Look at that.

541
00:26:31.730 --> 00:26:33.432
>> [LAUGH] It's the same data,

542
00:26:33.432 --> 00:26:38.070
[LAUGH] it's just being rendered in
a pretty format, so people like it.

543
00:26:38.070 --> 00:26:39.360
It's got a lot more options.

544
00:26:39.360 --> 00:26:41.880
You see down there the F keys that you
can hit to do all sorts of things.

545
00:26:41.880 --> 00:26:45.612
So don't think that top and kill and kill
all are the only ones that are out there.

546
00:26:45.612 --> 00:26:48.200
There's plenty of other
different techniques.

547
00:26:48.200 --> 00:26:50.560
Find the ones that you like,
the ones that you want to use.

548
00:26:50.560 --> 00:26:52.970
But just know that there
are a ton of different ways.

549
00:26:52.970 --> 00:26:54.999
But you can always count
on top being there, and

550
00:26:54.999 --> 00:26:57.300
you can always count on kill and
kill all being there.

551
00:26:57.300 --> 00:26:59.520
The rest of them may or
may not always be there for

552
00:26:59.520 --> 00:27:00.860
you when you're working on a server.

553
00:27:00.860 --> 00:27:02.830
>> All right, well Don thanks so
much for dropping by today and

554
00:27:02.830 --> 00:27:07.140
teaching us how to work with our processes
inside of our Linux command line area.

555
00:27:07.140 --> 00:27:09.590
But it does look like we are out
of time for this episode.

556
00:27:09.590 --> 00:27:12.140
We do thank you good folks out there for
watching as well, but

557
00:27:12.140 --> 00:27:14.920
I guess it's that time for us to sign off.

558
00:27:14.920 --> 00:27:17.470
For ITProTV I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

559
00:27:17.470 --> 00:27:18.110
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

560
00:27:18.110 --> 00:27:20.801
>> And we'll see you next time.

561
00:27:20.801 --> 00:27:26.714
[MUSIC]

562
00:27:26.714 --> 00:27:29.562
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how Linux manages storage. He demonstrates how storage is detected by Linux, and then shows how to mount the drives to make them usable. At the end of the episode, he explains how to monitor disk utilization to see if you are running low on space.
episodes.title: Managing Storage

And to your point, if you're running
a Linux install that has a graphical user

interface the odds are its got

Instead, I normally modify it a good bit.

485
00:23:41.932 --> 00:23:46.093
And so let's take for
example my internal drive,

486
00:23:46.093 --> 00:23:52.050
this /mnt/storage, which df-h
told me a moment ago is 35% full.

487
00:23:52.050 --> 00:23:53.664
All right.
Well, why is it 35% full?

488
00:23:53.664 --> 00:23:56.347
I wanna find out who is eating up so much
space cuz maybe I thought it was empty.

489
00:23:56.347 --> 00:23:58.348
Or maybe I'm at 99% full, and

490
00:23:58.348 --> 00:24:01.996
so I just need to find out where
that space is being consumed.

491
00:24:01.996 --> 00:24:04.666
So I can jump in there with du,
and with du,

492
00:24:04.666 --> 00:24:07.650
you can actually point
it at another location.

493
00:24:07.650 --> 00:24:12.150
So I can say du/mnt/storage, and so
now it's gonna point over there.

494
00:24:12.150 --> 00:24:15.306
But if I just run that, man,
it's gonna hit that whole drive.

495
00:24:15.306 --> 00:24:19.489
And I've got a ton of stuff over there,
really important stuff like Zork.

496
00:24:19.489 --> 00:24:23.844
And so [LAUGH] I see all that
information right there.

497
00:24:23.844 --> 00:24:28.689
And it gives it to me, and it gives it
to me in these byte values and stuff.

498
00:24:28.689 --> 00:24:30.449
So let's make this-
>> Always fun to read.

499
00:24:30.449 --> 00:24:32.050
>> Let's make it a little more friendly,
right?

500
00:24:32.050 --> 00:24:34.862
So I'm gonna take this,
I'm gonna add a little bit more to it.

501
00:24:34.862 --> 00:24:37.764
I'm gonna add -chd.

502
00:24:37.764 --> 00:24:39.384
First off, because there
are a couple of options, right?

503
00:24:39.384 --> 00:24:43.596
So -c is me telling it I
want to get a grand total.

504
00:24:43.596 --> 00:24:47.755
Give me a summary of the amount
of storage at the end, right?

505
00:24:47.755 --> 00:24:49.710
-h, I want it to be human readable.

506
00:24:49.710 --> 00:24:53.100
I want it to have sizes like gigabyte,
and megabyte, and kilobyte,

507
00:24:53.100 --> 00:24:54.580
not just straight up bytes.

508
00:24:54.580 --> 00:24:56.610
Make it a little more easier to read.

509
00:24:56.610 --> 00:24:59.340
And then d, I want to set a depth.

510
00:24:59.340 --> 00:25:02.170
I don't want it to go into
every subfolder, right?

511
00:25:02.170 --> 00:25:06.230
On this disk, I've only got a couple
of folders that are present.

512
00:25:06.230 --> 00:25:09.200
And I just wanna know which
folder is eating the most space.

513
00:25:09.200 --> 00:25:13.802
If I go into my Storage Disks,
I've got my Google Drive, my ISOs,

514
00:25:13.802 --> 00:25:15.872
QEMU, I've got shared VMs.

515
00:25:15.872 --> 00:25:18.676
I just wanna know which folder
is eating up that space.

516
00:25:18.676 --> 00:25:22.562
So -d lets you set a depth, and
you need to follow it by a number.

517
00:25:22.562 --> 00:25:25.781
I wanna go one folder deep and that's it.

518
00:25:25.781 --> 00:25:31.932
So this would be -d 1, instead of
combining my letters, it's -chd 1.

519
00:25:31.932 --> 00:25:36.780
And the way I remember this is, Daniel,
did you ever see the movie C.H.U.D?

520
00:25:36.780 --> 00:25:39.448
>> C.H.U.D, when you wrote chd,

521
00:25:39.448 --> 00:25:44.027
I thought C.H.U.D. [LAUGH]
>> It's a terrible B horror film from

522
00:25:44.027 --> 00:25:44.820
the 80s.

523
00:25:44.820 --> 00:25:46.036
>> That Don loves.

524
00:25:46.036 --> 00:25:48.054
>> It's how I remember disk utilization.

525
00:25:48.054 --> 00:25:49.744
What is eating up all of my space,
C.H.U.D. [LAUGH].

526
00:25:49.744 --> 00:25:52.876
>> You see it had its purpose,
Don, it had its purpose.

527
00:25:52.876 --> 00:25:55.240
>> That's my mnemonic on this one.

528
00:25:55.240 --> 00:25:57.737
So anyhow I'm gonna go ahead and do du.

529
00:25:57.737 --> 00:26:03.010
And I'll do -chd1/mnt/storage and it's
gonna lay the folders out for me, right?

530
00:26:03.010 --> 00:26:07.139
And when I run that, now this is a heck
of a lot more useful to me, right?

531
00:26:07.139 --> 00:26:10.710
Because I can see my Google Drive
is eating up 1.7 gigs.

532
00:26:10.710 --> 00:26:16.329
I can see that my ISOs are eating up
114 gigs, I've got a lot of ISO images.

533
00:26:16.329 --> 00:26:18.121
My profile is four and a half gigs.

534
00:26:18.121 --> 00:26:20.796
I've got Show Notes at 4.3 gigs.

535
00:26:20.796 --> 00:26:24.151
My VMs,
looks like they're the winner at 141 gigs.

536
00:26:24.151 --> 00:26:28.828
So I've got virtual machines that
are consuming the most space.

537
00:26:28.828 --> 00:26:32.290
And from here, we can start drilling
down and say okay, well which VMs?

538
00:26:32.290 --> 00:26:34.750
So let me go ahead and
look inside of the VMs folder.

539
00:26:34.750 --> 00:26:38.729
And now I can look in here,
and I can see that looks like,

540
00:26:38.729 --> 00:26:40.950
who's our winner on this one?

541
00:26:40.950 --> 00:26:43.640
I guess the Windows VM,
I got a Windows VM here.

542
00:26:43.640 --> 00:26:44.933
>> It is lab-dc01.

543
00:26:44.933 --> 00:26:46.890
>> No, macOS, lab-dc01?

544
00:26:46.890 --> 00:26:48.085
>> No, that is 28 gigs.

545
00:26:48.085 --> 00:26:50.672
>> Looking over it,
yeah, macOS at 28 gigs.

546
00:26:50.672 --> 00:26:53.304
So I got a Mac virtual machine,
it is at 28 gigs inside.

547
00:26:53.304 --> 00:26:55.949
So now I've identified
who's eating up that space.

548
00:26:55.949 --> 00:26:59.470
I might have to run the command a few
times before I finally get all the way

549
00:26:59.470 --> 00:27:02.756
down to the level where I'm able to
identify if I am able to see it and

550
00:27:02.756 --> 00:27:03.892
drill down with that.

551
00:27:03.892 --> 00:27:05.726
So df is great for a quick view,

552
00:27:05.726 --> 00:27:10.751
du is really useful when we actually need
to find out what's consuming our storage.

553
00:27:10.751 --> 00:27:11.306
>> Well, Don,

554
00:27:11.306 --> 00:27:14.394
I wish I would have had this episode
back when I first started with Linux.

555
00:27:14.394 --> 00:27:17.881
Because it takes you a little while,
usually fill to fill up your drive.

556
00:27:17.881 --> 00:27:20.753
And where you're actually
needing these types of

557
00:27:20.753 --> 00:27:22.812
things in some real emergency way.

558
00:27:22.812 --> 00:27:26.014
And then you're, I don't know how to check
for this, this would've been fantastic.

559
00:27:26.014 --> 00:27:29.213
It was a great demonstration showing
us how we can mount our drives,

560
00:27:29.213 --> 00:27:31.460
how we can permanently make that happen.

561
00:27:31.460 --> 00:27:34.620
And then start looking at utilization
when it comes what is actually going

562
00:27:34.620 --> 00:27:35.690
on inside of those drives.

563
00:27:35.690 --> 00:27:39.162
Don, you did a fantastic job with these
demonstrations today, appreciate it.

564
00:27:39.162 --> 00:27:43.630
But looking at the clock over here, and
it has certainly run out of time for us.

565
00:27:43.630 --> 00:27:46.172
>> [LAUGH]
>> I do like to give you a chance to add

566
00:27:46.172 --> 00:27:48.286
anything to the show before we close.

567
00:27:48.286 --> 00:27:50.619
>> Obviously there's a lot more
commands involved with storage,

568
00:27:50.619 --> 00:27:52.179
but the ones you see
here are pretty basic.

569
00:27:52.179 --> 00:27:55.114
And I'll just say that I was pretty
shocked that Zork wasn't what was

570
00:27:55.114 --> 00:27:56.746
actually eating up all my disk space.

571
00:27:56.746 --> 00:27:58.807
Yeah, that's a whole whopping 16k or
something.

572
00:27:58.807 --> 00:28:02.300
[LAUGH] But
these are pretty handy commands.

573
00:28:02.300 --> 00:28:04.890
Daniel, you mentioned you wished
you would have known that earlier.

574
00:28:04.890 --> 00:28:07.952
There's a lot of stuff that can happen,
usually centering around log files.

575
00:28:07.952 --> 00:28:12.116
Where some service starts crashing on your
system, or some daemon is restarting, and

576
00:28:12.116 --> 00:28:13.382
it floods your log files.

577
00:28:13.382 --> 00:28:16.256
It fills up your hard drives, and
du is a great way to find that.

578
00:28:16.256 --> 00:28:19.310
So a wonderful troubleshooting tool,
not just an informational tool.

579
00:28:19.310 --> 00:28:20.932
>> All right, well, Don,
thanks for joining us today.

580
00:28:20.932 --> 00:28:24.300
We appreciate your time, and we appreciate
our audience out there for watching.

581
00:28:24.300 --> 00:28:26.092
But as I've said,
we've run out of time for this episode.

582
00:28:26.092 --> 00:28:27.991
Come back for more though,
we've got plenty to come.

583
00:28:27.991 --> 00:28:30.999
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

584
00:28:30.999 --> 00:28:31.982
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

585
00:28:31.982 --> 00:28:33.498
>> And we'll see you next time.

586
00:28:33.498 --> 00:28:40.704
[MUSIC]

587
00:28:40.704 --> 00:28:43.964
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how difficult it can be to find files inside of a Linux system due to distribution fragmentation. He then demonstrates numerous methods that can be used to locate files quickly and easily. Specifically, he demonstrates the which, whereis, locate, find and grep commands.
episodes.title: Finding Files
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.138 --> 00:00:06.185
Welcome to ITPRO.TV I'm your host,
Don Pezet.

2
00:00:06.185 --> 00:00:07.088
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.088 --> 00:00:08.336
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.336 --> 00:00:12.310
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:12.310 --> 00:00:14.264
>> All right, greetings everyone and

6
00:00:14.264 --> 00:00:17.203
welcome back to another
great episode of ITPRO.TV.

7
00:00:17.203 --> 00:00:18.443
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

8
00:00:18.443 --> 00:00:21.039
And in today's episode,
we have a treat for you.

9
00:00:21.039 --> 00:00:24.152
We're doing Linux in the, or
[LAUGH] command line Linux stuff.

10
00:00:24.152 --> 00:00:25.486
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's what we've been working on.

11
00:00:25.486 --> 00:00:28.380
Don's laughing at me because I'm
butchering our intro here, but

12
00:00:28.380 --> 00:00:29.626
that's what we're doing.

13
00:00:29.626 --> 00:00:32.965
And joining us today,
the laughter is coming from Mr. Don Pezet.

14
00:00:32.965 --> 00:00:34.695
>> [LAUGH]
>> Don, welcome to the show.

15
00:00:34.695 --> 00:00:35.764
How are you, Mr. Funny Man?

16
00:00:35.764 --> 00:00:37.251
[LAUGH]
>> Hey, I'm doing great, and

17
00:00:37.251 --> 00:00:39.126
now that we've set the bar at
that high level of quality,

18
00:00:39.126 --> 00:00:39.961
I know I can live up to it.

19
00:00:39.961 --> 00:00:40.998
>> [LAUGH] That's right.

20
00:00:40.998 --> 00:00:41.670
Well, I could help you out.

21
00:00:41.670 --> 00:00:46.496
>> [LAUGH] We're going to be finding
files and this is a fun episode for

22
00:00:46.496 --> 00:00:49.230
me because I lose stuff all the time.

23
00:00:49.230 --> 00:00:52.430
I can't remember where I put things in the
file system, and then I gotta find them,

24
00:00:52.430 --> 00:00:57.770
and in the Linux world,
we actually have a ton of ways to find it.

25
00:00:57.770 --> 00:01:00.100
Almost all of which
are faster than the GUI.

26
00:01:00.100 --> 00:01:03.631
In the GUI, you have the ability, usually
through whatever your file manager is,

27
00:01:03.631 --> 00:01:06.880
like Nautilus where you can go in and
do a search and it'll find files.

28
00:01:06.880 --> 00:01:07.790
But they're all slow.

29
00:01:07.790 --> 00:01:09.100
I've tried them all, they're all slow.

30
00:01:09.100 --> 00:01:10.690
I don't know why, they just are.

31
00:01:10.690 --> 00:01:14.861
But when you go to the command line,
we have a virtual cornucopia of utilities

32
00:01:14.861 --> 00:01:19.113
that we can [LAUGH] use to locate files
and locate information across the drive.

33
00:01:19.113 --> 00:01:21.902
And so I wanna walk you
through a handful of those,

34
00:01:21.902 --> 00:01:25.169
all of which have saved my bacon
at some point in my career.

35
00:01:25.169 --> 00:01:27.795
[LAUGH] So we'll get a chance to see
them right here in this episode.

36
00:01:27.795 --> 00:01:28.390
>> All right, Don.

37
00:01:28.390 --> 00:01:31.554
Well let's pick the first fruit
out of that veritable cornucopia.

38
00:01:31.554 --> 00:01:32.977
What are we going to do?

39
00:01:32.977 --> 00:01:36.698
>> Let's start off with the which command,
which-

40
00:01:36.698 --> 00:01:38.419
>> So top hat, pointy broom, cauldron?

41
00:01:38.419 --> 00:01:40.068
>> We're gonna burn it at the stake.

42
00:01:40.068 --> 00:01:44.023
>> [LAUGH]
>> This is going on [CROSSTALK]

43
00:01:44.023 --> 00:01:45.177
>> We're having fun.

44
00:01:45.177 --> 00:01:47.787
>> So if you watched all of these
episodes, I've actually already used

45
00:01:47.787 --> 00:01:50.770
the which command in some other episodes
like when we were setting our Shells.

46
00:01:50.770 --> 00:01:54.630
If I want to set my default shell,
I need to know where the shell was stored.

47
00:01:54.630 --> 00:01:57.390
You might have a utility that you run,
that you run all the time, but

48
00:01:57.390 --> 00:02:01.630
you have no idea where it is on the file
system thanks to the search path.

49
00:02:01.630 --> 00:02:02.970
It finds things for me.

50
00:02:02.970 --> 00:02:07.219
So maybe for example,
I start using the nano text editor.

51
00:02:07.219 --> 00:02:09.519
This is where you know I'm
lying cuz I don't use it.

52
00:02:09.519 --> 00:02:13.460
[LAUGH] So I'm gonna go to my command
line here and I'm just gonna run nano and

53
00:02:13.460 --> 00:02:15.349
there it is, the nano text editor.

54
00:02:15.349 --> 00:02:15.900
It's amazing.

55
00:02:15.900 --> 00:02:17.987
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now where did that come from?

56
00:02:17.987 --> 00:02:21.019
Where is that executable actually stored?

57
00:02:21.019 --> 00:02:25.000
And you can use the which command,
which is not W-I-T-C-H.

58
00:02:25.000 --> 00:02:27.103
>> [LAUGH]
>> But W-H-I-C-H, and

59
00:02:27.103 --> 00:02:28.469
I can say which nano.

60
00:02:28.469 --> 00:02:29.250
And it'll tell me.

61
00:02:29.250 --> 00:02:32.820
It'll say yeah yeah yeah,
that's in /user/bin/nano.

62
00:02:32.820 --> 00:02:33.496
That's where it's at.

63
00:02:33.496 --> 00:02:35.540
So now I've found that binary.

64
00:02:35.540 --> 00:02:40.211
And the which command works great when I'm
looking for binary executables like this.

65
00:02:40.211 --> 00:02:41.870
But it's not perfect.

66
00:02:41.870 --> 00:02:47.070
What the which command does is it
looks for the very first match.

67
00:02:47.070 --> 00:02:50.880
In other words, there could be more
than one copy of nano on my disk or

68
00:02:50.880 --> 00:02:55.690
nano could have other supporting files
on the disk and witch won't find them.

69
00:02:55.690 --> 00:02:59.128
It finds the very first one and
returns it.

70
00:02:59.128 --> 00:03:01.150
That means it goes quick, which is nice.

71
00:03:01.150 --> 00:03:05.100
And it usually gonna find the right one,
but occasionally it doesn't, so

72
00:03:05.100 --> 00:03:05.860
it's not perfect.

73
00:03:05.860 --> 00:03:07.910
But if you're in a hurry,
like in the shell episode.

74
00:03:07.910 --> 00:03:09.676
I just didn't know where the shell was,
and

75
00:03:09.676 --> 00:03:11.269
the first one is gonna be the right hit.

76
00:03:11.269 --> 00:03:14.230
That's what I want, and
I used that which command.

77
00:03:14.230 --> 00:03:18.536
But you can also do, where is.

78
00:03:18.536 --> 00:03:23.062
Probably the first full on appropriately
named UNIX command you will ever see.

79
00:03:23.062 --> 00:03:24.043
>> [LAUGH]
>> They didn't drop

80
00:03:24.043 --> 00:03:24.854
the vowels or anything.

81
00:03:24.854 --> 00:03:25.385
>> Nah.

82
00:03:25.385 --> 00:03:27.293
>> It's just, where is, and
then you can type something.

83
00:03:27.293 --> 00:03:29.080
It's like you say where is nano?

84
00:03:29.080 --> 00:03:34.610
And when I run that,
this one gives me more than one hit, okay?

85
00:03:34.610 --> 00:03:36.480
So it shows,
if we look at the output here,

86
00:03:36.480 --> 00:03:40.330
it shows the search term that I used,
nano, right?

87
00:03:40.330 --> 00:03:45.804
And, it found /user/bin/nano,
that was the first hit.

88
00:03:45.804 --> 00:03:51.125
But then it found /user/share/nano.

89
00:03:51.125 --> 00:03:53.680
Well, I have a second copy, that binary.

90
00:03:53.680 --> 00:03:55.546
Apparently, I didn't
know that part of second.

91
00:03:55.546 --> 00:03:59.176
We got a second copy of that binary and
maybe I did that on purpose,

92
00:03:59.176 --> 00:04:02.146
maybe some software did,
maybe that was just a link,

93
00:04:02.146 --> 00:04:05.919
that might not even be a real file,
we'd have to go and check it out.

94
00:04:05.919 --> 00:04:07.928
But it also found the man page.

95
00:04:07.928 --> 00:04:11.930
Or nano.one.gz, right,
it's gzipped in archived.

96
00:04:11.930 --> 00:04:14.910
But notice how the file extension
didn't count towards the name here.

97
00:04:14.910 --> 00:04:16.600
It found it and it returned it.

98
00:04:16.600 --> 00:04:20.423
So where is,
is a much more thorough kind of search.

99
00:04:20.423 --> 00:04:25.400
So in that shell episode where I
said which bash and I found there

100
00:04:25.400 --> 00:04:30.190
was /user/bin/bash, I also could have
also done where is bash and it would have

101
00:04:30.190 --> 00:04:35.000
looked and found it and it finds that
same file as well as the man file for it.

102
00:04:35.000 --> 00:04:36.310
We locate it, we can spot it.

103
00:04:36.310 --> 00:04:39.895
So those to two commands are pretty
interchangeable, it's just whether or

104
00:04:39.895 --> 00:04:43.378
not you want to get the first hit and
run with it, or if you want to get more.

105
00:04:43.378 --> 00:04:44.588
It's like when you go to Google and

106
00:04:44.588 --> 00:04:46.345
they've got the are you
feeling lucky button.

107
00:04:46.345 --> 00:04:49.424
>> Yeah.
>> Which is the I'm feeling lucky button,

108
00:04:49.424 --> 00:04:53.600
and the where is, is the give me
the Yahoo results or something.

109
00:04:53.600 --> 00:04:54.712
I don't know.

110
00:04:54.712 --> 00:04:55.480
Kinda deluge.

111
00:04:55.480 --> 00:04:58.531
>> Now Don, will that work with
things like, we use stars and

112
00:04:58.531 --> 00:05:01.854
periods and stuff as kind of like
wild cards in other episodes.

113
00:05:01.854 --> 00:05:05.880
If I just run bash, and I know bash is
like in the command that I'm looking for,

114
00:05:05.880 --> 00:05:08.150
but it's not the command I'm looking for.

115
00:05:08.150 --> 00:05:09.055
Does that work?

116
00:05:09.055 --> 00:05:10.760
Or does it just look for prompt command?

117
00:05:10.760 --> 00:05:11.759
>> It will actually do it.

kinda tailor what it is you're looking for

screw that up, dash name and

00:17:23.490 --> 00:17:25.760

00:17:25.760 --> 00:17:28.890

00:17:28.890 --> 00:17:32.025

00:17:32.025 --> 00:17:37.155

00:17:46.150 --> 00:17:47.960

00:17:47.960 --> 00:17:50.220

00:17:50.220 --> 00:17:54.020

00:17:54.020 --> 00:17:56.030

00:17:56.030 --> 00:17:58.500

>> [LAUGH] Well, Don, I notice that when I

>> Yeah, GREP is really handy
can look inside a file, right?

00:18:34.156 --> 00:18:36.807
Everything that I've done
this whole episode, right,?

We are almost at the end now, and

What if we don't know the file name,

Or what if it's not

I'm looking for something like that.

You can use GREP and
GREP will search inside of files and

00:19:27.120 --> 00:19:28.470

00:19:30.360 --> 00:19:34.200

00:19:36.800 --> 00:19:42.770

00:19:42.770 --> 00:19:45.710
Maybe file one as a couple of terms in it,

00:19:45.710 --> 00:19:48.381

00:19:48.381 --> 00:19:51.450
>> [LAUGH]

00:19:51.450 --> 00:19:52.905

00:19:52.905 --> 00:19:58.017

when you're dealing with a text file,

00:20:15.884 --> 00:20:17.810

00:20:17.810 --> 00:20:20.690

00:20:20.690 --> 00:20:22.740

00:20:22.740 --> 00:20:27.850

00:20:30.941 --> 00:20:32.132

00:20:32.132 --> 00:20:33.640

00:20:34.600 --> 00:20:38.420

00:20:41.790 --> 00:20:45.330

00:20:50.180 --> 00:20:53.090

00:20:54.760 --> 00:20:58.390

00:21:09.500 --> 00:21:11.860

00:21:15.010 --> 00:21:18.960
Darn it, slash star, so it knows to look

00:21:18.960 --> 00:21:21.316
There we go, [LAUGH] we'll get it.

452
00:21:21.316 --> 00:21:22.635
>> You can do it, Todd.

00:21:22.635 --> 00:21:23.140
>> I know.

00:21:23.140 --> 00:21:27.597

00:21:27.597 --> 00:21:30.000

00:21:30.000 --> 00:21:31.860

00:21:31.860 --> 00:21:33.670
Test one and test two did.

00:21:33.670 --> 00:21:36.450
In fact, let me edit test one.

00:21:38.270 --> 00:21:42.170
And on that line that's got the string,

460
00:21:42.170 --> 00:21:44.270
So, like this is a string.

461
00:21:44.270 --> 00:21:46.030
Isn't it awesome?

462
00:21:47.410 --> 00:21:48.100
There we go.

00:21:48.100 --> 00:21:50.320
Now its a full on string, okay?

00:21:50.320 --> 00:21:54.536
And now, when I rerun that search, what

00:21:58.150 --> 00:22:01.076

00:22:02.910 --> 00:22:03.871

00:22:13.280 --> 00:22:15.540

like here's the whole sentence,

00:22:15.540 --> 00:22:17.480

00:22:17.480 --> 00:22:21.990

00:22:21.990 --> 00:22:25.990
Now, the search that I did is
only seraching the files in

00:22:37.200 --> 00:22:39.970

00:22:39.970 --> 00:22:43.750

any subfolder it finds underneath.

00:22:43.750 --> 00:22:46.990

00:22:46.990 --> 00:22:50.850

00:22:50.850 --> 00:22:56.240

00:23:00.800 --> 00:23:01.970

you'll get a ton of errors so

00:23:09.380 --> 00:23:12.600

00:23:12.600 --> 00:23:13.680

00:23:48.480 --> 00:23:52.600
So if it wasn't coloring for you, the i

Test2.

00:24:21.370 --> 00:24:24.410

00:23:04.501 --> 00:23:05.984
>> All right, Don.

452
00:23:05.984 --> 00:23:09.030
Well, that moves us into the last
thing we have for the show.

453
00:23:09.030 --> 00:23:09.800
Very interesting,

454
00:23:09.800 --> 00:23:13.425
I think this is one of the crowning
jewels of working in the Linux system.

455
00:23:13.425 --> 00:23:16.666
And it's because Linux is meant
to be very configurable, right?

456
00:23:16.666 --> 00:23:19.148
It was meant to be the way you like it.

457
00:23:19.148 --> 00:23:23.462
A lot of times, and you've talked about
this as well, things like ls commands.

458
00:23:23.462 --> 00:23:26.100
I wanna add certain options,
or I always add those options.

459
00:23:27.150 --> 00:23:29.950
And Linux, they give us
the ability to make it to where it

460
00:23:29.950 --> 00:23:34.250
always runs that option through a little
command that they give us, correct?

461
00:23:34.250 --> 00:23:38.314
>> Absolutely, yeah, we have aliases where
you can create your own custom name for

462
00:23:38.314 --> 00:23:39.462
any command, right?

463
00:23:39.462 --> 00:23:41.249
I used to do this with the ones
that I would always type wrong.

464
00:23:41.249 --> 00:23:43.839
>> [LAUGH]
>> There were some that I would always

465
00:23:43.839 --> 00:23:47.463
spell them wrong, so in the Unix world,
it's an old command now,

466
00:23:47.463 --> 00:23:51.241
but you used to have IF config Which,
it's still there, ifconfig.

467
00:23:51.241 --> 00:23:54.473
If you work in the Windows world,
the command is ipconfig.

468
00:23:54.473 --> 00:23:57.590
And I would move between Windows and Linux
so much that sometimes I would screw up.

469
00:23:57.590 --> 00:24:00.360
So I started creating an alias,
so that any time I ran ipconfig,

470
00:24:00.360 --> 00:24:03.670
it would just call ifconfig and
save me the screw up.

471
00:24:03.670 --> 00:24:06.910
It doesn't matter now,
cuz ifconfig is going away.

472
00:24:06.910 --> 00:24:10.770
But you can create aliases to
map any name to any command.

473
00:24:10.770 --> 00:24:12.160
And it's pretty handy.

474
00:24:12.160 --> 00:24:14.560
What you do is you just type alias and

475
00:24:14.560 --> 00:24:18.300
then the command that
you want to overwrite.

476
00:24:18.300 --> 00:24:24.417
Okay, so for example,
I may want to overwrite ipconfig, right?

477
00:24:24.417 --> 00:24:27.200
So that's the command that I keep running.

478
00:24:27.200 --> 00:24:28.802
I want it to run as ifconfig.

479
00:24:28.802 --> 00:24:32.575
And so then you can say, equals and
a single tick for a quote mark, and

480
00:24:32.575 --> 00:24:35.290
whatever command you
want it to actually run.

481
00:24:35.290 --> 00:24:38.828
I want it to run ifconfig instead.

482
00:24:38.828 --> 00:24:40.001
So now when I screw up and

483
00:24:40.001 --> 00:24:43.180
type the wrong thing,
it's gonna make me type the right thing.

484
00:24:43.180 --> 00:24:44.790
Now, before I do that,
let me clear that out.

485
00:24:45.910 --> 00:24:47.680
I'm gonna run ipconfig.

486
00:24:47.680 --> 00:24:48.380
Command not found.

487
00:24:48.380 --> 00:24:50.480
All right, it doesn't exist in Linux.

488
00:24:50.480 --> 00:24:55.340
Then I'm gonna run alias
ipconfig=ifconfig.

489
00:24:55.340 --> 00:25:01.080
Now when I run ipconfig, it says,
you meant to run ifconfig, and it runs it.

490
00:25:01.080 --> 00:25:02.760
That's one example of using an alias.

491
00:25:04.330 --> 00:25:05.680
Over the years you learn your commands.

492
00:25:05.680 --> 00:25:06.320
You stop screwing up.

493
00:25:06.320 --> 00:25:07.460
So you don't need it that way.

494
00:25:07.460 --> 00:25:10.070
But where I use it
are command line arguments.

495
00:25:10.070 --> 00:25:12.912
I rarely want just ls.

496
00:25:12.912 --> 00:25:16.207
I almost always want ls -lah, right?

497
00:25:16.207 --> 00:25:17.460
I want the long output.

498
00:25:17.460 --> 00:25:19.760
I wanna show all files, even hidden files.

499
00:25:19.760 --> 00:25:21.797
And I want it to be human
readable file sizes.

500
00:25:21.797 --> 00:25:23.720
That's what I want, lah.

501
00:25:23.720 --> 00:25:25.500
So I have to type that every time.

502
00:25:25.500 --> 00:25:27.036
And that's annoying.

503
00:25:27.036 --> 00:25:32.708
I could just say alias ls equals,
and then I'll do a single tick and

504
00:25:32.708 --> 00:25:37.980
tell it that I actually mean
that to be ls-lah, right?

505
00:25:37.980 --> 00:25:41.242
And when I do that, now whenever I run ls,

506
00:25:41.242 --> 00:25:44.888
it actually runs it the way
that I wanted it to.

507
00:25:44.888 --> 00:25:47.829
And it lays it out here and
I see all the files and

508
00:25:47.829 --> 00:25:50.500
information laid out nice and neat.

509
00:25:50.500 --> 00:25:52.810
And I might even want to go
a little bit further, and

510
00:25:52.810 --> 00:25:57.520
have like a --color=auto,
cuz I lost my coloring in that one.

511
00:25:57.520 --> 00:25:58.920
And so I can add that to it, or

512
00:25:58.920 --> 00:26:02.230
whatever else it is that I need to make
that alias work the way that I want.

513
00:26:02.230 --> 00:26:05.830
And now when I look at it, I get the long
output and it's nice and colorized.

514
00:26:05.830 --> 00:26:08.632
And all I had to run was ls.

515
00:26:08.632 --> 00:26:12.450
Now, quick word of caution about this,
aliases are a temporary thing.

516
00:26:12.450 --> 00:26:15.110
So the moment I log out,
the aliases go away.

517
00:26:15.110 --> 00:26:17.674
We're gonna do another episode
on environment variables and

518
00:26:17.674 --> 00:26:20.001
how we can make these things
persist between sessions.

519
00:26:20.001 --> 00:26:22.584
But just using the alias
command like this is temporary.

520
00:26:22.584 --> 00:26:25.976
So you really wanna put it into a login
script, so that every time you log in,

521
00:26:25.976 --> 00:26:27.670
the aliases are recreated.

522
00:26:27.670 --> 00:26:30.630
And you already have some of
those whether you know it or not.

523
00:26:30.630 --> 00:26:32.540
If you just run the alias command,

524
00:26:32.540 --> 00:26:37.040
it'll show you any aliases you've already
got and you'll see the ones that I made.

525
00:26:37.040 --> 00:26:41.020
There's the alias for
ipconfig right there.

526
00:26:41.020 --> 00:26:45.480
But there's other aliases like egrep and
fgrep, I didnt make those.

527
00:26:45.480 --> 00:26:48.468
But the system has them anyway,
they've been created.

528
00:26:48.468 --> 00:26:51.824
And that's because somebody at Red Hat,
in my case, decided to go ahead and

529
00:26:51.824 --> 00:26:52.620
put those there.

530
00:26:52.620 --> 00:26:54.049
if you're running Ubuntu
you may see different ones.

531
00:26:54.049 --> 00:26:57.829
If you're running Debian you'll see
different ones just based on whatever it

532
00:26:57.829 --> 00:27:00.020
is that was set up for your system.

533
00:27:00.020 --> 00:27:04.384
>> Well, Don you named this other useful
commands and that's definitely what it is.

534
00:27:04.384 --> 00:27:07.562
There's a lot of great, useful commands
that are inside of our Linux systems.

535
00:27:07.562 --> 00:27:11.756
They're gonna help us navigate, help us
get around the place a whole lot easier.

536
00:27:11.756 --> 00:27:16.182
Empower us to use the system in
a better way that's more convenient,

537
00:27:16.182 --> 00:27:17.660
more efficient.

538
00:27:17.660 --> 00:27:20.160
So we just have to be aware of
those things that are in there.

539
00:27:20.160 --> 00:27:24.010
And Don, you did a fantastic job of
showing us today some of those commands

540
00:27:24.010 --> 00:27:26.960
that are lurking around
inside of our Linux box.

541
00:27:26.960 --> 00:27:28.835
Got any parting words before
we close the show today?

542
00:27:28.835 --> 00:27:31.280
>> I tried to cover a lot
of stuff that I use,

543
00:27:31.280 --> 00:27:33.960
things that make my life a little better.

544
00:27:33.960 --> 00:27:37.090
Be careful as you start to find tools and
utilities that you really enjoy.

545
00:27:37.090 --> 00:27:40.200
I always try and stick with ones that
are standard, they're core utilities,

546
00:27:40.200 --> 00:27:42.980
ones that I know are going to be
there no matter what system I get on.

547
00:27:42.980 --> 00:27:45.100
When you start creating
a bunch of aliases,

548
00:27:45.100 --> 00:27:47.830
what happens when you go to a system
that doesn't have those aliases?

549
00:27:47.830 --> 00:27:50.168
Now that that's gone,
you can have a really hard time.

550
00:27:50.168 --> 00:27:52.600
So I try not to rely on them too much.

551
00:27:52.600 --> 00:27:55.859
If you do rely on them a lot, start
carrying a thumb drive with little script

552
00:27:55.859 --> 00:27:59.042
file that creates those aliases real
quick or something of that nature.

553
00:27:59.042 --> 00:28:01.306
But you don't want to lean on it too much,
but

554
00:28:01.306 --> 00:28:04.465
there are a ton of built in utilities
that really can help you and

555
00:28:04.465 --> 00:28:07.945
make that command line environment
a lot more friendly to use.

556
00:28:07.945 --> 00:28:08.755
Just explore around.

557
00:28:08.755 --> 00:28:10.568
Mess around with them.
You'll find that that's actually

558
00:28:10.568 --> 00:28:11.975
pretty neat what you can do in there.

559
00:28:11.975 --> 00:28:13.785
>> Words of wisdom from Don Pezet.

560
00:28:13.785 --> 00:28:17.135
My departing words will be check the man
files for each one of these commands.

561
00:28:17.135 --> 00:28:19.070
They have a lot of great
information inside of them.

562
00:28:19.070 --> 00:28:21.740
It might do something you haven't
even realize it could do and

563
00:28:21.740 --> 00:28:23.580
make your life a whole lot easier.

564
00:28:23.580 --> 00:28:25.142
I know I found out to be true for myself.

565
00:28:25.142 --> 00:28:28.800
Don, thanks so much for joining us today,
appreciate your time and effort as always.

566
00:28:28.800 --> 00:28:31.461
And as always, we appreciate you
good folks out there for watching.

567
00:28:31.461 --> 00:28:35.150
But look at the clock, we have exhausted
the time for yet another great show.

568
00:28:35.150 --> 00:28:35.910
Thanks for joining us,

569
00:28:35.910 --> 00:28:38.870
signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

570
00:28:38.870 --> 00:28:39.582
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

571
00:28:39.582 --> 00:28:42.141
>> And we'll see you next time

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduces viewers to variables. He demonstrates how you can store data in a variable for retrieval at a later time. He then shows a few examples of how these can be used.
episodes.title: Environment Variables
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.230 --> 00:00:03.174
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.174 --> 00:00:08.196
[CROSSTALK]
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.196 --> 00:00:10.705
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:10.705 --> 00:00:13.343
>> All right, greetings everyone.

5
00:00:13.343 --> 00:00:16.114
And welcome back to another
great episode of ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:16.114 --> 00:00:17.863
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

7
00:00:17.863 --> 00:00:21.902
And in today's episode, we are back with
more in our Linux Command Line series.

8
00:00:21.902 --> 00:00:23.985
Joining us in the studio,
you know who it is.

9
00:00:23.985 --> 00:00:25.650
Our good friend, Mr. Don Pezet.

10
00:00:25.650 --> 00:00:26.515
Don, welcome back sir.

11
00:00:26.515 --> 00:00:27.360
We're so glad to have you again.

12
00:00:27.360 --> 00:00:28.160
How is it going today?

13
00:00:28.160 --> 00:00:28.731
>> It is going so well.

14
00:00:28.731 --> 00:00:32.160
And we are ready to dive right back
into the world of Linux Command Line.

15
00:00:32.160 --> 00:00:35.950
And in this episode, we are taking
a look at environment variables.

16
00:00:35.950 --> 00:00:39.620
Which are odd little things that float
around in the back of our [LAUGH]

17
00:00:39.620 --> 00:00:42.630
shell prompts that we
don't think much about.

18
00:00:42.630 --> 00:00:44.680
But they are actually really important.

19
00:00:44.680 --> 00:00:46.078
They're incredibly useful.

20
00:00:46.078 --> 00:00:48.200
So we're gonna take
a look at how they work.

21
00:00:48.200 --> 00:00:50.960
Keep in mind, in this episode,
we're really gonna be doing

22
00:00:50.960 --> 00:00:54.910
a high level overview of environment
variables and how they function.

23
00:00:54.910 --> 00:00:58.339
But in a later series,
we're doing the Linux shell scripting.

24
00:00:58.339 --> 00:01:02.640
And in the shell scripting,
you use variables all the time.

25
00:01:02.640 --> 00:01:03.770
They are a pivotal piece of that.

26
00:01:03.770 --> 00:01:06.790
So here we're gonna focus
on the foundational side.

27
00:01:06.790 --> 00:01:09.340
But be sure to check out the scripting
series if you wanna really see these

28
00:01:09.340 --> 00:01:11.290
things in action and what all they can do.

29
00:01:11.290 --> 00:01:13.940
>> All right, Don, well,
let's talk about environment variables.

30
00:01:13.940 --> 00:01:15.717
You say they are lurking in our machine.

31
00:01:15.717 --> 00:01:17.733
They're super duper powerful.

32
00:01:17.733 --> 00:01:19.319
What the heck are they?

33
00:01:19.319 --> 00:01:20.360
[LAUGH]
>> All right, so

34
00:01:20.360 --> 00:01:23.130
let's just start with the variable.

35
00:01:23.130 --> 00:01:24.712
So a variable is basically a placeholder.

36
00:01:24.712 --> 00:01:27.410
It's a little placeholder in memory.

37
00:01:27.410 --> 00:01:31.240
Where the operating system sets
aside a little spot in memory, and

38
00:01:31.240 --> 00:01:33.477
says you can put stuff here.

39
00:01:33.477 --> 00:01:34.902
Think of this like a storage unit.

40
00:01:34.902 --> 00:01:37.368
[LAUGH] so I rent a storage unit and
I can put junk in there.

41
00:01:37.368 --> 00:01:37.901
>> Listen to this storage.

42
00:01:37.901 --> 00:01:39.940
[LAUGH]
>> And when I need it, I can go and

43
00:01:39.940 --> 00:01:40.780
get it out.

44
00:01:40.780 --> 00:01:42.078
That's all a variable is,
it's mini storage.

45
00:01:42.078 --> 00:01:43.062
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

46
00:01:43.062 --> 00:01:45.176
>> You've got it and you can reach out and

47
00:01:45.176 --> 00:01:47.590
grab data out of it whenever you want.

48
00:01:47.590 --> 00:01:50.058
You can put data there and
it'll sit there.

49
00:01:50.058 --> 00:01:53.304
Sit there until you're ready for
it and you go and you retrieve it.

50
00:01:53.304 --> 00:01:55.810
So that's what a variable does.

51
00:01:55.810 --> 00:01:59.860
Now you can use them, but
your computer uses them all the time,

52
00:01:59.860 --> 00:02:01.660
regardless of whether you use them or not.

53
00:02:01.660 --> 00:02:04.060
Variables are constantly in use.

54
00:02:04.060 --> 00:02:08.510
And so in your system, you have user
variables and system variables.

55
00:02:08.510 --> 00:02:10.460
Applications that create
their own variables.

56
00:02:10.460 --> 00:02:13.560
You have session variables
that are tied to your shell.

57
00:02:13.560 --> 00:02:16.770
You have global variables that
are tied to all of your shells.

58
00:02:16.770 --> 00:02:20.500
There's a number of variations of
the way these things get used.

59
00:02:20.500 --> 00:02:23.550
But at the end of the day, they're
all just a little piece of storage.

60
00:02:23.550 --> 00:02:24.727
A little storage unit.

61
00:02:24.727 --> 00:02:28.160
You can chunk data in there and
retrieve it when you want.

62
00:02:28.160 --> 00:02:32.310
Now if you create your own,
you certainly can make use them.

63
00:02:32.310 --> 00:02:35.730
But even if you don't, there are system
variables that are already created.

64
00:02:35.730 --> 00:02:40.290
>> So Don, we've actually been using
variables throughout this series so far.

65
00:02:40.290 --> 00:02:42.090
We just haven't been calling them that,
right?

66
00:02:42.090 --> 00:02:43.130
>> Yeah, absolutely.

67
00:02:43.130 --> 00:02:46.228
A lot of the commands that we run
are actually just leveraging variables.

68
00:02:46.228 --> 00:02:47.880
Now let me show you an example here.

69
00:02:47.880 --> 00:02:50.380
So in my command prompt,

70
00:02:50.380 --> 00:02:54.960
if I wanna find out what my computer's
name is, I can run the hostname command.

71
00:02:54.960 --> 00:02:56.440
And hostname returns it.

72
00:02:56.440 --> 00:02:58.240
And it just says, it's called Dons Laptop.

73
00:02:58.240 --> 00:02:59.830
Well, where did it get that from?

74
00:02:59.830 --> 00:03:02.440
It got that from an environment variable.

75
00:03:02.440 --> 00:03:05.530
There's a variable that's storing
what my computer's name is.

76
00:03:05.530 --> 00:03:06.350
And when I run hostname,

77
00:03:06.350 --> 00:03:09.710
it's just reaching out there and
grabbing it out of that variable.

78
00:03:09.710 --> 00:03:12.171
The variable in this case is
actually called hostname.

79
00:03:12.171 --> 00:03:16.174
And if I pull that up
through another application,

80
00:03:16.174 --> 00:03:21.110
I can do an echo $HOSTNAME,
and there it is, Dons Laptop.

81
00:03:21.110 --> 00:03:24.350
The variable in this
case was called hostname.

82
00:03:24.350 --> 00:03:25.750
And when I typed it here in this command,

83
00:03:25.750 --> 00:03:29.120
you know that it's a variable because
it starts with a dollar sign.

84
00:03:29.120 --> 00:03:32.320
The dollar sign is the command
line's little flag that says,

85
00:03:32.320 --> 00:03:34.610
what I'm about to type is a variable name,
okay?

86
00:03:34.610 --> 00:03:36.220
And the variables are case sensitive.

87
00:03:36.220 --> 00:03:38.010
This one happens to be
all capital letters.

88
00:03:38.010 --> 00:03:38.700
They don't have to be.

89
00:03:38.700 --> 00:03:41.000
It could be all lowercase letters,
but they are case sensitive.

90
00:03:41.000 --> 00:03:44.488
So when I run that hostname command,
that's what it's actually looking for.

91
00:03:44.488 --> 00:03:45.967
Or if I do whoami.

92
00:03:45.967 --> 00:03:48.295
whoami, I'm dpezet.

93
00:03:48.295 --> 00:03:51.260
All it did was look at
an environment variable.

94
00:03:51.260 --> 00:03:57.570
And the environment variable in this case,
if I echo that one, is called $USER.

95
00:03:57.570 --> 00:03:59.440
And there it is, dpezet.

96
00:03:59.440 --> 00:04:00.240
So that's the variable.

97
00:04:00.240 --> 00:04:02.520
It queries it and it pulls it back.

98
00:04:02.520 --> 00:04:05.590
Even some of the more fancy
commands like hostnamectl.

99
00:04:05.590 --> 00:04:08.500
If I run that one,
it returns a bunch of data.

100
00:04:08.500 --> 00:04:10.640
Here's my computer name,
my chassis, and so on.

101
00:04:10.640 --> 00:04:12.150
All of these are the data.

102
00:04:12.150 --> 00:04:14.930
It really is reaching out to these
different environment variables,

103
00:04:14.930 --> 00:04:18.210
grabbing that data and bringing it here.

104
00:04:18.210 --> 00:04:21.347
Now, how did I know that
it was called $HOSTNAME?

105
00:04:21.347 --> 00:04:23.510
Or how do I know that it was called $USER?

106
00:04:23.510 --> 00:04:26.240
Well, the dollar sign isn't
actually part of the name.

107
00:04:26.240 --> 00:04:29.925
The dollar sign is just a flag that says,
I'm about to type a variable name.

108
