And when I come in here I can
set my variables and I can say,

557
00:27:31.351 --> 00:27:35.866
var1=value1 and var2=value2 and so on.

558
00:27:35.866 --> 00:27:39.207
And by putting them here in this
profile folder when users log in,

559
00:27:39.207 --> 00:27:42.245
when they get that interactive shell,
this will be read and

560
00:27:42.245 --> 00:27:46.040
now they'll get those variables and
they'll be able to use them, okay.

561
00:27:46.040 --> 00:27:49.920
But there's still one little problem with
this which, again I wanna show you guys,

562
00:27:49.920 --> 00:27:54.070
I want to explain in more depth, so,
let's break in to part two though cuz I'm

563
00:27:54.070 --> 00:27:55.960
definitely gonna need
a little more time for it.

564
00:27:55.960 --> 00:28:00.040
But I want to explain how
these variables still aren't

565
00:28:00.040 --> 00:28:01.670
quite gonna be visible for everybody.

566
00:28:01.670 --> 00:28:04.660
And there's an extra little step that we
need to go through to take care of that.

567
00:28:04.660 --> 00:28:07.450
Most variables default to just
being visible to you, and so

568
00:28:07.450 --> 00:28:09.700
here we gotta do a little extra
work to get this one ready.

569
00:28:09.700 --> 00:28:13.630
But this is the starting work for that,
to get those variables pushed out.

570
00:28:13.630 --> 00:28:18.375
>> Definitely looking forward to seeing
how parent shells deal with their

571
00:28:18.375 --> 00:28:19.250
teenage sons.

572
00:28:19.250 --> 00:28:19.750
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

573
00:28:19.750 --> 00:28:20.995
>> Cuz they can be annoying.

574
00:28:20.995 --> 00:28:23.225
They won't take out the garbage or
anything.

575
00:28:23.225 --> 00:28:24.125
>> That's right.
>> Or clean their room.

576
00:28:24.125 --> 00:28:26.620
[LAUGH] All right, Don, well part
two looks like is on our horizon.

577
00:28:26.620 --> 00:28:28.270
I do thank you for joining us so far.

578
00:28:28.270 --> 00:28:30.910
But we're gonna go ahead and
call it a day for this episode.

579
00:28:30.910 --> 00:28:32.680
Come back and watch part two.

580
00:28:32.680 --> 00:28:35.750
See the culmination of John's epic
work that he's got going on here

581
00:28:35.750 --> 00:28:38.568
with environmental and local variables.

582
00:28:38.568 --> 00:28:40.750
But looking at the clock,
we're gonna go ahead and call it a day.

583
00:28:40.750 --> 00:28:41.870
Thanks for watching.

584
00:28:41.870 --> 00:28:42.850
Signing off for ITProTV.

585
00:28:42.850 --> 00:28:44.770
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

586
00:28:44.770 --> 00:28:45.370
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

587
00:28:45.370 --> 00:28:46.759
>> And we'll see you next time.

588
00:28:46.759 --> 00:28:53.530
[MUSIC]

589
00:28:53.530 --> 00:28:58.579
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don continues working with environment variables. He demonstrates how to make a variable globally available between shells. He also demonstrates how to make variables persist between logins.
episodes.title: Environment Variables Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.160
Welcome to ITPro.TV.

2
00:00:01.160 --> 00:00:03.554
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:03.554 --> 00:00:07.366
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:07.366 --> 00:00:08.339
>> [MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.339 --> 00:00:12.230
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:12.230 --> 00:00:14.092
>> All right, greetings everyone and

7
00:00:14.092 --> 00:00:17.077
welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITPro.TV.

8
00:00:17.077 --> 00:00:18.474
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie, and

9
00:00:18.474 --> 00:00:21.374
in today's episode we're back with
more of our Linux Command Line series.

10
00:00:21.374 --> 00:00:24.740
And joining us back in the studio for
a part two on variables,

11
00:00:24.740 --> 00:00:26.730
our good friend, Mr. Don Pezant.

12
00:00:26.730 --> 00:00:28.280
Don, welcome back sir, how's it going?

13
00:00:28.280 --> 00:00:30.720
>> It is going great Daniel,
ready to dive back in and

14
00:00:30.720 --> 00:00:34.450
wrap up with all of the stuff that I
just didn't quite get to in part one.

15
00:00:34.450 --> 00:00:36.217
Remember we're talking about variables and

16
00:00:36.217 --> 00:00:39.154
in the last episode we got a chance to
see how to set up some local variables.

17
00:00:39.154 --> 00:00:42.280
And we were setting up global variables
when I kind or ran out of time, and

18
00:00:42.280 --> 00:00:44.192
I have a lot more that
I wanted to talk about.

19
00:00:44.192 --> 00:00:46.613
So here in this episode we're
gonna be diving back in and

20
00:00:46.613 --> 00:00:48.891
kinda wrapping up with some
of the advanced points.

21
00:00:48.891 --> 00:00:51.499
And slight adjustments we need
to make to get everything

22
00:00:51.499 --> 00:00:53.172
working the way that we want right.

23
00:00:53.172 --> 00:00:56.960
>> Now Don when we left the previous show
we were kind of setting some persistent

24
00:00:56.960 --> 00:00:59.919
variables globally that everyone
would be able to use, and

25
00:00:59.919 --> 00:01:04.140
I guess that's a good place for us to pick
back up on setting those global variables.

26
00:01:04.140 --> 00:01:07.220
>> Right so,
the challenge that I ran into,

27
00:01:07.220 --> 00:01:10.040
right there at the end of the episode, is
that I forgot to talk about a particular

28
00:01:10.040 --> 00:01:12.560
topic, which is called
exporting variables.

29
00:01:12.560 --> 00:01:15.020
When you create a variable it's
usually just created for you.

30
00:01:15.020 --> 00:01:19.370
And it's usually even more so just
created for the session that you're in.

31
00:01:19.370 --> 00:01:23.200
And so, I showed how to add variables
to your bashrc file, right?

32
00:01:23.200 --> 00:01:28.720
So if I pull that up here let me
just tail my dot dash rc file.

33
00:01:28.720 --> 00:01:31.521
And so, I added these three variables,
which are just for me, right?

34
00:01:31.521 --> 00:01:32.890
They're designed for me.

35
00:01:32.890 --> 00:01:34.380
That's great.
And there they go.

36
00:01:34.380 --> 00:01:37.900
Well those variables
are called local variables.

37
00:01:37.900 --> 00:01:40.900
They're just for the session that I'm in.

38
00:01:40.900 --> 00:01:43.750
Unfortunately, when you run some commands,

39
00:01:43.750 --> 00:01:47.130
some commands will do what's
called spawning a sub-shell.

40
00:01:47.130 --> 00:01:50.830
You've get one shell running, and
they spawn a shell underneath it.

41
00:01:50.830 --> 00:01:52.170
It happens quite a bit.

42
00:01:52.170 --> 00:01:56.160
So for example, if I just run ls, right?

43
00:01:56.160 --> 00:01:58.380
I'm in my shell, I ran ls.

44
00:01:58.380 --> 00:01:59.360
It ran in my shell.

45
00:01:59.360 --> 00:02:02.030
It all happened in the same shell.

46
00:02:02.030 --> 00:02:05.160
If I do ls and a semicolon.

47
00:02:05.160 --> 00:02:08.890
And then, I do something like
ps dash dash forest, right?

48
00:02:08.890 --> 00:02:12.440
Which shows me my running processes and
maps them into a tree.

49
00:02:12.440 --> 00:02:16.170
Well the ls command is gonna run and
then the ps command is gonna run.

50
00:02:16.170 --> 00:02:19.340
So by the time ps runs,
ls is already done.

51
00:02:19.340 --> 00:02:23.430
So PS has a shell that's available
right there for it and it uses it so

52
00:02:23.430 --> 00:02:25.690
it's right underneath bash, right?

53
00:02:25.690 --> 00:02:29.321
But if I stick parentheses
around this that tells,

54
00:02:29.321 --> 00:02:32.368
whoops if I can actually do it,
here we go.

55
00:02:32.368 --> 00:02:34.210
>> [LAUGH]
>> That tells bash

56
00:02:34.210 --> 00:02:35.920
that I don't want to run
these as separate commands,

57
00:02:35.920 --> 00:02:38.570
instead I'm giving it what's
called a process list.

58
00:02:38.570 --> 00:02:41.230
Here's a list of processes
I want you to start.

59
00:02:41.230 --> 00:02:46.160
And when this happens,
ps can't take the same shell that ls

60
00:02:46.160 --> 00:02:50.520
is already running in and so
it's gonna spawn off into its own shell.

61
00:02:50.520 --> 00:02:53.640
And when that happens,
look at what happened at the forest.

62
00:02:53.640 --> 00:02:56.440
I have the bar shell that I was in.

63
00:02:56.440 --> 00:02:59.590
And now I have a sub shell underneath it.

64
00:02:59.590 --> 00:03:04.090
And ps actually ran in that sub shell.

65
00:03:04.090 --> 00:03:05.970
Now why do I care about that?

66
00:03:05.970 --> 00:03:07.250
Normally we don't, right?

67
00:03:07.250 --> 00:03:10.750
To an N user it ran,
it did it's job, I got my data,

68
00:03:10.750 --> 00:03:13.310
what do I care if it ran in a sub shell or
not?

69
00:03:13.310 --> 00:03:15.520
With variables we care, right?

70
00:03:15.520 --> 00:03:20.120
So for example,
if I say var 3 equals value 3, right, so

71
00:03:20.120 --> 00:03:22.760
I created variable 3 and there it is.

72
00:03:22.760 --> 00:03:25.140
And then, I type bash and
I move into a subshell.

73
00:03:25.140 --> 00:03:28.590
Now I'm manually moving into
a subshell here, alright?

74
00:03:28.590 --> 00:03:34.910
And when I do that,
if I do echo$ var 3, I get nothing.

75
00:03:34.910 --> 00:03:40.398
And if I type exit and
move out of that shell and

76
00:03:40.398 --> 00:03:45.173
I do an echo $var 3 there it is, okay?

77
00:03:45.173 --> 00:03:49.675
The variable was set for
my local session and local is very,

78
00:03:49.675 --> 00:03:54.330
very literal it means
the session that you're in.

79
00:03:54.330 --> 00:03:57.900
And so,
when I edited that profiles.dscript

80
00:03:57.900 --> 00:04:02.270
at the end of the last episode and I set
a variable there, that would happen for

81
00:04:02.270 --> 00:04:05.050
the initial session that's
a part of my user account.

82
00:04:05.050 --> 00:04:06.600
And all of the other
sessions that I spawn,

83
00:04:06.600 --> 00:04:08.500
they're not gonna have it and
it's not gonna work.

84
00:04:08.500 --> 00:04:11.260
It actually does work for
that first session but

85
00:04:11.260 --> 00:04:13.280
as a user we never see that first session.

86
00:04:13.280 --> 00:04:18.960
So it doesn't work for us, I guess it
would work if you were on one of the TTY

87
00:04:18.960 --> 00:04:24.120
actual console terminals on a server,
but whoever does that, right?

88
00:04:24.120 --> 00:04:27.210
So we've normally SHH'ed in or
something of that nature and

89
00:04:27.210 --> 00:04:29.960
you're in some secondary shell
that doesn't benefit from that.

90
00:04:29.960 --> 00:04:32.560
So, what we need to do is a little extra.

91
00:04:32.560 --> 00:04:33.810
Now to help illustrate this,

92
00:04:33.810 --> 00:04:37.080
because it does get confusing when
you start launching bash after bash.

93
00:04:37.080 --> 00:04:42.500
You know, if I sit here and
run bash three times, technically

94
00:04:42.500 --> 00:04:46.690
I'm four levels deep, right, from my
initial shell all the way down to here.

95
00:04:46.690 --> 00:04:50.760
And if I do a ps dash dash forest I can
see that, see I'm getting deeper and

96
00:04:50.760 --> 00:04:52.020
deeper into sub-shells.

97
00:04:52.020 --> 00:04:54.190
But there actually is
a variable that's stored.

98
00:04:54.190 --> 00:04:59.950
Which I'll do a echo dollar sign,
SHLVL, right, shell level.

99
00:04:59.950 --> 00:05:02.300
And that tells you how
many levels deep you are.

100
00:05:02.300 --> 00:05:05.860
Okay, now be careful cuz you're always one
more level deep than you think you are,

101
00:05:05.860 --> 00:05:07.150
the variable itself.

102
00:05:07.150 --> 00:05:10.920
So I can tell that I've got
four bash prompts open and

103
00:05:10.920 --> 00:05:12.730
it says that I'm five levels deep.

104
00:05:12.730 --> 00:05:14.560
And that first level doesn't show up here.

105
00:05:14.560 --> 00:05:16.260
It's technically my TTY.

106
00:05:16.260 --> 00:05:19.792
So, if I would type Exit five times,
this whole thing's gonna close.

107
00:05:19.792 --> 00:05:22.060
Actually if I type it four times,
the whole thing's gonna close.

108
00:05:22.060 --> 00:05:23.890
So I don't even get all
the way to the end.

109
00:05:23.890 --> 00:05:29.430
But you can see how far deep you
are by doing that echo $SHLVL and

110
00:05:29.430 --> 00:05:32.560
for a normal user, for somebody who's
just doing stuff on the command line,

111
00:05:32.560 --> 00:05:34.300
we don't really care, right?

112
00:05:34.300 --> 00:05:36.633
It just matters if I'm in
a subshell at all, right?

113
00:05:36.633 --> 00:05:37.800
That's really all that matters.

114
00:05:39.550 --> 00:05:42.520
So even ps -forest is enough for us.

115
00:05:42.520 --> 00:05:45.080
But if you're writing a script,
you do care.

116
00:05:45.080 --> 00:05:47.860
You do want to know where
you're at in that level.

117
00:05:47.860 --> 00:05:54.470
Now, when I ran variable
three equals value three.

118
00:05:54.470 --> 00:05:57.380
That's my normal way of
setting a variable as local.

119
00:05:57.380 --> 00:05:59.090
I can make it global though.

120
00:05:59.090 --> 00:06:03.510
I can make it persist across all of my
different shelves, including sub-shelves.

121
00:06:03.510 --> 00:06:05.150
And we do that with the export command.

122
00:06:05.150 --> 00:06:09.157
If I type export bar three,
that takes variable 3 and

123
00:06:09.157 --> 00:06:14.110
it changes from a local variable,
into a global one, right?

124
00:06:14.110 --> 00:06:18.590
So now if I echo $var 3, there it is.

125
00:06:18.590 --> 00:06:23.880
And if I type bash again,
now I'm in a subshell, right?

126
00:06:23.880 --> 00:06:28.290
Oops, if I can type my command
there we go I'm in the sub shell.

127
00:06:28.290 --> 00:06:31.632
And if I echo $var 3, there it is, right?

128
00:06:31.632 --> 00:06:34.730
I've now made it move across my sessions.

129
00:06:34.730 --> 00:06:37.239
And so, if I'm going to be
running commands that spawn other

130
00:06:37.239 --> 00:06:40.489
commands this is really important in
order for these variables to be visible,

131
00:06:40.489 --> 00:06:42.081
for us to be able to see these, right?

132
00:06:42.081 --> 00:06:44.601
So that's the way that sub shell works and

133
00:06:44.601 --> 00:06:47.554
that's the way we can take
the local variable and

134
00:06:47.554 --> 00:06:52.179
turn it into a global variable, so
that it's then present in other places.

135
00:06:53.370 --> 00:06:55.350
Why is all this important, right?

136
00:06:55.350 --> 00:06:58.633
Daniel's giving me the look,
which you guys can't see.

137
00:06:58.633 --> 00:07:00.403
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's the,

138
00:07:00.403 --> 00:07:01.770
why are you telling us all this stuff?

139
00:07:01.770 --> 00:07:03.961
>> What are you talking about, Don Pezet?

140
00:07:03.961 --> 00:07:05.580
[LAUGH]
>> And the reason is,

141
00:07:05.580 --> 00:07:10.090
when you're setting things
inside of your bashrc file,

142
00:07:10.090 --> 00:07:13.930
you can do them as simple,
local variables, who cares, right?

143
00:07:13.930 --> 00:07:16.220
But it's gonna break your sub shell stuff.

144
00:07:16.220 --> 00:07:20.290
And if you set it in profiles.d
that's applying to all the users, and

145
00:07:20.290 --> 00:07:23.320
it's messed up all their sub shells, and
now everybody's gotta start tracking

146
00:07:23.320 --> 00:07:25.440
the shell level and
seeing where they're at or whatever.

147
00:07:25.440 --> 00:07:30.782
It's a mess, and so when you start posting
variables that way you wanna export them.

148
00:07:30.782 --> 00:07:34.242
Okay, now I showed you an example
here in two steps, right?

149
00:07:34.242 --> 00:07:41.082
I said var 4 equals value 4,
and then export var 4, right?

150
00:07:41.082 --> 00:07:43.928
But I could have done it all in one line,

151
00:07:43.928 --> 00:07:47.562
I could say export var 5 equals value 5,
right?

152
00:07:47.562 --> 00:07:50.769
That creates the variable,
populates the variable, and

153
00:07:50.769 --> 00:07:53.020
makes it global all in one line.

154
00:07:53.020 --> 00:07:58.270
And now, if I drop into a sub shell
I can echo dollar sign var five,

155
00:07:58.270 --> 00:08:02.090
and there it is, just like 4 or 3 or
any of the other ones that I've done.

156
00:08:02.090 --> 00:08:03.990
So I can do it all in one line, right?

157
00:08:03.990 --> 00:08:07.100
And that's what I wanted to do
at the end of the last episode.

158
00:08:07.100 --> 00:08:08.101
>> [LAUGH].
>> Before I realized

159
00:08:08.101 --> 00:08:09.542
I hadn't really explained why-
>> It happens.

160
00:08:09.542 --> 00:08:10.274
>> I wanted to do that in the first place.

161
00:08:10.274 --> 00:08:13.340
Yeah it's my habit it's kinda built in.

162
00:08:13.340 --> 00:08:18.850
When I modify things in /etc/profiles.d,

163
00:08:18.850 --> 00:08:22.970
I always do an export there, and
that's because I want those variables to

164
00:08:22.970 --> 00:08:25.170
be available in each of
the shells that we do.

165
00:08:25.170 --> 00:08:29.635
So if we go back to that,
so I'm gonna do a sudo by

166
00:08:29.635 --> 00:08:35.660
/etc/profile.d/, and then whatever
I wanna name this script, right?

167
00:08:35.660 --> 00:08:39.580
So I might call it custom.sh.

168
00:08:39.580 --> 00:08:42.540
And then I start putting in my variables.

169
00:08:42.540 --> 00:08:46.120
And you could do one variable in each
script and have a ton of scripts,

170
00:08:46.120 --> 00:08:46.830
that's fine.

171
00:08:46.830 --> 00:08:48.770
Or you could put all your
variables in one script.

172
00:08:48.770 --> 00:08:51.770
It doesn't really matter, the system's
gonna go through an run each one.

173
00:08:51.770 --> 00:08:57.242
So I could come in here and
I could say not just Var 1 equals value 1,

174
00:08:57.242 --> 00:09:02.138
I would wanna make sure I said
export var 1 equals value 1 and

175
00:09:02.138 --> 00:09:04.637
export var 2 equals value 2.

176
00:09:04.637 --> 00:09:07.868
And you can do the same
thing in your bashrc file.

177
00:09:07.868 --> 00:09:10.360
In your bashrc file it
doesn't really matter

178
00:09:10.360 --> 00:09:12.840
which one you do if you're
not using sub shells.

179
00:09:12.840 --> 00:09:15.545
Because It'll work inside your session.

180
00:09:15.545 --> 00:09:19.020
bashrc is loaded every time you run bash,
but

181
00:09:19.020 --> 00:09:22.320
this one,
this isn't run every time we run bash.

182
00:09:22.320 --> 00:09:24.210
This is part of our profile.

183
00:09:24.210 --> 00:09:25.290
And so that's different,.

184
00:09:25.290 --> 00:09:27.260
and that's why we want to make
sure that we do exports here, so

185
00:09:27.260 --> 00:09:28.790
it'll be present everywhere else.

186
00:09:28.790 --> 00:09:32.760
And you can just come through and
list whatever ones you want.

187
00:09:32.760 --> 00:09:35.090
Like Neil's shirt color.

188
00:09:35.090 --> 00:09:36.560
>> That's a very important variable.

189
00:09:36.560 --> 00:09:37.610
>> It really is.

190
00:09:37.610 --> 00:09:40.470
And so, we can [INAUDIBLE] this stuff and
now it'll be available.

191
00:09:40.470 --> 00:09:44.093
And because I'm putting it inside
a script inside of profiles.d,

192
00:09:44.093 --> 00:09:47.510
it's going to be there for every user.

193
00:09:47.510 --> 00:09:49.350
Every user will now be able to query this.

194
00:09:49.350 --> 00:09:52.040
Now, I'm actually
forgetting one extra thing,

00:02:29.491 --> 00:02:34.076

00:02:34.076 --> 00:02:34.815

00:14:24.030 --> 00:14:26.210
where they list all the file
systems they support.

314
00:14:26.210 --> 00:14:31.184
And in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.3 and
earlier, they had support for Btrfs.

315
00:14:31.184 --> 00:14:32.903
But it was flagged as preview, right,

316
00:14:32.903 --> 00:14:36.290
because they were trying to test it
to make sure it was stable enough.

317
00:14:36.290 --> 00:14:42.250
Well, starting in 7.4, Red Hat has
officially dropped support for Btrfs.

318
00:14:42.250 --> 00:14:44.610
Not even a preview anymore,
it's just gone.

319
00:14:44.610 --> 00:14:46.790
So when you come and
look at their supported file systems,

320
00:14:46.790 --> 00:14:49.698
it's not even in the list,
so it's just not there.

321
00:14:49.698 --> 00:14:51.740
You've got ext2, 3, and 4.

322
00:14:51.740 --> 00:14:54.210
You've got XFS that I've
already talked about.

323
00:14:54.210 --> 00:14:56.460
You got GFS,
which is the Gluster File System.

324
00:14:56.460 --> 00:14:59.165
That's designed for server clusters,
not for workstations.

325
00:14:59.165 --> 00:15:03.120
But those file systems,
those are the ones they support.

326
00:15:03.120 --> 00:15:07.342
Those are the ones where they can
guarantee data resiliency, all right?

327
00:15:07.342 --> 00:15:10.645
Btrfs is off, so
it's a very powerful file system.

328
00:15:10.645 --> 00:15:12.710
Btrfs has a ton of bells and whistles.

329
00:15:12.710 --> 00:15:13.435
It can do really cool stuff.

330
00:15:13.435 --> 00:15:15.160
It can create logical volumes.

331
00:15:15.160 --> 00:15:16.930
You can grow and shrink them.

332
00:15:16.930 --> 00:15:18.580
You can clone volumes.

333
00:15:18.580 --> 00:15:20.230
You can create multiple RAID arrays.

334
00:15:20.230 --> 00:15:23.500
You can do all sorts of really
cool stuff right inside of Btrfs.

335
00:15:23.500 --> 00:15:27.550
Very powerful, but it just needs more time
to mature and become more data stable.

336
00:15:27.550 --> 00:15:30.560
And once that happens,
I do believe that Btrfs is the future.

337
00:15:30.560 --> 00:15:33.286
I think we will all be running
Btrfs five years from now,

338
00:15:33.286 --> 00:15:35.152
maybe not two years from now, right?

339
00:15:35.152 --> 00:15:36.800
It's just gonna take time for
that to evolve, but

340
00:15:36.800 --> 00:15:38.520
it is another file
system that's out there.

341
00:15:38.520 --> 00:15:40.350
>> Well, Don,
what if I like living on the edge, man?

342
00:15:40.350 --> 00:15:45.040
I play the ponies, and
I download unstable [LAUGH] file systems.

343
00:15:45.040 --> 00:15:46.010
Can I still do that?

344
00:15:46.010 --> 00:15:49.767
>> Yeah, I mean, if you installed Ubuntu
today, or if you installed Debian today,

345
00:15:49.767 --> 00:15:52.064
in the installer,
you can choose Btrfs, right?

346
00:15:52.064 --> 00:15:55.731
If you install CentOS, they've actually
kept the driver in on theirs, and

347
00:15:55.731 --> 00:15:56.834
you can choose Btrfs.

348
00:15:56.834 --> 00:15:58.801
But if you install
Red Hat Enterprise Linux,

349
00:15:58.801 --> 00:16:00.417
it's not even an option in the list.

350
00:16:00.417 --> 00:16:04.619
And if you add it yourself, cuz you
can do that, if you add it yourself,

351
00:16:04.619 --> 00:16:06.390
Red Hat won't support you.

352
00:16:06.390 --> 00:16:08.700
If you call them on the phone and
you've got some problems on your disks,

353
00:16:08.700 --> 00:16:11.839
they'll look and they'll say, well you're
running VTRFS, what do you expect?

354
00:16:11.839 --> 00:16:13.038
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

355
00:16:13.038 --> 00:16:14.013
>> And so that's what you get.

356
00:16:14.013 --> 00:16:14.823
>> Bye [LAUGH].

357
00:16:14.823 --> 00:16:18.400
>> But that makes me think about
something else, speaking about support.

358
00:16:18.400 --> 00:16:20.808
When it comes to working
in these file systems,

359
00:16:20.808 --> 00:16:22.924
they all support a standard feature set.

360
00:16:22.924 --> 00:16:26.693
Things like file permissions, right, and
the path directory structure and all that.

361
00:16:26.693 --> 00:16:30.303
They all support that, but
there are some file systems that don't.

362
00:16:30.303 --> 00:16:35.740
So for example, if I format a disc as FAT,
the old Microsoft file allocation table.

363
00:16:35.740 --> 00:16:39.460
Every Linux distribution supports FAT
because we use it on SD cards and stuff.

364
00:16:39.460 --> 00:16:43.730
But if you format a file system as FAT,
it doesn't support file permissions.

365
00:16:43.730 --> 00:16:45.920
So you can't set permissions
on files anywhere.

366
00:16:45.920 --> 00:16:49.150
You can't set disk quotas on folders,
you lose that support.

367
00:16:49.150 --> 00:16:50.600
And it may be important, it may not.

368
00:16:50.600 --> 00:16:53.260
On an SD card, it's not really
important so, what do you care?

369
00:16:53.260 --> 00:16:56.200
But on your main hard drive, you do care.

370
00:16:56.200 --> 00:17:00.490
But where I find I'm impacted the most
are by the maximum file sizes.

371
00:17:00.490 --> 00:17:05.910
And so this page that I'm on here, let me
go back to this, what Red Hat is doing,

372
00:17:05.910 --> 00:17:09.320
is they're listing the certified and

373
00:17:09.320 --> 00:17:14.330
maximum file size and
file system size, okay?

374
00:17:14.330 --> 00:17:17.560
The file system means if
I create a partition,

375
00:17:17.560 --> 00:17:23.120
what's the biggest partition I can support
while using a particular file system?

376
00:17:23.120 --> 00:17:26.100
And if we look at this,
let me try and zoom in a bit here.

377
00:17:26.100 --> 00:17:29.991
But we've got EXT2, 3, and 4,
the top two, and XFS at the bottom.

378
00:17:29.991 --> 00:17:34.746
So if I look over here at the file system,
I can see that EXT2.

379
00:17:34.746 --> 00:17:39.080
You can do a 16TB partition with EXT2 or
3.

380
00:17:39.080 --> 00:17:43.820
Well, if I wanted more than 16TB,
I can't do that with EXT2 and 3.

381
00:17:43.820 --> 00:17:49.380
I'd have to go up to EXT4
where I could get 50TB.

382
00:17:49.380 --> 00:17:53.180
Now notice the little bracketed
number there, that 1EB right?

383
00:17:53.180 --> 00:17:57.725
That means that theoretically,
EXT4 can go all the way to 1EB for

384
00:17:57.725 --> 00:18:01.312
a single partition, but
Red Hat hasn't tested it.

385
00:18:01.312 --> 00:18:05.142
They haven't created a 1TB array and
run it through thorough testing,

386
00:18:05.142 --> 00:18:07.729
so they're saying we'll
support up to 50TB.

387
00:18:07.729 --> 00:18:11.416
And I encourage you guys, even if you
don't run Red Hat, if you run Ubuntu or

388
00:18:11.416 --> 00:18:12.440
whatever.

389
00:18:12.440 --> 00:18:15.250
Follow Red Hat's list here
because they've tested and

390
00:18:15.250 --> 00:18:18.920
certified that there's no data
loss up to this particular size.

391
00:18:18.920 --> 00:18:21.480
And if you look down to XFS,
it can go, well,

392
00:18:21.480 --> 00:18:26.300
they've tested to 500TB and
all the way up to 16EB.

393
00:18:26.300 --> 00:18:29.720
Really huge amount of
data there to be tested.

394
00:18:29.720 --> 00:18:35.150
Now back when BTRFS was
supported by Red Hat,

395
00:18:35.150 --> 00:18:38.770
they didn't have a certified number at
all, they just had the theoretical and

396
00:18:38.770 --> 00:18:40.630
the theoretical in it was 8EB.

397
00:18:40.630 --> 00:18:45.620
So very comparable to what we get
with XFS, but on the file size,

398
00:18:45.620 --> 00:18:48.170
that's where we're most
likely to run into an issue.

399
00:18:48.170 --> 00:18:53.517
Because when we're creating files,
it's not often that I have a 16TB drive.

400
00:18:53.517 --> 00:18:58.624
But I might have database that has
a file that's over 2TB in size.

401
00:18:58.624 --> 00:19:02.913
And if I've got EXT2 or 3,
2TB is the maximum size for a file.

402
00:19:02.913 --> 00:19:04.860
That database is gonna have some problems.

403
00:19:04.860 --> 00:19:07.460
All right, so if you're running
into an issue with files,

404
00:19:07.460 --> 00:19:09.190
you've might of exceeded that file size.

405
00:19:09.190 --> 00:19:12.800
On some of the older file formats
like FAT, this limit is like 2 gigs.

406
00:19:12.800 --> 00:19:16.130
It's really, really low and
we bump into that problem all the time.

407
00:19:16.130 --> 00:19:19.360
But with these file systems,
they support much larger sets of data.

408
00:19:19.360 --> 00:19:25.490
If you look at XFS, an individual file
can be 500TB or theoretically, 8EB.

409
00:19:25.490 --> 00:19:29.940
Same thing with BTRFS, they go up to 8EB
on a file, that's a huge amount of data.

410
00:19:29.940 --> 00:19:32.950
But if you find that you're
trying to copy a file and

411
00:19:32.950 --> 00:19:37.362
it's telling you there's not enough
disk space and you look and there is.

412
00:19:37.362 --> 00:19:40.738
It might be that the file itself
is actually bigger than the limit

413
00:19:40.738 --> 00:19:41.871
of that file system.

414
00:19:41.871 --> 00:19:42.712
And that happens, right?

415
00:19:42.712 --> 00:19:44.321
That's the kind of limitation,

416
00:19:44.321 --> 00:19:47.142
that's why we need to understand
what the file system is.

417
00:19:47.142 --> 00:19:49.478
We don't necessarily need
to change the file system,

418
00:19:49.478 --> 00:19:51.407
we just need to understand
the file system and

419
00:19:51.407 --> 00:19:54.840
say all right, I'm trying to do something
this file system doesn't support.

420
00:19:54.840 --> 00:19:56.550
So maybe I need to break that file up.

421
00:19:56.550 --> 00:20:00.664
Or maybe I do need to format it and
put this data on a different file system.

422
00:20:00.664 --> 00:20:03.257
So you can certainly go through that, but

423
00:20:03.257 --> 00:20:07.568
I didn't want to really delve into
the actual administrative side.

424
00:20:07.568 --> 00:20:10.499
[INAUDIBLE] More of an understanding
of that limitation.

425
00:20:10.499 --> 00:20:14.461
Because we're remoted into a cloud server
where the drives are already formatted or

426
00:20:14.461 --> 00:20:17.809
whatever, we need to understand those
limitations that we can operate

427
00:20:17.809 --> 00:20:18.612
inside of that.

428
00:20:18.612 --> 00:20:21.973
And as you work with a command line, you
will occasionally bump into these limits.

429
00:20:21.973 --> 00:20:25.400
>> All right, well Don, that's a really
great compare and contrast when it comes

430
00:20:25.400 --> 00:20:28.213
to the different file systems that
we might find in our systems and

431
00:20:28.213 --> 00:20:30.024
why I might wanna choose one or the other.

432
00:20:30.024 --> 00:20:30.618
And heck,

433
00:20:30.618 --> 00:20:34.715
how to find out what one I'm actually
running if I do wanna make that leap.

434
00:20:34.715 --> 00:20:37.715
Or if I'm running into problems
when trying to do something,

435
00:20:37.715 --> 00:20:40.031
maybe moving a file that's
a little too large.

436
00:20:40.031 --> 00:20:42.543
Don, anything else that you want to add
to the show before we call it a day?

437
00:20:42.543 --> 00:20:45.581
>> Yeah, if you're really interested
in learning about this and

438
00:20:45.581 --> 00:20:48.732
you want to learn more about how to
actually format a file system or

439
00:20:48.732 --> 00:20:51.043
how to work with some of
the advanced features.

440
00:20:51.043 --> 00:20:54.503
Check out our Linux Administrator show
because we actually go through and

441
00:20:54.503 --> 00:20:55.530
do this stuff there.

442
00:20:55.530 --> 00:20:58.225
Here in the command line show, I just
wanted to focus on what those differences

443
00:20:58.225 --> 00:21:01.470
were, but we do cover it in other shows,
so be sure to check it out there.

444
00:21:01.470 --> 00:21:06.290
And then as far as picking a final system,
I said I like XFS, but that's just me.

445
00:21:06.290 --> 00:21:07.520
And who the heck am I, right?

446
00:21:07.520 --> 00:21:12.455
So if you If you like BTRFS,
stick with it, if you like EXT4, great,

447
00:21:12.455 --> 00:21:13.625
stick with it.

448
00:21:13.625 --> 00:21:17.715
Only switch if there's actually some
particular tangible benefit and

449
00:21:17.715 --> 00:21:19.685
in my case,
the tangible benefit is support.

450
00:21:19.685 --> 00:21:22.555
I know the Red Hat has tested it,
and it makes me happy, right?

451
00:21:22.555 --> 00:21:25.205
If you don't care about that,
then that doesn't make you happy and

452
00:21:25.205 --> 00:21:26.115
there's no reason to go with it.

453
00:21:26.115 --> 00:21:30.273
So find the one that you like,
but don't pigeon hole yourself,

454
00:21:30.273 --> 00:21:31.900
I still learn about
the other file systems,

455
00:21:31.900 --> 00:21:34.950
cuz I know I need to know them in case
I encounter systems that I have that.

456
00:21:34.950 --> 00:21:36.370
And I don't necessarily
wanna do that change.

457
00:21:36.370 --> 00:21:37.870
>> All right, well, thanks so
much for your time and

458
00:21:37.870 --> 00:21:40.760
effort on this Don,
we definitely appreciate it.

459
00:21:40.760 --> 00:21:44.121
And we appreciate you good folks out
there for watching but unfortunately,

460
00:21:44.121 --> 00:21:46.075
it's that time for
us again to call it a day.

461
00:21:46.075 --> 00:21:47.932
>> [LAUGH]
>> Thanks for watching, join us back for

462
00:21:47.932 --> 00:21:49.710
more Linux command line coming up.

463
00:21:49.710 --> 00:21:51.630
As for this show goes, time to sign off.

464
00:21:51.630 --> 00:21:53.875
For ITProTV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

465
00:21:53.875 --> 00:21:54.535
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

466
00:21:54.535 --> 00:21:56.968
>> And we'll see you next time.

467
00:21:56.968 --> 00:22:02.131
[MUSIC]

468
00:22:02.131 --> 00:22:06.398
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how software is managed in Debian based systems (Ubuntu, Mint, etc). He demonstrates how to install, update and remove software using the apt and apt-get utilities.
episodes.title: Debian Package Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:04.082
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:04.082 --> 00:00:10.610
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:12.210 --> 00:00:14.045
>> All right, greetings everyone and

4
00:00:14.045 --> 00:00:16.687
welcome back to another
great episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:16.687 --> 00:00:20.230
I am your host Daniel Lowrie and in
today's episode, we're back with more in

6
00:00:20.230 --> 00:00:24.210
our Linux command line series and
it's been such a great time so far.

7
00:00:24.210 --> 00:00:27.230
Joining us back in the studio again,
he likes it so much, Mr. Don Pezet.

8
00:00:27.230 --> 00:00:28.395
He's here with us again today.

9
00:00:28.395 --> 00:00:29.390
Don, how's it going today?

10
00:00:29.390 --> 00:00:32.635
>> Well you just can't keep me away
from that Linux command line, so

11
00:00:32.635 --> 00:00:34.445
[LAUGH] we are back at it today.

12
00:00:34.445 --> 00:00:37.330
In this episode, we're gonna be
taking a look at package management

13
00:00:37.330 --> 00:00:39.850
which is a fancy way of
saying installing software.

14
00:00:39.850 --> 00:00:40.458
And-
>> [LAUGH]

15
00:00:40.458 --> 00:00:42.062
>> So, we're gonna take a look at

16
00:00:42.062 --> 00:00:45.911
the Debian operating system, or
the Debian variants that are out there.

17
00:00:45.911 --> 00:00:47.448
>> Mm.
>> And get a chance to see how we can

18
00:00:47.448 --> 00:00:50.720
install software on them, how we can work
with it, how we can remove software.

19
00:00:50.720 --> 00:00:53.450
And the various ways that we
get software packages up and

20
00:00:53.450 --> 00:00:55.070
running from the command line.

21
00:00:55.070 --> 00:00:56.892
>> All right, Don.
Well let's go ahead and,

22
00:00:56.892 --> 00:01:01.130
without further ado,
let's jump into Debian package management.

23
00:01:01.130 --> 00:01:03.761
Obviously, when we say to
be in package management,

24
00:01:03.761 --> 00:01:07.512
that means that this is some sort
of to be in type systems, correct?

25
00:01:07.512 --> 00:01:10.695
>> Yes, yeah, and
it used to be back in the day when half of

26
00:01:10.695 --> 00:01:13.346
the viewers [INAUDIBLE]
say that's awesome.

27
00:01:13.346 --> 00:01:14.880
I run Debian.
I love it, right?

28
00:01:14.880 --> 00:01:19.380
But today, actually,
not many people run straight up Debian.

29
00:01:19.380 --> 00:01:22.840
But they do run some of the variants
that come from it, right?

30
00:01:22.840 --> 00:01:28.080
Ubuntu, one of the most popular Linux
distros out there is a fork of Debian.

31
00:01:28.080 --> 00:01:33.300
So that they take Debian, the Deb fork of
it and then they turn that into Ubuntu.

32
00:01:33.300 --> 00:01:36.158
If you're on Linux Mint,
Linux Mint is a fork of Ubuntu.

33
00:01:36.158 --> 00:01:38.490
Which in turn is a fork of Debian.

34
00:01:38.490 --> 00:01:42.398
So they all kind of have Debian deep
down under their deep dark souls.

35
00:01:42.398 --> 00:01:45.139
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] And that means, fortunately,

36
00:01:45.139 --> 00:01:48.040
the way we manage packages
on them is the same.

37
00:01:48.040 --> 00:01:52.760
So if you're running Debian,
Linux Mint, Ubuntu, Kali Linux,

38
00:01:52.760 --> 00:01:56.320
a number of the other variants that are
out there, they all use the same package

39
00:01:56.320 --> 00:01:58.290
manager, and the stuff we're gonna
see right here in this episode.

40
00:01:58.290 --> 00:02:00.400
So while it's titled
Debian Package Management,

41
00:02:00.400 --> 00:02:02.510
it really applies to a lot
more distros than that.

42
00:02:02.510 --> 00:02:07.060
Now if you're running Red Hat or
Fedora or CentOS.

43
00:02:07.060 --> 00:02:07.956
They're all Red Hat based.

44
00:02:07.956 --> 00:02:09.950
They have a different package manager.

45
00:02:09.950 --> 00:02:13.304
So when you go out on the Internet and
you go to look for software,

46
00:02:13.304 --> 00:02:16.929
you might find where software is
packaged for Debian based systems.

47
00:02:16.929 --> 00:02:20.640
Or it's packaged for Red Hat based systems
or better, maybe it's packaged for both.

48
00:02:20.640 --> 00:02:22.700
But that's not always the case.

49
00:02:22.700 --> 00:02:27.115
Now, I think you'll find that
most software is packaged for

50
00:02:27.115 --> 00:02:29.910
Debian because of Ubuntu,
because of its popularity.

51
00:02:29.910 --> 00:02:33.159
So you're more likely to find that
than you are the Red Hat's side so

52
00:02:33.159 --> 00:02:35.667
if you're in this camp,
the camp for this episode,

53
00:02:35.667 --> 00:02:38.578
you're in luck because most
people are gonna build for you.

54
00:02:38.578 --> 00:02:41.639
And that package, let's talk about
why that's important, right?

55
00:02:41.639 --> 00:02:44.740
Because the package itself
does something important.

56
00:02:44.740 --> 00:02:47.700
We don't technically need
packages to install software.

57
00:02:47.700 --> 00:02:49.068
We just need source code, right?

58
00:02:49.068 --> 00:02:52.602
A developer can release the source code,
we could download it, and

59
00:02:52.602 --> 00:02:54.220
we could compile it and run it.

60
00:02:54.220 --> 00:02:56.250
And we'll see how to do
that in another episode.

61
00:02:56.250 --> 00:02:57.739
But we can do that on Red Hat or Debian.

62
00:02:57.739 --> 00:02:59.140
We wouldn't care what distro we were on.

63
00:02:59.140 --> 00:03:01.129
We could compile the source code.

64
00:03:01.129 --> 00:03:03.655
The problem is, first off,
it's pain in the butt.

65
00:03:03.655 --> 00:03:04.927
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

00:25:58.542 --> 00:25:59.166
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now,

516
00:25:59.166 --> 00:26:03.445
on a server, we're usually trying to
maintain the minimal footprint possible.

517
00:26:03.445 --> 00:26:05.966
And so when you get a suggested package,

518
00:26:05.966 --> 00:26:09.168
sometimes that's not
necessarily what you want.

519
00:26:09.168 --> 00:26:11.751
For example,
let's say that I'm on a server and

520
00:26:11.751 --> 00:26:13.519
let's see if this one will do it.

521
00:26:13.519 --> 00:26:14.347
I don't know if it will or not.

522
00:26:14.347 --> 00:26:17.971
This is actually an Ubuntu server that's
hosted in the Amazon Web Services and so

523
00:26:17.971 --> 00:26:19.903
they have a special deployment of Ubuntu.

524
00:26:19.903 --> 00:26:22.606
It's a little bit different, so
I'm not sure if it'll do it.

525
00:26:22.606 --> 00:26:26.760
But sometimes you'll see when you run a
command and it can't find the command and

526
00:26:26.760 --> 00:26:30.874
it says, if you want it, here's a quick
way you can install it and have it.

527
00:26:30.874 --> 00:26:32.793
I can do a sudo app install mc, right?

528
00:26:32.793 --> 00:26:35.626
And Midnight Commander's not installed,
here's how I can install it real quick.

529
00:26:35.626 --> 00:26:39.723
Now, that's kind of a suggestion or when
you install another software it might have

530
00:26:39.723 --> 00:26:43.552
all the packages that it needs and then
have additional ones that it suggests.

531
00:26:43.552 --> 00:26:48.388
In those scenarios, if you choose to
install them, it doesn't necessarily hurt

532
00:26:48.388 --> 00:26:52.746
you or hurt the application, but
it increases your security footprint.

533
00:26:52.746 --> 00:26:55.026
If I'm trying to maintain
a secure server and

534
00:26:55.026 --> 00:26:57.486
I see that Midnight Commander
is not installed,

535
00:26:57.486 --> 00:27:01.271
that's not a message to me saying,
I need to install Midnight Commander.

536
00:27:01.271 --> 00:27:04.813
It's a message to me saying, I just
need to find a different way to do this.

537
00:27:04.813 --> 00:27:08.031
I wanted to copy some files, so
I'll use cp cuz I know that's built in.

538
00:27:08.031 --> 00:27:08.654
>> Yeah.
>> I don't need

539
00:27:08.654 --> 00:27:09.498
Midnight Commander for that.

540
00:27:09.498 --> 00:27:13.587
I run into that with editors a lot
where you run nano and, well,

541
00:27:13.587 --> 00:27:15.423
that's installed, but-
>> [LAUGH]

542
00:27:15.423 --> 00:27:15.945
>> But it's not installed.

543
00:27:15.945 --> 00:27:20.200
All right, well, fine, I'll use vi or
vim or whatever, right?

544
00:27:20.200 --> 00:27:22.631
You try not to install things,
you install extra things.

545
00:27:22.631 --> 00:27:26.800
And what you'll find is that when you're
installing software, like with app-get.

546
00:27:26.800 --> 00:27:30.818
If I do man for apt-get,
it's got a ton of options and

547
00:27:30.818 --> 00:27:33.956
you can tell it not to pull dependencies.

548
00:27:33.956 --> 00:27:36.710
You can tell it not to
pull suggested packages.

549
00:27:36.710 --> 00:27:39.888
You can really configure and
get advanced with it.

550
00:27:39.888 --> 00:27:44.346
Usually, you just want to install the
minimum amount to get things working on

551
00:27:44.346 --> 00:27:45.290
a server.

552
00:27:45.290 --> 00:27:46.761
On a workstation you can
go a little bit further.

553
00:27:46.761 --> 00:27:48.223
>> Right.
>> And you know what,

554
00:27:48.223 --> 00:27:51.838
it's also worth mentioning,
Im doing apt-get here, right?

555
00:27:51.838 --> 00:27:52.592
>> Yeah.
>> Or apt.

556
00:27:52.592 --> 00:27:57.390
There are other utilities out there that
maybe available, for example, aptitude.

557
00:27:57.390 --> 00:27:59.318
Let me see if I got it here.

558
00:27:59.318 --> 00:28:00.633
Nope, but I can install it.

559
00:28:00.633 --> 00:28:01.218
>> Yeah.

560
00:28:01.218 --> 00:28:02.721
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

561
00:28:02.721 --> 00:28:04.279
let me install it cuz I just
kinda wanna show it to you.

562
00:28:04.279 --> 00:28:07.791
I don't use aptitude myself, but
I know that it is available and

563
00:28:07.791 --> 00:28:08.970
some people like it.

564
00:28:08.970 --> 00:28:09.625
>> I do, I'm using it.

565
00:28:09.625 --> 00:28:13.086
It's pretty convenient especially for
searching through things and

566
00:28:13.086 --> 00:28:14.087
looking for stuff.

567
00:28:14.087 --> 00:28:14.842
I like it.
>> Yeah,

568
00:28:14.842 --> 00:28:20.040
when you're working with the command line
you gotta remember the commands, but

569
00:28:20.040 --> 00:28:25.400
there's sometimes, I'm gonna call them
sudo GUI utilities or whatever that is.

570
00:28:25.400 --> 00:28:26.412
And-
>> As in PSE.

571
00:28:26.412 --> 00:28:27.144
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

572
00:28:27.144 --> 00:28:30.650
then a really graphically user
interface but it's kinda close.

573
00:28:30.650 --> 00:28:31.232
Aptitude is like that.

574
00:28:31.232 --> 00:28:37.590
If I pull up aptitude, here we go,
we get kind of a navigable menu.

575
00:28:37.590 --> 00:28:40.081
And I can come in and say,
let me look at my Installed Packages or

576
00:28:40.081 --> 00:28:42.438
let me look at Not Installed packages,
Virtual Packages.

577
00:28:42.438 --> 00:28:44.370
I'll go into Not Installed, right?

578
00:28:44.370 --> 00:28:45.971
And then it gives me categories.

579
00:28:45.971 --> 00:28:49.850
I wanna find, I don't know, http, right?

580
00:28:49.850 --> 00:28:51.212
I want webservers, right?

581
00:28:51.212 --> 00:28:54.540
And the number of packages
gets smaller and smaller.

582
00:28:54.540 --> 00:28:58.572
There were 50,000 packages a second ago,
there's only 44 in the webserver category.

583
00:28:58.572 --> 00:29:04.380
And I can go in there, and there's only
five in the main fully supported category.

584
00:29:04.380 --> 00:29:05.540
Meanwhile, it's 39 in universe.

585
00:29:05.540 --> 00:29:06.383
>> [LAUGH]
>> Just everything.

586
00:29:06.383 --> 00:29:08.936
I'm gonna go in main and now I can find.

587
00:29:08.936 --> 00:29:09.634
Here's apache.

588
00:29:09.634 --> 00:29:12.391
If I wanna install that and that's it.

589
00:29:12.391 --> 00:29:15.050
I figured light httpd would be there but
no.

590
00:29:15.050 --> 00:29:18.770
So I can find that though and
if I wanna install apache, there it is.

591
00:29:18.770 --> 00:29:22.970
I can choose that package and
we can go in and choose to install it.

592
00:29:22.970 --> 00:29:26.988
You'll see right now it's not installed
but I can install it if I wanted.

593
00:29:26.988 --> 00:29:30.310
Showing me the dependencies,
the information about the package.

594
00:29:30.310 --> 00:29:33.406
Read about it and then I can choose
to install it or update it or

595
00:29:33.406 --> 00:29:35.126
whatever if that's what I want.

596
00:29:35.126 --> 00:29:39.200
Up at the top it's giving me
the menu kinda commands, right?

597
00:29:39.200 --> 00:29:42.760
I could push g to preview, download,
install, or remove packages.

598
00:29:42.760 --> 00:29:46.330
So if I hit g, I haven't tagged this
one yet, so I would need to tag it.

599
00:29:46.330 --> 00:29:48.605
You gotta do a Ctrl + T and
then you come in.

600
00:29:48.605 --> 00:29:52.520
And it's got this whole kinda menu system
that you can use to be able to work

601
00:29:52.520 --> 00:29:53.164
with that.

602
00:29:53.164 --> 00:29:56.365
So I'm a little awkward in this
one because I don't use it much.

603
00:29:56.365 --> 00:29:57.770
Play Minesweeper?

604
00:29:57.770 --> 00:30:00.819
>> Where are you going?

605
00:30:00.819 --> 00:30:01.945
[LAUGH] That is very Minesweeper.

606
00:30:01.945 --> 00:30:03.098
>> My first pick I lost.

607
00:30:03.098 --> 00:30:04.124
So I had no idea what's in it.

608
00:30:04.124 --> 00:30:05.273
So-
>> That's great.

609
00:30:05.273 --> 00:30:08.451
>> Hey, this is a great example of
increasing your security footprint.

610
00:30:08.451 --> 00:30:09.468
>> That's right.
>> Right?

611
00:30:09.468 --> 00:30:12.266
I wanted to install an easy
package manager on a server.

612
00:30:12.266 --> 00:30:13.346
And I got Minesweeper.

613
00:30:13.346 --> 00:30:15.452
>> [LAUGH]
>> And that's not something we want.

614
00:30:15.452 --> 00:30:19.764
That's why we have to be careful about
what we install on a server, but

615
00:30:19.764 --> 00:30:24.236
otherwise, I guess now the real question
is how we get out of this thing?

616
00:30:24.236 --> 00:30:24.736
Q?
>> Q enough.

617
00:30:24.736 --> 00:30:25.320
>> And we'll get out, there we go.

618
00:30:25.320 --> 00:30:26.272
Apt-get is one example.

619
00:30:26.272 --> 00:30:28.361
If you got a GUI that's the whole software

620
00:30:28.361 --> 00:30:31.882
store that you use on there,
that's design to be simple but design for

621
00:30:31.882 --> 00:30:33.750
work stations not for servers.

622
00:30:33.750 --> 00:30:36.362
So don't feel like you've
only got one choice.

623
00:30:36.362 --> 00:30:40.630
The graphical one is actually called
Synaptic, is the GUI-based one.

624
00:30:40.630 --> 00:30:41.887
Aptitude is command line.

625
00:30:41.887 --> 00:30:44.270
There's Deselect,
is another one that's command line.

626
00:30:44.270 --> 00:30:45.506
I know some people like it.

627
00:30:45.506 --> 00:30:48.510
I just stick with what's built-in
because minimal foot print.

628
00:30:48.510 --> 00:30:49.801
That's what I normally think, right?

629
00:30:49.801 --> 00:30:52.410
So apt-get or just apt by itself.

630
00:30:52.410 --> 00:30:52.949
Those are available.
And

631
00:30:52.949 --> 00:30:57.240
there's also another utility called
apt-cache, which is a kind of handy one.

632
00:30:57.240 --> 00:30:59.223
With apt-get you could search for
packages.

633
00:30:59.223 --> 00:31:03.381
With the newer apt, you're supposed to
search with apt-cache cuz you cache this

634
00:31:03.381 --> 00:31:07.615
list of packages and you can just search
locally, so it's faster and more robust.

635
00:31:07.615 --> 00:31:10.043
So there's new tools like that
that are coming off all the time.

636
00:31:10.043 --> 00:31:14.595
But as far as getting software installed,
that's really all there is to it.

637
00:31:14.595 --> 00:31:17.616
If it's already in a repo then
you're just doing apt, install, and

638
00:31:17.616 --> 00:31:18.772
the name of the software.

639
00:31:18.772 --> 00:31:22.860
If it's not in the repo, you can download
the package and install it individually.

640
00:31:22.860 --> 00:31:26.704
Or if that developer has a repo, hopefully
they do, you could add it to the list and

641
00:31:26.704 --> 00:31:29.292
now anytime you do updates,
that'll update as well.

642
00:31:29.292 --> 00:31:33.550
Installing from a repository is always
the best if you have the choice.

643
00:31:33.550 --> 00:31:34.170
>> Excellent stuff, Don.

644
00:31:34.170 --> 00:31:36.617
Because when it comes to software,

645
00:31:36.617 --> 00:31:42.010
installation has been one of the more
difficult things for the new Linux user.

646
00:31:42.010 --> 00:31:45.981
So, being able to easily download, install
software onto their system is really

647
00:31:45.981 --> 00:31:48.871
gonna help a lot of people that
are new to the Linux's game.

648
00:31:48.871 --> 00:31:53.571
I think you did a great job of showing
us how we can actually do that without

649
00:31:53.571 --> 00:31:55.278
making it so convoluted.

650
00:31:55.278 --> 00:31:56.808
>> [LAUGH]
>> It makes you just run for

651
00:31:56.808 --> 00:31:58.685
the nearest Windows system.

652
00:31:58.685 --> 00:32:01.814
[LAUGH] So anything else you like to add
to the segment before we close it down?

653
00:32:01.814 --> 00:32:02.587
>> That's really about it.

654
00:32:02.587 --> 00:32:06.900
There are a few other package managers
that are always on the horizon.

655
00:32:06.900 --> 00:32:11.616
I encourage you not to jump to the latest
shiny package manager that comes along cuz

656
00:32:11.616 --> 00:32:14.500
a lot of them do have
dependency tracking issues.

657
00:32:14.500 --> 00:32:17.020
They get better and more robust over time.

658
00:32:17.020 --> 00:32:19.559
If your package manager makes a mistake,
it can break software and

659
00:32:19.559 --> 00:32:20.884
it can be very difficult to fix it.

660
00:32:20.884 --> 00:32:23.797
So, I encourage you to stick
with the tried and true ones,

661
00:32:23.797 --> 00:32:27.423
like all the ones I mentioned on the show
today those are all very stable,

662
00:32:27.423 --> 00:32:31.585
mature ones that are available and welcome
to be used, but if you hear about some new

663
00:32:31.585 --> 00:32:35.240
shiny one on the Internet,
maybe I'll try that one instead.

664
00:32:35.240 --> 00:32:37.700
Just be really careful,
don't do that on production systems.

665
00:32:37.700 --> 00:32:40.300
Packages aren't something
you want to mess up.

666
00:32:40.300 --> 00:32:41.500
>> All right.
Well, there you go, everyone.

667
00:32:41.500 --> 00:32:45.617
Now you know how to run out and install
software on your Debian-based systems if

668
00:32:45.617 --> 00:32:48.752
you're running Ubuntu or
anything like that, Linux Mint,

669
00:32:48.752 --> 00:32:51.596
you can with confidence get
some software installed.

670
00:32:51.596 --> 00:32:54.515
That Minesweepers' calling your name,
I know that for a fact.

671
00:32:54.515 --> 00:32:55.925
>> [LAUGH]
>> Don, thanks for joining us today and

672
00:32:55.925 --> 00:32:57.435
we do thank our audience for watching.

673
00:32:57.435 --> 00:32:59.946
Well, it looks like it's that time
again for us to call it a day.

674
00:32:59.946 --> 00:33:03.410
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

675
00:33:03.410 --> 00:33:03.965
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

676
00:33:03.965 --> 00:33:04.639
>> And we'll see you next time.

677
00:33:04.639 --> 00:33:12.475
[MUSIC]

678
00:33:12.475 --> 00:33:15.396

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how software is managed in Redhat based systems (CentOS, Fedora, etc). He demonstrates how to install, update and remove software using the yum and dnf utilities.
episodes.title: Redhat Package Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.092 --> 00:00:02.269
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.269 --> 00:00:08.284
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.284 --> 00:00:12.003
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.003 --> 00:00:13.860
>> All right, greetings to everyone, and

5
00:00:13.860 --> 00:00:16.380
welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:16.380 --> 00:00:20.460
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and in today's
episode, we're back with more in our Linux

7
00:00:20.460 --> 00:00:25.250
command line series and joining us in
the studio, you know him as Don Pezet.

8
00:00:25.250 --> 00:00:28.050
But he's our good friend,
mentor in this endeavor.

9
00:00:28.050 --> 00:00:29.400
How's it going today, Don?

10
00:00:29.400 --> 00:00:30.440
Glad to have you again, sir.

11
00:00:30.440 --> 00:00:33.360
>> Well I'm ready to dive right back
in to the world of Linux command line.

12
00:00:33.360 --> 00:00:36.220
And in this episode we're
gonna be taking a look at

13
00:00:36.220 --> 00:00:40.100
Installing software on Red Hat
based systems or RPM based systems.

14
00:00:40.100 --> 00:00:42.330
So we'll see some of the utilities
we can use to install it.

15
00:00:42.330 --> 00:00:43.830
What's involved with that process and

16
00:00:43.830 --> 00:00:47.420
some of the kind of best practices as far
as how we get that software in there and

17
00:00:47.420 --> 00:00:50.870
ultimately get it out if we need to,
all right here in this episode.

18
00:00:50.870 --> 00:00:54.948
>> So we took a look at Debian
packages in our previous episode.

19
00:00:54.948 --> 00:00:59.412
This is kinda like the same thing, right,
it allows you to, be able to install

20
00:00:59.412 --> 00:01:03.694
software as a package instead of having
to run around finding everything.

21
00:01:03.694 --> 00:01:07.540
How is it different should I say
is what I'm trying to get to.

22
00:01:07.540 --> 00:01:10.833
>> All right, well in the last episode we
talked about those Debian packages and

23
00:01:10.833 --> 00:01:14.076
I said how the advantage of a package
is that when you download software it's

24
00:01:14.076 --> 00:01:16.018
usually on more than one component, right.

25
00:01:16.018 --> 00:01:20.290
So you've got binaries, and manpages,
and libraries and all this stuff.

26
00:01:20.290 --> 00:01:21.760
And if you had to install it manually,

27
00:01:21.760 --> 00:01:23.340
you'd have to know where
all that stuff went.

28
00:01:23.340 --> 00:01:25.750
You'd have to copy the right
files to the right locations and

29
00:01:25.750 --> 00:01:28.130
if you get even one wrong,
the whole thing breaks.

30
00:01:28.130 --> 00:01:29.890
It's a bit of a nightmare, right, so

31
00:01:29.890 --> 00:01:35.145
the purpose of a package file is to
contain not just the finals that we need,

32
00:01:35.145 --> 00:01:38.775
but information about what to do
with the finals, where to put them.

33
00:01:38.775 --> 00:01:42.125
Where does the manpage go,
where do the libraries go,

34
00:01:42.125 --> 00:01:45.505
what permissions need to be set for
these things to execute right.

35
00:01:45.505 --> 00:01:46.873
That's called metadata.

36
00:01:46.873 --> 00:01:48.992
And the metadata that's
part of the package has it,

37
00:01:48.992 --> 00:01:52.430
it's basically an instruction sheet that
says here's what to do to do the install.

38
00:01:52.430 --> 00:01:57.607
Well, in the Debian episode we did
the .deb packages which were developed for

39
00:01:57.607 --> 00:01:59.230
Debian.

40
00:01:59.230 --> 00:02:02.920
And those are effective but
they store their metadata a certain way.

41
00:02:02.920 --> 00:02:04.800
In the Red Hat world we use RPM.

42
00:02:06.040 --> 00:02:08.320
RPM is the Red Hat Package Manager.

43
00:02:08.320 --> 00:02:12.050
And RPM packages have the same
files in them, the same libraries,

44
00:02:12.050 --> 00:02:13.400
the same binaries.

45
00:02:13.400 --> 00:02:16.180
But the metadata is stored
in a different format and so

46
00:02:16.180 --> 00:02:17.920
they're not compatible with each other.

47
00:02:17.920 --> 00:02:21.449
There's actually two things that break
compatibility one is the metadata format,

48
00:02:21.449 --> 00:02:22.849
which by and large, is just XML.

49
00:02:22.849 --> 00:02:25.625
But they use different names for
things for whatever reason, right.

50
00:02:25.625 --> 00:02:29.757
The other thing is that in the Red Hat
world they use cpio compression,

51
00:02:29.757 --> 00:02:34.055
which is different than in the Debian
world where they use just use gzip.

52
00:02:34.055 --> 00:02:36.125
So it's two different
compression types too,

53
00:02:36.125 --> 00:02:39.815
and your software has to expect that to
know how to work within that environment.

54
00:02:39.815 --> 00:02:42.285
So Red Hat packages are just
fundamentally different,

55
00:02:42.285 --> 00:02:47.085
but inside of them it technically is
the same data as far as that application.

56
00:02:47.085 --> 00:02:49.000
Which is a different instruction set.

57
00:02:49.000 --> 00:02:51.290
So when we go and
download one of these packages and

58
00:02:51.290 --> 00:02:54.000
install with it, we get all the benefits
we did from the Debian world.

59
00:02:54.000 --> 00:02:57.509
We get all the files we need, we get
the information on where they go and

60
00:02:57.509 --> 00:03:00.319
we get information on their
associated dependencies.

61

00:26:27.402 --> 00:26:29.720
And they tell you all about EPEL and
what it is.

497
00:26:29.720 --> 00:26:32.810
If you're using Fedora,
you've likely already got it.

498
00:26:32.810 --> 00:26:34.010
If you're CentOS,

499
00:26:34.010 --> 00:26:38.465
you can install it pretty easy, on RedHat
it's actually not so easy to install it.

500
00:26:38.465 --> 00:26:42.256
>> [LAUGH]
>> On CentOS, all you would do let's say

00:26:42.256 --> 00:26:50.190
yum, sudo, yum install EPEL dash release,
that command right there, all right?

502
00:26:50.190 --> 00:26:55.220
And on CentOS,
they actually have an EPEL repo package

503
00:26:55.220 --> 00:26:58.440
in the normal repo, right,
but you choose to install it.

504
00:26:58.440 --> 00:26:59.090
And when you run that,

505
00:26:59.090 --> 00:27:00.330
it gets it installed
>> But

506

00:27:10.220 --> 00:27:13.540

510
00:27:13.540 --> 00:27:15.860
There's a link in here somewhere
that says like, how do I use it.

511
00:27:15.860 --> 00:27:19.300
Not how do I contribute, but here,
how can I use these packages?

512
00:27:19.300 --> 00:27:20.970
And they give a link to pull.

513
00:27:20.970 --> 00:27:24.090
So I'm running Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7,
or at least I think I am.

514
00:27:24.090 --> 00:27:25.140
Let's find out.

515
00:27:25.140 --> 00:27:27.680
I will do a host, hostname.

516
00:27:27.680 --> 00:27:28.430
All right?

>> No you won't.

>> hostnamectl, there we go.

519
00:27:31.410 --> 00:27:33.576
So I am running
Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.4.

520
00:27:33.576 --> 00:27:36.720
So on the EPEL website, I can come in and

521
00:27:36.720 --> 00:27:40.930
find the newest version of
EPEL release for EL 7, right?

522
00:27:40.930 --> 00:27:42.070
That's what I want.

523
00:27:42.070 --> 00:27:46.780
And you can just copy that link and
then back on your server,

524
00:27:46.780 --> 00:27:50.020
you can say, sudo yum install and
paste that in.

525
00:27:50.020 --> 00:27:55.337
And it's gonna reach out and
grab that EPEL release package, right?

526
00:27:55.337 --> 00:27:55.926
>> Space between.

527
00:27:55.926 --> 00:27:56.508
>> There.
>> Did I spell it wrong?

528
00:27:56.508 --> 00:27:58.472
>> There's a space between.
>> Space, there we go.

529
00:27:58.472 --> 00:28:01.000
So it'll install it.

530
00:28:01.000 --> 00:28:03.830
And what it's really doing
is not installing software,

531
00:28:03.830 --> 00:28:06.600
just adding that file.

532
00:28:06.600 --> 00:28:12.450
If I go into \etc\yum.repos.d\ and look,

533
00:28:12.450 --> 00:28:17.440
you'll see where it's added epel.repo and
epel-testing.repo and

534
00:28:17.440 --> 00:28:20.485
that one's dangerous,
let me tell you it's not quite safe.

535
00:28:20.485 --> 00:28:25.430
>> [LAUGH]
>> And if I look at that file, if I If I

536
00:28:25.430 --> 00:28:30.120
pull up the EPEL testing,
one sales got enabled equals zero.

537
00:28:30.120 --> 00:28:31.550
It's not turned on.

538
00:28:31.550 --> 00:28:32.680
So I don't have to worry about.

539
00:28:32.680 --> 00:28:35.120
I could turn on if I wanted but
it's turned off by default.

540
00:28:35.120 --> 00:28:38.340
Versus if I just look at epel.repo,
that one is, actually,

541
00:28:38.340 --> 00:28:42.240
it was not turned on either by default.

542
00:28:42.240 --> 00:28:43.879
Wait, that's EPEL source.

543
00:28:43.879 --> 00:28:45.450
Where's actual, up here.

544
00:28:45.450 --> 00:28:45.990
There we go.

545
00:28:45.990 --> 00:28:46.890
They're full on EPEL.

546
00:28:46.890 --> 00:28:47.986
That one right there.

547
00:28:47.986 --> 00:28:49.066
Enabled equals one.

548
00:28:49.066 --> 00:28:52.320
And so now there might be
some software that I want.

549
00:28:52.320 --> 00:28:55.770
It's not in the normal repo and
now I can go in and find it.

550
00:28:55.770 --> 00:29:00.760
So the Guake terminal that I used,
I don't think that's in the normal repo.

551
00:29:00.760 --> 00:29:05.253
But now if I come in and I do a yum list,
sudo that, it'll go out on a look, and

552
00:29:05.253 --> 00:29:10.062
it's looking not just in the regular
repositories but it's also looking EPEL.

553
00:29:10.062 --> 00:29:13.696
So there's Guake, and
if I look way over here on the right,

554
00:29:13.696 --> 00:29:16.310
it found it in the EPEL repository.

555
00:29:16.310 --> 00:29:18.320
Red Hat doesn't officially support Guake.

556
00:29:18.320 --> 00:29:19.395
Worked fine, though.

557
00:29:19.395 --> 00:29:20.630
>> [LAUGH]
>> And I can get it from EPEL.

558
00:29:20.630 --> 00:29:22.160
So you'll see people talk about that.

559
00:29:22.160 --> 00:29:23.740
That's a third-party repository.

560
00:29:23.740 --> 00:29:26.570
And if you trust them, great.

561
00:29:26.570 --> 00:29:29.800
But some of them are pretty
dodgy that are out there.

562
00:29:29.800 --> 00:29:33.340
I know a lot of people like RPMForge,
and I don't trust them one single bit.

563
00:29:33.340 --> 00:29:37.270
But there's various repositories out
there that you may trust or not.

564
00:29:37.270 --> 00:29:39.440
And you can set up your own repo too.

565
00:29:39.440 --> 00:29:42.750
Maybe you have your own in
house developed software.

566
00:29:42.750 --> 00:29:44.090
You can create your own repository and

567
00:29:44.090 --> 00:29:47.200
point your servers to it and you can
distribute your own software that way.

568
00:29:47.200 --> 00:29:50.360
Or limited versions of public
softwares that you do trust.

569
00:29:50.360 --> 00:29:53.640
Maybe I don't want the whole EPEL,
I just wanna a couple of packages from it.

570
00:29:53.640 --> 00:29:55.090
So I can maintain my own repository.

571
00:29:55.090 --> 00:29:58.452
There is a lot of power that you can
get when you mess with repositories.

572
00:29:58.452 --> 00:30:01.310
>> Don, this is super cool stuff,
being able to manage

573
00:30:01.310 --> 00:30:04.650
our software on our systems is
a very important thing obviously.

574
00:30:04.650 --> 00:30:08.280
Cuz if we can't get tools installed to
do work that we need to get done, well,

575
00:30:08.280 --> 00:30:10.690
then we're gonna have a bad day at work,
that's for sure.

576
00:30:10.690 --> 00:30:11.700
And someone's gonna be looking for

577
00:30:11.700 --> 00:30:13.375
somebody that does know
how to get that happening.

578
00:30:13.375 --> 00:30:14.160
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now, Don,

579
00:30:14.160 --> 00:30:17.860
I think you've done a masterful job
of showing us how we can use yum and

580
00:30:17.860 --> 00:30:21.810
RPM and working with the repositories
inside a Red Hat based systems,

581
00:30:21.810 --> 00:30:25.570
very very cool stuff and
even learned a few things myself today.

582
00:30:25.570 --> 00:30:28.360
Very very cool, Don thanks for
joining us today, I appreciate it for

583
00:30:28.360 --> 00:30:29.150
you showing up today.

584
00:30:29.150 --> 00:30:31.250
I also appreciate our audience for
watching.

585
00:30:31.250 --> 00:30:34.630
I know we thoroughly appreciate
our audience everyday,

586
00:30:34.630 --> 00:30:36.450
as you guys are what make
the magic happen here.

587
00:30:36.450 --> 00:30:39.840
But it does look like we're
out of time for this episode.

588
00:30:39.840 --> 00:30:43.640
Don't worry though, we have plenty of
other shows going on if not this one,

I don't know if we're continuing on,
but signing off for

00:30:47.150 --> 00:30:49.660
ITProTV, I've been your

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how not every application is provided in a nice package. He then demonstrates how you can build software from the original source code. He also explains some scenarios where you may chose to build from source even when a package is available.
episodes.title: Installing from Source
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:00.894
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:00.894 --> 00:00:02.558
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.558 --> 00:00:06.397
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.397 --> 00:00:08.158
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.158 --> 00:00:12.165
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.165 --> 00:00:13.495
>> All right greetings everyone.

7
00:00:13.495 --> 00:00:16.465
We wanna welcome back to another
great episode of ITProTV.

8
00:00:16.465 --> 00:00:19.605
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie, and
in today's episode, we're back with more

9
00:00:19.605 --> 00:00:22.556
in our Linux Command Line series, and
of course, joining us in the studio,

10
00:00:22.556 --> 00:00:25.602
it would be like a day without sunshine
if we didn't have our good friend, Mr.

11
00:00:25.602 --> 00:00:26.966
Don Pezet joining us today again.

12
00:00:26.966 --> 00:00:28.015
Don, how's it going, man?

13
00:00:28.015 --> 00:00:29.204
>> It is going just swell, and

14
00:00:29.204 --> 00:00:31.595
we're diving right back into
the Linux command line.

15
00:00:31.595 --> 00:00:32.603
In this episode,

16
00:00:32.603 --> 00:00:37.121
we're gonna be taking a look at how to
Install an application from source code.

17
00:00:37.121 --> 00:00:38.610
>> [LAUGH]
>> Basically building an app.

18
00:00:38.610 --> 00:00:40.275
I like to say building it from scratch,
but

19
00:00:40.275 --> 00:00:42.091
you're not really
building it from scratch.

20
00:00:42.091 --> 00:00:42.630
Somebody else has already made that thing.

21
00:00:42.630 --> 00:00:44.597
[LAUGH]
>> We're programming the entire

22
00:00:44.597 --> 00:00:45.301
[LAUGH] thing.

23
00:00:45.301 --> 00:00:46.334
No.
>> We just need to make it work.

24
00:00:46.334 --> 00:00:46.920
>> Yeah.
>> So

25
00:00:46.920 --> 00:00:48.851
in this episode that's
what we're gonna do.

26
00:00:48.851 --> 00:00:51.760
No package managers,
no automated installers.

27
00:00:51.760 --> 00:00:54.824
We're gonna get source code, turn it into
a working application, get it up and

28
00:00:54.824 --> 00:00:57.520
running, and we're gonna do it
all right here in this episode.

29
00:00:57.520 --> 00:00:59.799
>> All right,
well it sounds like a lot of fun Don, but

30
00:00:59.799 --> 00:01:03.297
if anybody has worked with Linux, for
any length of time, when someone starts

31
00:01:03.297 --> 00:01:06.814
talking about installing from source,
you probably get a couple of kickbox.

32
00:01:06.814 --> 00:01:09.398
A, why don't you just use one of
the package management systems?

33
00:01:09.398 --> 00:01:11.970
>> [LAUGH]
>> They seem to work quite well, and

34
00:01:11.970 --> 00:01:14.880
that's the facto and
default way to do things.

35
00:01:14.880 --> 00:01:18.770
So Don, what would be the advantage,
why would we want to do it this way,

36
00:01:18.770 --> 00:01:21.155
especially since most people find
this to be kind of difficult?

37
00:01:21.155 --> 00:01:23.700
>> Yeah, as a routine matter of course,

38
00:01:23.700 --> 00:01:26.410
I generally don't like to install
from source, if I can avoid it.

39
00:01:26.410 --> 00:01:29.426
So if there is a package,
if there is an RPM, or a DEB, or

40
00:01:29.426 --> 00:01:33.927
whatever that's available for me to
download, that software's already built,

41
00:01:33.927 --> 00:01:36.946
and it makes it a heck of a lot
easier to get it installed,

42
00:01:36.946 --> 00:01:39.745
and so that's the better
way to do it in most cases.

43
00:01:39.745 --> 00:01:43.122
But there are times when we
don't really have a choice.

44
00:01:43.122 --> 00:01:46.062
That choice is taken away from us,
or there's times where we might have

45
00:01:46.062 --> 00:01:48.510
a legitimate reason from wanting to,
from source.

46
00:01:48.510 --> 00:01:50.730
So let me run through a couple of reasons.

47
00:01:50.730 --> 00:01:53.400
One, there might not
be packages available.

48
00:01:53.400 --> 00:01:57.312
There might be some software that I want
to install, but there's no RPM, there's no

49
00:01:57.312 --> 00:02:01.603
dev, there's no prebuilt package
available, all there is a source code.

50
00:02:01.603 --> 00:02:04.960
So if I wanna run it, I don't have a
choice, I've got to build it from source,

51
00:02:04.960 --> 00:02:06.150
that's one reason.

52
00:02:06.150 --> 00:02:11.656
Another reason is, maybe it's really
sensitive software, and you don't trust

53
00:02:11.656 --> 00:02:17.496
the people that built it, and that's not a
bad thing, we should trust no one, right?

54
00:02:17.496 --> 00:02:18.581
What was it, the Xbox.

55
00:02:18.581 --> 00:02:21.645
[LAUGH] We might be like that.

56
00:02:21.645 --> 00:02:23.742
If you're in a high security environment,

57
00:02:23.742 --> 00:02:26.520
you might require code
review of an application.

58
00:02:26.520 --> 00:02:30.270
I got to review the code, well even
if I review the code, if I'm using

59
00:02:30.270 --> 00:02:35.200
a precompiled binary, who's to say it
was built from the same code I reviewed.

60
00:02:35.200 --> 00:02:39.670
So if you wanna be absolutely certain, you
download the source code, you review it.

61
00:02:39.670 --> 00:02:42.723
You look for back doors or
other security weaknesses.

62
00:02:42.723 --> 00:02:44.908
When you're confident everything's fine,

63
00:02:44.908 --> 00:02:48.212
you can then compile the software
yourself from that source code, and

64
00:02:48.212 --> 00:02:50.970
now you know that it's safe,
it works the way you want it.

65
00:02:50.970 --> 00:02:52.750
So that's another reason
why I might do it.

66
00:02:52.750 --> 00:02:56.253
But both of those are not
necessarily the greatest reasons.

67
00:02:56.253 --> 00:02:58.348
Well I mean,
if you're in the security world.

68
00:02:58.348 --> 00:02:58.980
>> Yeah [LAUGH].

69
00:02:58.980 --> 00:02:59.770
>> That one's pretty good.

70
00:02:59.770 --> 00:03:04.215
But one of the reasons, for me, where I
will sometimes build software from source,

71
00:03:04.215 --> 00:03:08.050
is because sometimes it can optimized for
your hardware architecture.

72
00:03:08.050 --> 00:03:11.596
When a developer makes a package
that package file has to

73
00:03:11.596 --> 00:03:14.549
cater to like the lowest
common denominator.

74
00:03:14.549 --> 00:03:18.508
So when they precompile a binary
they don't know if you're

75
00:03:18.508 --> 00:03:23.506
gonna be running it on a system with
an Intel processor or an AMD processor.

76
00:03:23.506 --> 00:03:28.422
They don't know if you're gonna be on
an Intel Xeon, with, 30 MB of L2 cache,

77
00:03:28.422 --> 00:03:29.726
or 32, whatever.

78
00:03:29.726 --> 00:03:32.251
>> [LAUGH]
>> Or if you're running on an old Athlon

79
00:03:32.251 --> 00:03:36.620
with only 1 MB of L2 cache, they don't
know what hardware you're gonna run.

80
00:03:36.620 --> 00:03:40.360
So they create a generic binary,
that'll run on as many

81
00:03:40.360 --> 00:03:44.140
hardware architectures as possible,
within usually single architecture.

82
00:03:44.140 --> 00:03:47.087
Now, If we want to really take
advantage of the bells and

83
00:03:47.087 --> 00:03:50.663
whistles in our processor,
if we're doing like video and coding,

84
00:03:50.663 --> 00:03:53.424
our processor might have
accelerators in their, or

85
00:03:53.424 --> 00:03:57.714
with encryption, a lot of processors have
AES acceleration built into the CPU.

86
00:03:57.714 --> 00:04:01.814
Well, if we wanna take advantage of that,
we can get the source code, and

87
00:04:01.814 --> 00:04:06.181
we could compile it ourselves, and
we can use compile options to enable that,

88
00:04:06.181 --> 00:04:07.460
they call them flags.

89
00:04:07.460 --> 00:04:11.170
We can do these flags to enable these
features because we know we have them.

90
00:04:11.170 --> 00:04:13.760
Who cares if the other
customers don't have it, we do.

91
00:04:13.760 --> 00:04:15.238
So let's take advantage of those features.

92
00:04:15.238 --> 00:04:18.692
So sometimes when you
compile software from code,

93
00:04:18.692 --> 00:04:21.353
you actually get better performance.

94
00:04:21.353 --> 00:04:24.183
It takes better advantage of
the hardware resources that you've got,

95
00:04:24.183 --> 00:04:27.056
because it was built right on the machine
that you intend to run it on, and

96
00:04:27.056 --> 00:04:28.540
it's able to see all that hardware.

97
00:04:28.540 --> 00:04:30.900
>> Well Don, if it's so
awesome do to it that way,

98
00:04:30.900 --> 00:04:33.030
why aren't we doing everything this way?

99
00:04:33.030 --> 00:04:34.755
>> Cuz it's a pain in the butt.

100
00:04:34.755 --> 00:04:36.732
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] You know it used to be

101
00:04:36.732 --> 00:04:37.634
a nightmare.

102
00:04:37.634 --> 00:04:40.828
It used to be an absolute nightmare
that you'd get the source code,

103
00:04:40.828 --> 00:04:43.079
and it wasn't good enough
right out of the box.

104
00:04:43.079 --> 00:04:45.936
You had to go through, and
edit lines inside the code,

105
00:04:45.936 --> 00:04:47.815
and change it to match your system.

106
00:04:47.815 --> 00:04:51.360
You had to put in a bunch of paths, and
other things, that made it really just

107
00:04:51.360 --> 00:04:54.920
extremely difficult, and I remember back
in the old days like building a custom

108
00:04:54.920 --> 00:04:58.090
kernel and stuff, it was an all
day process, it took a long time.

109
00:04:58.090 --> 00:04:59.263
>> Scariest environment imaginable.

110
00:04:59.263 --> 00:04:59.879
That's all you had to say.

111
00:04:59.879 --> 00:05:01.783
>> That's all you had to say.
>> [LAUGH]

112
00:05:01.783 --> 00:05:03.086
>> But what you'll see in this episode

113
00:05:03.086 --> 00:05:04.440
is that it's not like that anymore.

114
00:05:04.440 --> 00:05:08.642
That there's a lot of utilities that are
available that make it super simple for

115
00:05:08.642 --> 00:05:11.286
us to be able to compile this and
get things going.

116
00:05:11.286 --> 00:05:13.203
So that's a really big help, but

117
00:05:13.203 --> 00:05:16.500
the main reason we don't want
to do this is it's harder.

118
00:05:16.500 --> 00:05:18.940
It's harder than just getting
a package and installing it.

119
00:05:18.940 --> 00:05:20.950
But, there's other negatives as well.

120
00:05:20.950 --> 00:05:22.740
If I install with a package,

121
00:05:22.740 --> 00:05:26.090
a lot of times I can use a package
manager to manage my updates.

122
00:05:26.090 --> 00:05:30.520
So, if a new version comes out,
I just run yum update, or

123
00:05:30.520 --> 00:05:33.440
app update, or app upgrade I guess.

124
00:05:33.440 --> 00:05:37.313
Whatever it is I need to do to update the
packages, and then reach out to repos, and

125
00:05:37.313 --> 00:05:40.928
pull down the new packages, and
update them, all nice and automatic like.

126
00:05:40.928 --> 00:05:43.604
But if I'm building from source,
when an update comes out,

you're gonna use those every single day.

513
00:24:52.710 --> 00:24:54.420
The rest of them are all nice to know.

514
00:24:54.420 --> 00:24:56.940
They make your life easier, and
the more proficient you get with it,

515
00:24:56.940 --> 00:24:59.540
the faster you'll be able
to edit files with vi.

516
00:24:59.540 --> 00:25:00.840
So I wanna walk you through those, but

517
00:25:00.840 --> 00:25:02.650
I don't really have enough
time here in this episode.

518
00:25:02.650 --> 00:25:04.310
So, Daniel, let's do a part two.

519
00:25:04.310 --> 00:25:05.520
>> Sounds good.
>> And we'll treat it like this.

520
00:25:05.520 --> 00:25:07.650
So, part one, these were the core,

521
00:25:07.650 --> 00:25:10.390
fundamental commands we need
to know to work with vi.

522
00:25:10.390 --> 00:25:13.710
And then in Part Two, we're gonna show you
the ones that can really start to ratchet

523
00:25:13.710 --> 00:25:17.860
up your productivity and
take advantage of some of the quick,

524
00:25:17.860 --> 00:25:20.000
large scale bulk editing
that we can do inside of vi.

525
00:25:20.000 --> 00:25:21.330
>> All right, well Don, sounds great,

526
00:25:21.330 --> 00:25:25.260
I can't wait to see what's gonna go on
inside of that Part Two because I know

527
00:25:25.260 --> 00:25:28.390
my vi skills could definitely use

528
00:25:28.390 --> 00:25:30.170
Most of us are in the same boat.

529
00:25:30.170 --> 00:25:32.790
So thanks for joining us today,
we appreciate your time and effort.

530
00:25:32.790 --> 00:25:34.930
Appreciate our audience out there for
watching.

531
00:25:34.930 --> 00:25:38.340
But as the man has said, we are out of
time for this episode, come on back for

00:25:38.340 --> 00:25:40.390
that part two and
learn a little more about vi though.

00:25:40.390 --> 00:25:43.190
Signing off for ITPro.TV,

Specifically, he demonstrates how to copy and paste, work with multiple lines at once, and how to search through a document.

>> All right, greetings, everyone, and

7
00:00:16.482 --> 00:00:18.050

8

00:00:21.180 --> 00:00:22.378

00:00:26.180 --> 00:00:29.960
