12
00:00:29.960 --> 00:00:30.860
Don, welcome back, sir.

13

14
00:00:31.590 --> 00:00:32.810
>> It is going just well, Daniel.

15
00:00:32.810 --> 00:00:33.740
We're gonna dive right back in and

00:00:33.740 --> 00:00:37.550
go a little further into vi than
we did in the last episode.

17
00:00:37.550 --> 00:00:41.140
Last episode kind of served as a primer,
teaching us the basics that we need to

18
00:00:41.140 --> 00:00:44.260
know just to get in,
edit a file, save, and get out.

19
00:00:44.260 --> 00:00:47.782
But now, I wanna kick it up a notch and go

20
00:00:47.782 --> 00:00:50.686
that are, I mean, it's not super advanced,
but delete stuff.

21
00:00:50.686 --> 00:00:52.288
>> [LAUGH]
>> Things like that, but

22
00:00:52.288 --> 00:00:55.831
they are important, ones that will
make our job a little bit easier and

23
00:00:55.831 --> 00:00:59.455
help you to see how vi can be used to
quickly and efficiently edit files.

24
00:00:59.455 --> 00:01:02.829
>> Well, Don, it'll be a lot of fun
because I know that once I've written

25
00:01:02.829 --> 00:01:04.515
up that letter, that email to you,

26
00:01:04.515 --> 00:01:08.310
or just my first draft of it,
that tells you how much I can't stand you.

27
00:01:08.310 --> 00:01:11.205
I realize, yeah, it felt good to write,
but I probably shouldn't send that.

28
00:01:11.205 --> 00:01:13.341
>> [LAUGH]
>> Get it out of the file that we're

29
00:01:13.341 --> 00:01:15.753
sharing, and
deletion is a good place to start.

30
00:01:15.753 --> 00:01:16.811
Let's start there.

31
00:01:16.811 --> 00:01:20.442
>> [LAUGH] All right, so let's go, and
we'll jump back into that Moby Dick file

32
00:01:20.442 --> 00:01:24.095
that I've been kind of using this show,
and we'll edit that one.

33
00:01:24.095 --> 00:01:26.765
And let's say that I wanna
delete some data out of here.

34
00:01:26.765 --> 00:01:30.235
Well, if you're in insert mode, so
I'll press i to get into insert mode,

35
00:01:30.235 --> 00:01:33.485
you can just move wherever you want,
and you can use your Backspace and

36
00:01:33.485 --> 00:01:35.605
Delete keys just like normal, right?

37
00:01:35.605 --> 00:01:37.790
So it's not too big of a deal there.

38
00:01:37.790 --> 00:01:40.570
We can go through and
we can delete things just like normal.

39
00:01:40.570 --> 00:01:43.790
But if I wanna delete an entire line,
like let's say this line here,

40
00:01:43.790 --> 00:01:47.840
this START OF THIS PROJECT GUTENBERG
EBOOK MOBY DICK; OR THE WHALE.

41
00:01:47.840 --> 00:01:49.200
So I wanna delete that whole line.

42
00:01:49.200 --> 00:01:50.960
Well, I could move to it and

43
00:01:50.960 --> 00:01:53.600
then hold down the Delete key
while it slowly went away.

44
00:01:53.600 --> 00:01:54.490
>> That's fun.

45
00:01:54.490 --> 00:01:57.265
>> Or we could take advantage of, well,

46
00:01:57.265 --> 00:02:02.050
vi's plethora of shortcuts and
commands that can do the same thing.

47
00:02:02.050 --> 00:02:06.060
So for example, if I hit Escape,
I'm in command mode now.

48
00:02:06.060 --> 00:02:09.061
And in command mode, it is important to
pay attention where the cursor is cuz I'm

49
00:02:09.061 --> 00:02:12.590
gonna tell it to delete
a line that I'm on, right?

50
00:02:12.590 --> 00:02:16.543
And the old way of doing it without
the colon would be to use the d command.

51
00:02:16.543 --> 00:02:19.311
And if I press d twice,
it will delete this sign.

52
00:02:19.311 --> 00:02:22.466
And so if you watch down here
at the bottom of my screen,

53
00:02:22.466 --> 00:02:24.370
I'm gonna press d, right?

54
00:02:24.370 --> 00:02:26.520
There's the first d, and
nothing has happened.

55
00:02:26.520 --> 00:02:30.130
And then I can hit d again and
then with that line, all right?

56
00:02:30.130 --> 00:02:32.270
So if I wanna delete one,
I can certainly do that.

57
00:02:32.270 --> 00:02:36.278
And I can just come up here and I can keep
doing it, dd, dd, dd, woo hoo, all right,

58
00:02:36.278 --> 00:02:37.114
so-
>> [LAUGH]

59
00:02:37.114 --> 00:02:38.900
>> Just going through it and deleting it.

60
00:02:38.900 --> 00:02:42.680
The newer way to do it, the colon-based
command, would be to come in and

61
00:02:42.680 --> 00:02:46.190
pick a line, like this Produced
by Daniel Lazarus and Jonesey,

62
00:02:46.190 --> 00:02:51.070
apparently, and I will do a colon and
then just d, all right?

63
00:02:51.070 --> 00:02:54.510
A single d, the same amount of keystrokes,
right, but :d, and

64
00:02:54.510 --> 00:02:56.410
that will tell it to delete that line.

65
00:02:56.410 --> 00:03:01.738
So same basic command, just being issued
again to go in and delete that line.

66
00:03:01.738 --> 00:03:05.226
So pretty straightforward there,
you can choose to ignore one and

67
00:03:05.226 --> 00:03:06.290
just use the other.

68
00:03:06.290 --> 00:03:08.934
Maybe I like dd better than :d, but

69
00:03:08.934 --> 00:03:13.446
I tend to use the colon command,
so :d knocks out that line.

70
00:03:13.446 --> 00:03:16.290
>> All right, well, Don, another
fundamental thing that we use when we're

71
00:03:16.290 --> 00:03:19.240
editing text is the copy and paste,
right, that we couldn't live without.

72
00:03:19.240 --> 00:03:21.390
This is a must have.

73
00:03:21.390 --> 00:03:23.308
Am I just highlighting text and
right-clicking?

74
00:03:23.308 --> 00:03:24.657
Wait, I might be ahead of the system,
right?

75
00:03:24.657 --> 00:03:25.536
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

76
00:03:25.536 --> 00:03:28.090
vi was developed before the mouse.

77
00:03:28.090 --> 00:03:31.760
So we don't have a mouse cursor where
you can just go and highlight text and

78
00:03:31.760 --> 00:03:32.390
copy and paste.

79
00:03:32.390 --> 00:03:34.760
I mean, you actually do if
you're on your desktop, right?

80
00:03:34.760 --> 00:03:36.960
I can come in, and
I can highlight and copy and paste.

81
00:03:36.960 --> 00:03:39.710
But if I'm SSHed into a server or
something like that,

82
00:03:39.710 --> 00:03:41.200
I might not have that functionality.

83
00:03:41.200 --> 00:03:45.098
So you can actually do copy and
paste right from the inside of vi.

84
00:03:45.098 --> 00:03:47.270
They don't call it copy and paste though.

85
00:03:47.270 --> 00:03:49.280
They call it yank and put.

86
00:03:49.280 --> 00:03:52.430
Remember, this stuff was developed back
before these were standard industry terms.

87
00:03:52.430 --> 00:03:54.410
And so
they could call it whatever they wanted.

88
00:03:54.410 --> 00:03:59.650
And so we can yank text from the screen,
and we can put it somewhere else, right?

89
00:03:59.650 --> 00:04:03.131
So if I wanna yank text,
I can come up to a line and

90
00:04:03.131 --> 00:04:05.408
I can use the y command to yank.

91
00:04:05.408 --> 00:04:08.872
And again, I can do yy or
I can do :y, either one.

92
00:04:10.100 --> 00:04:13.220
And so I'll do yy, for example.

93
00:04:13.220 --> 00:04:16.810
Now when I do that,
nothing really changes on the screen.

94
00:04:16.810 --> 00:04:19.816
Right, and that's because I've
copied that line into my buffer.

95
00:04:19.816 --> 00:04:24.470
And I can move to another place and
I can say, p, to put,

96
00:04:24.470 --> 00:04:27.850
and now it puts that line right there.

97
00:04:27.850 --> 00:04:30.197
So now I've got it and
I can do it over and over again.

98
00:04:30.197 --> 00:04:33.048
And you keep putting, cuz it's stored
in the memory buffer, right, so

99
00:04:33.048 --> 00:04:35.380
you can keep laying that
memory buffer out there.

100
00:04:35.380 --> 00:04:36.420
And we're now putting it in.

101
00:04:36.420 --> 00:04:38.430
So we've copied and pasted.

102
00:04:38.430 --> 00:04:41.630
Now feel free to use your mouse.

103
00:04:41.630 --> 00:04:43.600
Use your GUI if you've got it.

104
00:04:43.600 --> 00:04:46.110
You can cut and paste all you want, right?

105
00:04:46.110 --> 00:04:50.440
But be careful, here, I'm copying and
pasting using the command mode.

106
00:04:50.440 --> 00:04:54.760
If I use my mouse and I come in and
I highlight this line, right, and

107
00:04:54.760 --> 00:04:58.820
I copy it, right, or I think in
GNOME terminal, it's Ctrl+Shift+C.

108
00:04:58.820 --> 00:05:00.280
And then I go and paste it.

109
00:05:00.280 --> 00:05:02.630
Well, I'm still in command mode.

110
00:05:02.630 --> 00:05:04.605
I don't wanna paste
anything in command mode,

111
00:05:04.605 --> 00:05:06.410
there's a lot of commands
that I'd be sending.

112
00:05:06.410 --> 00:05:10.100
So you gotta make sure you get
into insert mode before you start

113
00:05:10.100 --> 00:05:12.770
pasting with your GUI or
whatever if you do that.

114
00:05:12.770 --> 00:05:17.570
But if you wanna be a purist and just
use y, you've got y for yank and p for

115
00:05:17.570 --> 00:05:19.573
put, easy to copy and paste.

116
00:05:19.573 --> 00:05:24.442
>> Now Don, I've noticed that sometimes
when I'm using vi, I'm in command mode,

117
00:05:24.442 --> 00:05:28.889
and my cursor will start jumping around
cuz I forgot to go into insert mode or

118
00:05:28.889 --> 00:05:29.688
something.

119
00:05:29.688 --> 00:05:34.240
And I'm typing something away, maybe like
this, and I notice that my cursor moves.

120
00:05:34.240 --> 00:05:35.513
What is going on there?

121
00:05:35.513 --> 00:05:39.787
>> All right, so again,
this was all developed before mice.

122
00:05:39.787 --> 00:05:44.008
In the olden days, there were several
different keyboards that were used, and

123
00:05:44.008 --> 00:05:46.320
not every keyboard had arrow keys on them.

124
00:05:46.320 --> 00:05:48.129
Most of us, you look at your laptop or
your desktop, and

125
00:05:48.129 --> 00:05:49.217
you've got arrow keys on there.

126
00:05:49.217 --> 00:05:50.692
And you can use them to navigate,

127
00:05:50.692 --> 00:05:53.410
I'm doing it here in this
show all the time, right?

128
00:05:53.410 --> 00:05:56.470
But if you didn't have arrow keys or
if your arrow keys didn't work,

129
00:05:56.470 --> 00:05:59.650
if you are remoted into a terminal
session that didn't sport arrow keys,

130
00:05:59.650 --> 00:06:01.560
you needed a different way to navigate.

131
00:06:01.560 --> 00:06:05.810
So, inside of vi,
it actually mapped a series of keys.

132
00:06:05.810 --> 00:06:08.930
It's the H, J, K, L keys.

133
00:06:08.930 --> 00:06:12.535
On a US keyboard, they're all
right in a row, H, J, K, and L.

134
00:06:12.535 --> 00:06:15.810
And can we show my keyboard for a second?

135
00:06:15.810 --> 00:06:19.770
So here you can see on my keyboard where
the H, J, K, and L, they're all in a row.

136
00:06:19.770 --> 00:06:21.612
And because of my little
cheating stickers,

137
00:06:21.612 --> 00:06:23.410
I see the little arrow
keys that are on here.

138
00:06:23.410 --> 00:06:28.240
The H is left and L is right,
J is down, K is up, all right?

139
00:06:28.240 --> 00:06:31.930
They don't actually stand for something,
like H isn't higher or whatever.

140
00:06:31.930 --> 00:06:34.020
It's just, they're all in a row,
they're convenient to use.

141
00:06:34.020 --> 00:06:36.270
You can place one hand on them and
navigate around.

142
00:06:36.270 --> 00:06:41.230
So when I'm in the command mode,
if I press H, J, K,

143
00:06:41.230 --> 00:06:46.120
or L, I'm gonna move around based
on which of those that I hit.

144
00:06:46.120 --> 00:06:49.279
And that's what normally happens when
somebody forgets that they're in command

145
00:06:49.279 --> 00:06:51.166
mode or
doesn't even know what command mode is.

146
00:06:51.166 --> 00:06:52.974
And they just try and start typing.

147
00:06:52.974 --> 00:06:56.381
They'll use our arrow keys to move where
they want, and then they'll start to type.

148
00:06:56.381 --> 00:06:59.310
And if I type the word this, T-H,

149
00:06:59.310 --> 00:07:03.969
eventually, shoot-
>> T and I, [LAUGH].

150
00:07:03.969 --> 00:07:07.623
>> But it will start moving that cursor
around, and they won't know why.

151
00:07:07.623 --> 00:07:09.457
Right, and
it's because of those keys that are there.

152
00:07:09.457 --> 00:07:11.750
Now those keys are valuable.

153
00:07:11.750 --> 00:07:15.060
Because I find even today, there'll be
times where I've remoted into a server and

154
00:07:15.060 --> 00:07:16.690
my arrow keys aren't working.

155
00:07:16.690 --> 00:07:18.963
And so you fall back to using those,
H, J, K, and L.

156
00:07:18.963 --> 00:07:20.177
And you can navigate around using it.

157
00:07:20.177 --> 00:07:22.039
>> Yeah,
God forbid you type the word history.

158
00:07:22.039 --> 00:07:25.716
Because then it would be H, which would
move your cursor to the left, and then I,

159
00:07:25.716 --> 00:07:27.135
which would be in insert mode.

160
00:07:27.135 --> 00:07:30.141
Then S, which will actually start
typing into the wrong spot.

161
00:07:30.141 --> 00:07:32.947
And it freaks you out, it's like,
it kinda takes you out of your element.

162
00:07:32.947 --> 00:07:34.133
You're like, what is going on?

163
00:07:34.133 --> 00:07:37.163
And it can really disturb your calm,

164
00:07:37.163 --> 00:07:41.868
[LAUGH] if you don't understand
what the heck is going on.

165
00:07:41.868 --> 00:07:44.141
>> Yeah, absolutely,
and you can fix it, but

166
00:07:44.141 --> 00:07:47.100
it gets kind of annoying having
to go back and fix things.

167
00:07:47.100 --> 00:07:48.730
You wanna try and avoid that.

168
00:07:48.730 --> 00:07:51.729
All right, now, I have made quite a bit
of a mess of my little file here with all

169
00:07:51.729 --> 00:07:52.801
these lines that I pasted.

170
00:07:52.801 --> 00:07:53.850
>> Gone a little berserk.

171
00:07:53.850 --> 00:07:55.610
>> And if I wanna delete them,
I can sit here and

172
00:07:55.610 --> 00:07:57.510
do individual deletes over and over again.

173
00:07:57.510 --> 00:08:02.090
But one of the more powerful commands that
we have inside of vim is that we can do

174
00:08:02.090 --> 00:08:02.900
ranges.

175
00:08:02.900 --> 00:08:06.676
We can have a command applied not just
to one line, but more than one line.

176
00:08:06.676 --> 00:08:08.684
All right, we don't see it here.

177
00:08:08.684 --> 00:08:11.560
Well, I guess we sort of see it,
my head's on it.

178
00:08:11.560 --> 00:08:14.850
But at the bottom right, you see those
numbers that are changing, all right?

179
00:08:14.850 --> 00:08:16.297
Those numbers are tracking
what line I'm on.

180
00:08:16.297 --> 00:08:18.170
So right now, I'm on line 27.

181
00:08:18.170 --> 00:08:19.729
And then I'm on line 30.

182
00:08:19.729 --> 00:08:22.660
And now I'm on line 35, all right?

183
00:08:22.660 --> 00:08:26.940
And as I navigate around looking at
this stuff, as I move to the right, see,

184
00:08:26.940 --> 00:08:28.490
the second number is changing.

185
00:08:28.490 --> 00:08:31.627
I'm on line 30 and
I'm 16 characters in, or

186
00:08:31.627 --> 00:08:35.844
I'm 25 characters in, right,
so it's tracking that for me.

187
00:08:35.844 --> 00:08:39.452
If I wanted to delete a range of lines,
I could say, look,

188
00:08:39.452 --> 00:08:44.870
it starts here on line 25, all the way
down here to line 33, these are bad lines.

189
00:08:44.870 --> 00:08:47.246
I wanna get rid of 25 to 33, all right?

190
00:08:47.246 --> 00:08:50.676
Now I know that :d will delete a line, but

191
00:08:50.676 --> 00:08:54.510
I can actually put a range
of lines right here.

192
00:08:54.510 --> 00:09:00.246
I could say 25,33d, that's gonna go in and
delete all of those lines,

193
00:09:00.246 --> 00:09:05.520
or hopefully, it will delete all
of those lines if we were right.

194
00:09:05.520 --> 00:09:08.330
So I'm gonna run that,
and they all go away.

195
00:09:08.330 --> 00:09:10.430
I just deleted a range of lines.

196
00:09:10.430 --> 00:09:12.350
And that's really handy with the copy and
